[Card-Carrying Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CardCarryingVillain): Downplayed - he's fully aware that he has no principles, and he blatantly admits as much to Barrett in his [At Least I Admit It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AtLeastIAdmitIt) speech, but he's pragmatic enough to make himself a [Villain with Good Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainWithGoodPublicity).

[Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive): The President of the Shinra Corporation, President Shinra is shown to be a greedy and ruthless tyrant who rules over Midgar through fear, crushing those who oppose him with his corporation's private army and the Turks.

[Destination Defenestration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DestinationDefenestration):  (SPOILER) When the party follows the trail of Jenova blood to his office, they discover a hole in one of the windows, with President Shinra dangling off a railing outside, calling out for help. It is all but stated that Sephiroth attempted to kill him by throwing him through the window.

[Dies Differently in Adaptation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiesDifferentlyInAdaptation):  (SPOILER) In the original game, he was [Killed Offscreen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffscreen) after capturing the AVALANCHE members who raided Shinra HQ, and the party finds him impaled with Sephiroth's sword, thus confirming that he was the killer. In the remake, he actually survives Sephiroth's initial rampage, and manipulates AVALANCHE into rescuing him before holding them at gunpoint. It's at this point that Sephiroth shows up again and finishes him off in full view of the party.

[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): He is quick to beg for his life when dangling off a building,  (SPOILER) even asking Avalanche for mercy. But once he grabs a gun, he's quick to talk tough again.

[Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): Despite Sephiroth's early appearance President Shinra still drives a great deal of *Remake.*  (SPOILER) At the end of *Remake* he dies and Sephiroth becomes the more direct antagonist of the party, while Rufus assumes his place as head of Shinra itself.

[The Emperor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmperor): Like in the original. Officially he is the owner and CEO of a conglomerate, but in practice he is this. Wields absolute, unchecked power? Check. Is the boss of a superpower? Check. Is in control of large amounts of the planet? Check. Has expansionist and conquest policies? Check. Commands vast armies? Check. Controls politics? Check. Can hand it all off to his kid? Check. The fact that Barret explicitly calls Rufus the "heir to the throne" is practically just lampshade hanging.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Implied. Following Professor Hojo's suggestion that they *forcibly impregnate* Aerith and turn her into their own [Breeding Slave](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreedingSlave), he quickly adjourns the meeting and refuses to discuss the matter any further. It's probably the only example of him possibly displaying *any* kind of morality in the entire game, and even then it's quite questionable...

[Godhood Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodhoodSeeker): While he never makes any direct claims of godhood, his goal is to fulfil the legends of the Ancients, find their Promised Land of limitless mako, and build a utopia there that he will rule over.

[Gold-Colored Superiority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldColoredSuperiority): President Shinra has many gold adorned and accented items in his posession and scattered throughout the Shinra building, including a gold-plated Desert Eagle pistol. A massive golden statue of himself even looms over visitors to the Shinra Museum inside the tower. All of which symbolize his self-proclaimed position at the top of the global hierarchy.
[Good Smoking, Evil Smoking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodSmokingEvilSmoking): He smokes a cigar during the board meeting and is very, very evil.

[The Hedonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHedonist): A more [Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive) version of the trope than usual but President Shinra outright admits that he has no principles aside from "I know what I want, and I take it." This pursuit of self-gratification leans heavily into his role as a [Straw Nihilist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrawNihilist): He doesn't care about any higher values except furthering his own self-interests and vanity. It even plays into his long-term goals of Godhood Seeking: It's all just to indulge his greed and elitist desire to live an even more opulent life.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite):
    - During the confrontation outside Mako Reactor 5, Barret accuses the President of having [brainwashed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Brainwashed) the populace into compliance. President Shinra denies this notion, claiming that it's beneath him to resort to such methods... [only to then immediately reveal his plan to use propaganda to make the populace believe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistinctionWithoutADifference) [an Avalanche/Wutai conspiracy is responsible for the terrorist attacks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl) so that the people will be fine with reigniting the war again. The fact that he owns the media and liberally uses them to make himself a [Villain with Good Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainWithGoodPublicity) *really* stretches the notion that he's not brainwashing people. - Calls out Barret for caring more about Avalanche's reputation than actually shutting down the reactors, calling concepts like truth, honour, justice, and freedom "vain indulgences"... These accusations coming from a man holding a [Bling-Bling-BANG!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlingBlingBang) gun and who has a golden statue of himself displayed as a prominent showpiece a couple of floors down, it more so emphasizes his own nihilistic hypocrisy than the actual point he's making. Given that this is a part of his [At Least I Admit It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AtLeastIAdmitIt) speech, this is likely intentional: At least he's honest about being an unprincipled narcissist.

[Impaled with Extreme Prejudice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice):  (SPOILER) Like the original, this is his fate at the hands of Sephiroth, as he gets stabbed through the back with his katana and left to die. Unlike the original, the party is actually around to witness it.

[I Was Quite the Looker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWasQuiteTheLooker): Hard as it may be to imagine, there's an old picture of him from his days as an upstart young businessman that shows he was the spitting image of his son. Years of living a life filled with bloodshed and corruption has clearly taken its toll on Shinra Sr.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): During their initial confrontation at Reactor 5, Barret accuses him and his company of sucking the planet's lifeforce dry. Shinra dryly notes that it's true, but it's also no secret. *Everyone* knows where Mako comes from, and the vast majority of citizens consider it a fair trade for the convenience electricity brings. He notes that Barret should be as angry towards them as he is towards Shinra, since they are effectively complicit. He's absolutely right on this. Not only is Shinra's immense power only possible because people readily, eagerly buy their electricity while knowing how it is made, but ambient dialogue from  NPCs  around Midgard shows the majority of them are in favor of the reactors.
[Narcissist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Narcissist): The man has an entire museum dedicated to *himself* right beneath his office, complete with a huge gold statue right at the front entrance.

[Non-Action Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionBigBad): Unlike his son and heir Rufus, he doesn't appear to have any knowledge or proficiency in combat. That said, guns [(at least in cutscenes)](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation) are a great equalizer and he is able to have Barret at his mercy after getting the drop on him with a handgun.
[Only One Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyOneName): His first name is never once mentioned in the story, with everyone else simply referring to him by his title.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): He is very stern on the forces of Shinra and Hojo not *physically* harming Aerith, since as the last Ancient she's valuable to him beyond measure. Abduct her and experiment on her using whatever means get the job done, but don't risk killing her.

[Right for the Wrong Reasons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RightForTheWrongReasons): Claims that Avalanche is working with Wutai to destroy Midgar, giving his company an excuse to [wage war again](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarForFunAndProfit). In the  INTERmission  DLC, it turns out that agents of Wutai *are* working with Avalanche, though they aren't backing Avalanche as much as Shinra claims, and are operating in a much smaller capacity.
[Self-Made Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfMadeMan): He single-handedly raised the company up from a small arms manufacturer to a massive conglomerate.

[Slouch of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlouchOfVillainy): He's first seen watching a screen Barret and his crew infiltrating Mako Reactor 1 while slouching in his chair a top of Shinra Tower, surrounded by other [Ominous Multiple Screens](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousMultipleScreens).

[The Sociopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSociopath): He has no qualms with dropping the Sector 7 plate, killing thousands of people who live on or under the plate, for an excuse to start a war with Wutai, and plans on abandoning Midgar to build a new city in the Promised Land. When Barret confronts him and demands to know what principles he has, President Shinra coldly declares that he will use anyone and anything at his disposal to get what he wants and discard those who are no longer useful to him, and that "There is no room for sentiment or guilt."

[Straw Nihilist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrawNihilist): He mocks values such as truth, honor, freedom and justice, believing them to be "vain indulgences", as he describes them. In particular, he calls out Barret's demands for clearing Avalanche's name, saying that Barret is ultimately more interested in preserving Avalanche's reputation than saving Midgar or the planet. In keeping with the trope he's also [The Hedonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHedonist) and [The Sociopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSociopath).

[Trumplica](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Trumplica): President Shinra in the original game acted as a stand-in and gross exaggeration of many contemporary famous 90s billionaires and business tycoons, [Donald Trump](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/DonaldTrump) among them. The Remake emphasizes the comparisons (actual or imagined) in the wake of Trump's ascension to and fall from the United States Presidency, and all the power and pageantry that office represents. Remake Shinra even *looks* vaguely like Trump, to further the allegory.
[The Unfettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered): As he puts it in his grand speech towards Barret; when he sees something he wants, he takes it.

[Ungrateful Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBastard): Towards the end of the game,  (SPOILER) Barret begrudgingly saves President Shinra from falling off the roof of his own skyscraper, demanding that he pay this act of kindness back by confessing his wrongdoings. Shinra then proceeds to pull a gun on him and mock his sentimentality. It only earns him a sword through the back [courtesy of Sephiroth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousRescue) .

[Villain Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainHasAPoint):
    - He points out to Barret that everyone in Midgar knows the exact nature of mako and the lifestream and yet they are perfectly fine with Shinra exploiting mako for power if it means they benefit from it by having easy access to electricity; thus, every person in the city is complicit in Shinra's deeds. QUOTE **President Shinra**: Picture it! Picture a world without Shinra. Without Mako energy. [A stagnant, impotent world](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreativeSterility). Now picture a *natural* disaster. Who would help the people? Help them recover and rebuild? You? [With their old world ruined](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRevolutionWillNotBeCivilized), [will they thank you for the new](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReignOfTerror)? - (SPOILER) When Barret saves him from falling to his death off the top of the Shinra headquarters, his demands (when the President had offered him anything he wanted to save him) are to make a public broadcast admitting Shinra were the ones who dropped the Sector 7 plate, and Avalanche is an independent anti-Shinra group with no connections to Wutai. Once he has a gun and feels more confident, the President points out that Barret could have demanded they shut down the mako reactors, but all he asked is for the President to clear their names. He directly calls out that having such priorities shows Barret's true interests and motives are self-interest, covered by a veneer of altruism and heroics.

[Villain with Good Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainWithGoodPublicity): He's much more successful at framing Avalanche as terrorists working for Wutai while playing up Shinra's rescue efforts. Most of Midgar's residents thus have a much worse view of them than of Shinra. It helps that he owns the news.

[Villains Want Mercy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainsWantMercy): Near the end of the game,  (SPOILER) when he's dangling off the roof of the Shinra Building, he begs Avalanche to save him. Barret begrudgingly does so on the grounds he clear Avalanche's name in regards to the destruction of Sector 7; instead, the minute he's back on solid ground, he pulls a gun on him.

[Xanatos Gambit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/XanatosGambit): His handling of Avalanche's attacks on the mako reactors. If Avalanche is stopped, Shinra continues business as usual, with some good publicity for stopping a terrorist attack. If the attack succeeds, Shinra destroys the reactors themselves (while maximizing collateral damage) and frames Avalanche, turning public opinion against them.
[Adaptation Dye-Job](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationDyeJob): In the original game, his hair was of orange shade. Here, it's more of a platinum blonde.
[Adaptation Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationNameChange): Not him but rather his guard dog, Darkstar, who was named *Dark Nation* in the original.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): In the original game Rufus was a very unremarkable boss: his only move was a shotgun blast that did mediocre damage, he was reliant on support from his attack dog Dark Nation to give him defensive buffs and attack Cloud, and he had pitiful HP compared to other bosses around the same time. In *Remake*, Rufus is a fully capable combatant in his own right, able to use [Gun Kata](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunKata) to parry Cloud's attacks and jet around the arena, he utilizes trick coins to create laser blasts, explosions, and smoke fields, and his shotgun is a [Combo Rifle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComboRifle) that can split into two capable of rapid fire. He's even more dangerous with Darkstar by his side, as the two can protect each other and combo their attacks together, such as Darkstar knocking Cloud into the air for Rufus to shoot back down.

[Adaptational Heroism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalHeroism): Only in a relative sense. Rufus's introductory speech from the original game about controlling the masses through fear instead of [Bread and Circuses](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreadAndCircuses) makes no appearance in this incarnation, with his father absorbing most of that leadership style for himself and leaving the question of how Rufus will run Shinra much more up in the air. Most of his screentime is instead spent on building up his status as a worthy opponent to Cloud. In *Rebirth*, Rufus has his priorities enough in order that he tries cutting a deal with the party to leave each other alone until the much more pressing problem of Sephiroth is dealt with, calls out the board of directors on going along with his father's insane plan to destroy Sector 7, and while he still mistakenly believes that there's a Promised Land for him to find and conquer, Rufus does want to confirm that it actually *exists* before he stakes everything on it. All of this seems to be in keeping with Rufus' [Hazy-Feel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HazyFeelTurn) in *[Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/FinalFantasyVIIAdventChildren)*, as well as subsequent Compilation media that have consistently painted him as more inclined towards [Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy) than his father's [Stupid Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StupidEvil).

[Adaptational Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalNiceGuy): Also relative. Rufus is complimentary to Cloud during his boss battle [and seems to respect that Cloud was giving him a real fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent). He also seems to have some degree of legitimate affection for Darkstar, given he refers to it as ["D"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffectionateNickname) and motions for it to retreat after it's been critically beaten by Cloud.

[Adaptational Intelligence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalIntelligence): In the original game when Cloud's party infiltrated Junon diguised as Shinra Grunts, Rufus walked right up to them after the parade and didn't even notice. In *Rebirth* he (along with the rest of the Turks) are able to easily see through their [Paper Thin Disguises](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaperThinDisguise) but let them approach him as a means of communicating with them in order to cut a deal with them. At the end of the game, he also realizes that  (SPOILER) "Glenn" is actually working for Sephiroth and using the brewing Wutai-Shinra war to keep Rufus from being able to do anything about Sephiroth, although he doesn't realize that Glenn actually *is* Sephiroth until the latter drops the ruse .
[Affectionate Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffectionateNickname): Refers to Darkstar as "D" when issuing certain commands.
[Age Lift](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AgeLift): He was 25 in the original, but was aged up to 30 in *Remake*.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): Both Rufus and his pet Dark Nation/Darkstar get this. Compared to the original, far more focus is given in *Rebirth* to how Rufus tries to keep other Shinra directors under his control and deal with the upcoming war against Wutai. In addition, his rivalry against Cloud is played up as he goes out of his way to duel the ex-SOLDIER in both *Remake* and *Rebirth*. Dark Nation/Darkstar goes from a single-battle support during Rufus' boss fight in the original and *Remake* to his faithful canine companion/attack hound that is consistently by its master's side throughout *Rebirth.*
[Attack Animal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackAnimal): For his duel with Cloud, he is accompanied by his guard dog, Darkstar.

[Authority in Name Only](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorityInNameOnly): Despite being the "Vice President" of Shinra Inc., Rufus was functionally living in exile [Reassigned to Antarctica](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReassignedToAntarctica) after running afoul of (and attempting to assasinate) his father President Shinra. As such, his vice presidency was a ceremonial position granted only because he was the President's son. Heidegger initially tries to reinforce this by calling him "Mr. Vice President" after Rufus assumes control of Shinra Inc. during the epilogue to *Remake*, but Tseng quickly refutes it calling him "Mr. *President*", to which Rufus responds "That's right."

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): Even more than in the original. While Darkstar is genetically engineered and equipped with magic spells, Rufus himself doesn't have any supernatural abilities that even the Turks demonstrate here and there. Armed with a highly-modified shotgun and some [trick coins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser), he's able to square off surprisingly evenly with Cloud even after sending Darkstar away.

[Baddie Flattery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaddieFlattery): He thinks quite highly of himself, but he considers Cloud a [Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent) and is completely frank about how much exertion the ex-SOLDIER is requiring him to expend during their battle.

[Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe): Albeit, an extremely effective one who always appears to be on the cusp of being *the* [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad). For all his ability, and the constant threat he poses to Avalanche, he's ultimately just another pawn to Sephiroth's machinations.  (SPOILER) For what it's worth, he's just about the only character who seems to make Sephiroth sweat, as he goes through a hell of a lot of effort into manipulating him, engineering an entire war just to prevent turning him into a potential enemy. Not half bad for a [Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe).

[Chick Magnet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChickMagnet): Maybe not to the same extent as Cloud, but Rufus has his fair share of in-universe fan girls all across the Planet as many of the NPC comments on how handsome he is when brought up in conversation.
[Cold Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColdHam): Rufus rarely raises his voice above a bored sounding monotone, but he speaks with the eloquence and confidence befitting the President of Shinra.

[Combat Pragmatist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatPragmatist): After demonstrating how he can shoot coins out of the air to produce deadly attacks, he flips more coins but this time, when Cloud's eyes follow them into the air, Rufus uses them as a distraction to allow himself to close and attack Cloud directly.
[Combination Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack): Rufus has many attacks that he can use with Darkstar for the first couple phases of his fight.
[Combo Rifle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComboRifle): His new shotgun can now split into a pair of automatic [Hand Cannons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandCannon).

[Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive): Rufus is an arrogant man who's spoiled by Daddy's money, and upon finding out Cloud is a SOLDIER says that this means he "owns [him]".

[Counter-Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CounterAttack): Rufus can respond to Cloud's physical attacks and skills by parrying them and opening him up for a free shot in the back, limiting how reckless Cloud can afford to be regarding CQC. Rufus can't counter while he is preoccupied using skills or staggered and if he's out of bullets he's forced to reload instead of attack after the parry.

[Daddy's Little Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DaddysLittleVillain): The apple didn't fall far from the tree; though Rufus bears no affection for his father, he's inherited every bit of his corporate degeneracy.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): He's got quite the silver tongue, particularly when it comes to his duels with Cloud, who he smugly still refers to as an employee of his despite Cloud quitting (and being explicitly defiant against) Shinra.
QUOTE **Rufus:** *(referring to Darkstar)* As you can see, he's very loyal.

QUOTE **Cloud:** Yeah. You don't bite the hand that feeds.

QUOTE **Rufus:** And yet here you are.
[Dragon Ascendant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonAscendant): He becomes the new president of the company after his father is killed.

[Dual Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss): He's fought alongside his dog, Darkstar. In a twist, you are required to deplete Darkstar's HP before you can even drain Rufus' HP.
QUOTE **Rufus:** Just the two of us... Well, maybe three.

[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): Darkstar leaves in the final phase of his battle, so Cloud faces Rufus one-on-one.
QUOTE **Cloud:** It's on for real now?<br data-format="\\"/>**Rufus:** Yeah. You should be honored.

[Even Evil Has Loved Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasLovedOnes):
    - He seems to care for his pet, Darkstar, as he sends it away from the fight once its HP is gone. (SPOILER) And *Rebirth* shows that the feeling is mutual as after Rufus takes enough damage during his fight with Cloud at the tournament, Darkstar will jump in to assist him. - Averted in regard to his father, who he cares so little for that his ascension to the position of President upon the old man's death matters much more to him than the loss of his father did. Of course, given his father is a sociopathic scumbag…

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards):
    - Would-be fascist dictator he may be, but in *Rebirth* he calls the Shinra board of directors out on not having the guts to stand up to his father, especially when it came to his more ruthless actions like destroying Sector 7. - In Chapter 14, (SPOILER) when Hojo offers to tend to an injured Tseng, Rufus turns him down, preventing Hojo from turning Tseng into another Sephiroth clone like Roche.
QUOTE **Hojo:** (SPOILER) Tseng is in grave condition... Perhaps I could help?
**Rufus:** No. The medical team will see to him.*([Beat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Beat))* I think you have enough material. *[cuts to (SPOILER) Roche as a Sephiroth clone ]*
[Explosion Propulsion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExplosionPropulsion): Rufus' guns are powerful enough that he can use the recoil to zip around the arena by shooting behind himself.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): *Rebirth* makes him out to be one for Sephiroth. Both are heirs to power and prestige, with an intense rivalry with Cloud, and a tendency to destroy that which does not aide their agenda. Glenn calls him a Pig-headed, Daddy hating child, when after all is said and done could just as much said about Sephiroth,  (SPOILER) which is notable because Glenn is Sephiroth under a glamor .

[Glass Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlassCannon): As a boss, Rufus hits hard and can easily knock down or stun-lock Cloud, and he counters most frontal attacks. On the other hand, he has really low HP for a late-game boss, and reloading his guns leaves him so vulnerable that he instantly staggers with a single Braver — which may be enough for Cloud to pummel him to death even without a Limit ready.
[Gun Kata](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunKata): His gun lets him parry blows from Cloud and fight him in melee range.

[Guns Akimbo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunsAkimbo): Rufus can split his shotgun into a pair of [Hand Cannons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandCannon) to unload bullets onto Cloud. It's even the skill name.
[Guns vs. Swords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunsVsSwords): The fight against him becomes this once Darkstar leaves, pitting his guns against Cloud's sword.

[Foe Romance Subtext](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FoeRomanceSubtext): Less so "subtext" and more like outright text, where both Cloud and Rufus both lay it on thick with the [Ho Yay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoYay), to the point where their backhanded compliments sound like full-blown flirting. QUOTE **Cloud**: Think you got my number?
**Rufus**: Not at all, you're making me sweat. *[[Pulls two coins out of his pocket](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoesThisRemindYouOfAnything)]* Good thing I came prepared.
[The Gunslinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGunslinger): Rufus is one of the most skilled gunfighters in the world, able to give Cloud a run for his money.
[Hand Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandCannon): Two of them, though he usually wields them [combined into a single shotgun.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComboRifle)

[Improbable Aiming Skills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableAimingSkills): Rufus's Bright Lights attack has him toss two coins in the air and then shoot those coins out of the air with his guns, sending them hurtling towards Cloud at an insane velocity.

[I See Them, Too](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ISeeThemToo): Rufus is so far the only non-party member aside from Sephiroth  (SPOILER)  and as of *Rebirth*, Cissnei,  who has been able to see the Arbiters of Fate. How this is possible and what it means are current unknown.

[Kryptonite Factor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KryptoniteFactor): Like most bosses in the game, Rufus has both an obvious one of these and one that's left to the player to ascertain. If you Assess him, the description mentions that striking him with "a certain special move" when he's reloading will stagger him. That move is Braver, which instantly fills Rufus's entire stagger gauge. His more subtle weakness is  (SPOILER) a one-time vulnerability each to Sleep and Stop, which allows Cloud to easily land a Braver hit .

[Let's Get Dangerous!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LetsGetDangerous): For the first while of the fight, Darkstar is the one that uses the more dangerous attacks while Rufus keeps his distance providing support fire. Then when Darkstar's HP starts to drop, a cutscene plays where Rufus admits Cloud is giving him a challenge, and he pulls out his first pair of trick coins and shoots them to send a pair of laser blasts at Cloud. From then on, Rufus starts using his own special attacks freely, and makes it clear *he's* the one to worry about, not his pet attack dog.

[Let's You and Him Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LetsYouAndHimFight): It's suggested in the ending to *Rebirth* that  (SPOILER)  Sephiroth manipulated Rufus into starting a war with Wutai to prevent him from pulling an [Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine) with Cloud and the gang.

[A Lighter Shade of Black](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ALighterShadeOfBlack): While he may be a villain in his own right, he's much less of an amoral slimeball than his father, and he's not impressed with some of what the late President pulled, such as dropping the Sector 7 plate - he even calls the department heads out on this, figuring that if they truly gave a shit, they would have stopped him.
[Light Is Not Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsNotGood): He wears all white, but he's far from a man with good intentions.

[Money Mauling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoneyMauling): While his primary weapon is his shotgun, in later phases of the fight he produces new attacks by pulling coins out of his coat, tossing them around and shooting them mid-air to produce explosions, obscuring smokescreens, and high-power kinetic projectiles. He also has a [Combination Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack) where he'll toss coins for Darkstar to electrify with thunder, creating [fields of thunder damage.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AreaOfEffect)

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): In the original game, Dark Nation was able to cast Bolt. In *Remake*, Darkstar retains the Thunder spell but with a new utility; it can strike Rufus' gun with lightning to let him fire an electrically charged blast at Cloud, or zap some of Rufus' coins with lightning to create electrical fields on the ground that stun Cloud.

[Nepotism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Nepotism): As noted in the description above, he's the VP of the Shinra company by virtue of being the President's son. The fact that the Shinra company owns and runs a substantial part of the world emphasizes the similarities between corporate nepotism and hereditary monarchy, with Rufus' position being closer to that of the son of an evil emperor. Barret lampshades this by referring to Rufus as the "heir to the throne."
[No Cure for Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoCureForEvil): Averted for Darkstar at least who often prioritizes using Curaga on Rufus should he take any damage. That said, it will never heal itself.

[O.O.C. Is Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness): While Rufus is normally smug (with some moments of annoyance at the other department heads), it's when  (SPOILER)  he notices how Glenn was clapping the same way as Sephiroth upon realizing the ploy of pitting Shinra against Wutai again, and the visual of Glenn and Sephiroth glitching between the two. Rufus actually briefly panics, shooting Glenn as he was about to walk away. Glenn then mocks Rufus about shooting him from behind again, and Rufus angrily immediately rapid-fires his shotgun empty into what is revealed to be another Sephiroth clone.
[Overlord Jr.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverlordJr): He's as much of a [Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive) as his father.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): His guard dog, Darkstar, is supposed to be willing to give its life to protect Rufus. However, Rufus wordlessly motions for it to retreat once Cloud's dealt enough damage to it, ensuring Darkstar's continued survival while Rufus now has to face down the ex-SOLDIER all by himself. It's unclear whether he's being empathetic to it or simply pragmatic about fighting with an injured attack dog that they also presumably put a lot of resources into genetically engineering. Rufus does the same during his match with Cloud at the Gold Saucer arena, calling off Darkstar after being critically beaten by Cloud.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): During the Junon parade, Rufus  (SPOILER)  actually offers Cloud and Co. an [Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine). If they are willing to go after Sephiroth (which they were already planning on doing) Rufus is willing to look the the other way and stop chasing after them.  The reasoning behind it is pretty simple: it would simply drain too many resources to continually pursue the party and if they can get rid of a much bigger threat to BOTH of them, then they're better off not getting in each others way.  (SPOILER)  The deal gets ruined by Yuffie, but the fact is he was willing to put aside his pride in order to ask Cloud for his help .

[Progressively Prettier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProgressivelyPrettier): While Rufus from previous entries was certainly no slouch in the looks department, *Remake* downplays a lot of his sharper features, making him look considerably younger.

[Puzzle Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuzzleBoss): If you do not Assess him and don't manage to figure out what to do against him, the fight against Rufus can easily last over ten times the time it may take to beat him with the puzzle figured out.

[Rank Scales with Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RankScalesWithAsskicking): Played straighter than his original incarnation. During his battle with Cloud, he showcases some fairly elaborate [Gun Kata](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunKata) moves and in general, spends a lot of the fight essentially toying with the ex-SOLDIER.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): He's definitely not the most scrupulous individual, but Rufus is probably one of the most logically-minded and reasonable individuals in the entire organization, next to [Reeve](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate). When presented with the reality of Sephiroth's threat,  (SPOILER) he's even outright ready to pardon Cloud and the Avalanche party to recruit them for hunting the man down — though [Yuffie's failed assassination attempt on him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero) squashes that rather quickly.

[Reassigned to Antarctica](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReassignedToAntarctica): Was placed in charge of an unspecified project across the ocean from Midgar, but those in the know know he was in fact exiled from Midgar by President Shinra.

[Recoil Boost](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecoilBoost): His gun can give him one to help him get around quickly. It's effective enough to double as a sort of improvised [Flash Step](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlashStep).
[Right-Hand Attack Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RightHandAttackDog): Darkstar is a panther-like fiend that Rufus has trained to follow his orders, with it fighting alongside him.

[The Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRival):  (SPOILER) By the time of *Rebirth*, he clearly considers himself Cloud's rival as he enters the fighting tournament just to have the opportunity to have a rematch with Cloud.

[Running Both Sides](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningBothSides): During *Rebirth*,  (SPOILER) it is heavily implied that Wutai's Viceroy Sarruf, which is just the characters that make up his name in Japanese backwards, is actually him under a pseudonym.  This is similar to his role in *Before Crisis*  (SPOILER) as one of AVALANCHE's top financial backers, even using the organization to try an assassinate his father, an event referenced at the start of *Remake*.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): Darkstar utilizes Thunder magic which Rufus can use for certain [Combination Attacks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombinationAttack).

[Shotguns Are Just Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShotgunsAreJustBetter): An elaborate single-barrel shotgun, replacing the classic double-barreled [Sawed-Off Shotgun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SawedOffShotgun) from the original game. He mostly [uses it on Cloud at fairly close range,](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShortRangeShotgun) but he has several tricks to keep Cloud at a safe distance from him while still dealing out heavy damage.

[Smug Smiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSmiler): The arrogant heir to the Shinra Company is rarely seen without a self-confident smirk on his face. He's smiling for the entirety of his fight with Cloud and while he's willing to admit Cloud's a strong enemy, he never really acts as if he's in any real danger.

[Spared by the Adaptation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SparedByTheAdaptation): Dark Nation was originally killed like any other monster at the player's discretion, but once Darkstar's Hit Points are depleted, Rufus simply motions for it to leave the battle to him, and it flees.
[Throw Down the Bomblet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowDownTheBomblet): Rufus' *Think Fast* attack scatters several coins which he then shoots to trigger a chain of explosions.
[Too Many Belts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooManyBelts): His redesigned long coat now comes equipped with several belt straps below the waistline that serve no functional purpose whatsoever.

[True Sight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueSight): When the Whispers surround Shinra tower, he sees them while Tseng cannot, making Rufus the only person  (SPOILER)  along with Cissnei, as of *Rebirth*,  besides the main characters so far who can do so.
[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): Good ol' ["D"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffectionateNickname) is always at Rufus' side and ever-ready to assist and protect him in battle.
[Villain: Exit, Stage Left](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainExitStageLeft): Like in the original, he escapes his battle with Cloud via helicopter looking no worse for wear.
[Villain Holds the Leash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainHoldsTheLeash): Rufus is plenty strong on his own, but Darkstar is capable of both dishing out attacks and keeping his master healthy.
[Villain in a White Suit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainInAWhiteSuit): The despicable Rufus Shinra is in an impeccably tailored long white suit.

[Weak, but Skilled](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeakButSkilled): There are actual mooks in the game with more HP than Rufus, but his skill and ability to counter your attacks elevates him to a threat level befitting one of the endgame bosses.

[Weaksauce Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaksauceWeakness):
    - His phase with Darkstar has a surprising weakness to (SPOILER) Triple Slash. Seemingly it breaks his script so that he moves to defend Darkstar but takes a hit breaking their link putting the dog in pressure. Wail on it, build another bar and repeat. - His second phase's Assess entry alludes to the need to strike him with Braver while he's reloading in order to stagger him, but he deliberately makes sure to dash away from Cloud whenever he needs to reload to prevent Cloud from hitting him. (SPOILER) He doesn't resist the first use of Sleep or Stop on him though, and Braver striking him while he's frozen by one of those works just as well as if he was reloading.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): Surprisingly, *Sephiroth* of all people seems to consider him a dangerous adversary to his endgame.  (SPOILER) So much so that he puts in considerable effort into crafting a false-flag ruse with Wutai as a means of manipulating Rufus into war with them ,*solely* to prevent Rufus from becoming Cloud's ally. If Sephiroth still retains his memories from *[Advent Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/FinalFantasyVIIAdventChildren)*, it would certainly explain it as Rufus was Kadaj's biggest obstacle from completing the Reunion.  It definitely helps that Rufus is a much, *much* more capable and shrewd man than his father ever was.
[Adaptational Attractiveness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalAttractiveness): He is much slimmer, and his facial hair is much more trimmed compared to how he was in the original game.

[Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): He's constantly seen insulting and belittling his underlings while ignoring what they are telling him. When one protests too much, he gives an [Implied Death Threat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpliedDeathThreat) of sending the poor guy out to get slaughtered by Avalanche just to get rid of his second-guessing their plans.
[Beard of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeardOfEvil): His beard is much shorter and groomed than his original appearance but still just as evil.

[Colonel Kilgore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonelKilgore): Once a high-ranking soldier and now the commander of Shinra's private military, Heidegger is ruthless and cruel, advocating for the use of extreme force and caring nothing for any civilian casualties that may ensue.

[Corporate Warfare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorporateWarfare): He's the head of Shinra's Public Security division — that is to say, its military. He's also a cruel and ruthless man who advocates the use of extreme force in response to threats and sneers at those who balk at civilian casualties.

[Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive): He's one of the highest-ranking members of the Shinra corporation, and is just as corrupt as most of them, using horrible methods in order to keep Midgar's population in line.

[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): He is this in Part 2 as he is the only one out of the Shinra executives who does not make any personal engagements with Cloud's party; in contrast, Rufus, Scarlet, and Palmer fight them in boss fights, Hojo attempts to capture them in Costa del Sol with a robot, and Reeve travels alongside them as Cait Sith.

[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): He has been President's Shinra's right-hand man since the early days of the company. The president trusts him implicitly, which has made Public Security the most powerful division within Shinra.
[Evil Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilLaugh): Heidegger is prone to letting out his signature bellicose laugh **"GYAHAHA!"** whenever he's doing something particularly cruel.
[General Ripper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralRipper): He's practically the general of the Shinra forces, obsessed with crushing Wutai and the AVALANCHE resistance by any means necessary.

[Good Scars, Evil Scars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodScarsEvilScars): Has an ugly looking scar going through his left eye, indicating his wickedness, although it is slightly more subdued than most examples.

[The Heavy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy): For Part 1. President Shinra is the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) of the story, and Sephiroth is the [Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain), but most of the plot is caused by his attempts to expose Avalanche and smear their name.
[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): He's the head of "Public Security" despite being Shinra's main enforcer in maintaining its tyranny over the people.
[I Shall Taunt You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IShallTauntYou): During the Airbuster boss fight, his projected [Hologram](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hologram) will be constantly taunting the party.

[Lack of Empathy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LackOfEmpathy): He directly tells his subordinates that he doesn't care about civilian casualties in their operations against Avalanche, and when one starts to protest, Heidegger cuts him off and threatens to fire him and his squadron if they have a problem with his orders.

[Nerves of Steel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NervesOfSteel): We only briefly see him in a combat situation, but it's enough to demonstrate that despite all his other flaws, he's not short of physical courage. When Cloud whips the rear wheel of his motorbike into Heidegger's squad, he simply leans back slightly and grimaces as the rubber passes his face by inches while the soldiers around him stumble, panic and flee.
[Rugged Scar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RuggedScar): He used to be a commanding officer in the military and has a scar over his left eye that suggests he saw some combat.

[Stout Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoutStrength): Notable in the original game for tossing his underlings about like toys, he retains that quality in Remake but is now more of a traditional [Brute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBrute) rather than a [Fat Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatBastard).

[Taking the Bullet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingTheBullet): The  (SPOILER) shuriken,  in this case. When  (SPOILER) Yuffie tries to assassinate Rufus at his inauguration, Heidegger tackles him out of its trajectory and takes the gash in his place.
[Stroke the Beard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrokeTheBeard): His official character render has him stroking his beard in a pensive manner.

[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): Implied to have this in regards to President Shinra, as  (SPOILER) he continues referring to Rufus as Vice President after President Shinra’s death, and has a notable look of displeasure when Rufus affirms Tseng’s correction that he’s the President now .

[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): Despite coming into contact with the party several times, they never actually fight. The closest they get to crossing blades is at the end of the Shinra headquarters segment, which sees him leading a bunch of [mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mook) to surround the party, only to be swept aside by Cloud on a stolen motorcycle. Heidegger himself only comes out unscathed because Cloud just barely misses hitting him in the face with his wheels.

[Villainous Valor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousValor): Warhawk braggart though he is, he does seem to hold a genuine appreciation for his men, handing out their awards personally, [though it might be just because of how impressive they look in formation, which by proxy makes him look good as their boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope). Less ambiguously in *Rebirth*, he doesn't hesitate to  (SPOILER) put himself between Rufus and Yuffie, the new president's would-be assassin, sustaining a gory wound in the process .
[Virtue Is Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VirtueIsWeakness): As evidenced by the quote above, Heidegger believes showing mercy to an enemy is just giving said enemy a chance to attack again.

[Warhawk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Warhawk): When Avalanche's bomb disables the Sector 1 Mako Reactor, Heidegger [causes the reactor to completely self-destruct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FalseFlagOperation) and then tells the public that Avalanche is a Wutai-affiliated terrorist organization in order to stoke the fires of another war.

[Ace Pilot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AcePilot): She's a proficient [Mini-Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MiniMecha) pilot and even has her own [Ace Custom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AceCustom) mech in The Crimson Mare, which she pilots during her [Boss Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossBattle) in the  INTERmission  DLC.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): In the original, the fights we see are her fight with Tifa in a comical [slap battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatFight) and fighting Cloud and the others in the Proud Clod with Heidegger’s help. In here or specifically in Yuffie's DLC she became a [Boss Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossBattle) towards Yuffie and Sonon, albeit by piloting one of her machines without Heidegger’s help. Additionally, in *Rebirth* she’s capable of taking on *the entire party*  (SPOILER) minus a barely conscious Cloud  and keep them on the ropes until Tifa, Aerith and Yuffie are able to flank her.

[Alpha Bitch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlphaBitch): She's basically a high school queen bee if that high school queen bee became a scientist at a [MegaCorp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MegaCorp) and learned zero lessons in humility.

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain):
    - She acts as the main antagonist of Yuffie's DLC mission, being the Head of Department that is in charge of creating the Ultimate Materia she is trying to steal, and being a personal nemesis for Sonon (SPOILER) since one of her out of control mechs killed his sister . She even fights Yuffie and Sonon in a mech as a boss. - In *Rebirth* she is the main villain of the Gongaga chapter, attacking the reactor to capture the Weapon there and facing the party as they interfere. Despite the Whispers and Sephiroth being in the fray most of the plot happens as a consequence of her actions.

[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy): For both Barret and Yuffie:
    - In Barret's case, she's the one directly responsible for convincing all of Corel to make the transition to Mako, failing to keep the resultant Mako reactor maintained, and then pinning the blame for its critical failure on anti-Shinra insurgents, with her personally torching and murdering the town in order to cover it up. Barret lost everyone he loved except for his best friend's infant daughter, as well as his right arm. - Yuffie saw her actively try and kill both her and Sonon - and when she failed, she sent Deepground operatives and Nero on them, who succeeded in murdering Sonon in front of her very eyes. Yuffie makes it clear to Barret that when the crew gets their chance at Scarlet, she wants to be there to see the witch die.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): Compared to the original, she gets far more screentime throughout the remakes as the vicious baroness who provides constant challenge to the heroes' party.

[Awesome, but Impractical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeButImpractical): While she's a [Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius), her mech creations often favor extravagant designs that emphasize form over function.

[Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): Scarlet using one of the Shinra soldiers as a footstool while he crouches on all fours should be a clear indication that she's this. When an experiment to create Huge Materia goes awry, she casually walks out of the lab as the experiment goes critical and blows up with her scientists still inside.

[The Baroness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBaroness): She was already a nasty piece of work, but the Remake seems to be taking her character into absurd levels. She clearly enjoys wielding power over others, as seen in the [Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss) entry above, and she also has a *fascination* with the weapons she creates.
[Beauty Is Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeautyIsBad): As you can see, she's as beautiful as she is wicked.
[Brutal Honesty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrutalHonesty): She is a blunt woman who does not care if her remarks hurt or insult others.

[Camera Abuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CameraAbuse): In her introductory scene, she knocks over the cameraman that was with the man interviewing her for no discernible reason other than to appear hostile.

[Climax Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClimaxBoss): Scarlet and the Crimson Mare mark II serve as Rebirth's climax boss. She is engaged at a climactic point in Gongaga with the female members of the party  (SPOILER) while mako poisoning disables Cloud. Seeing Tifa in danger gives Cloud the motivation to try help but the poisoning makes him vulnerable to Sephiroth's manipulations, making him attack Tifa. This causes her to be eaten by a Weapon and learn vital parts of Sephiroth's plan and the vital role of the White Whispers and Weapons.

[Color Motif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorMotif): Red. She's called Scarlet, her iconic outfit is a [red dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyInRed) and many of her personally designed mechs and weaponry tend to also be colored red.

[Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive): She's one of the highest-ranking members of the Shinra corporation, and is just as corrupt as most of them, creating various weaponry and machinery which the company uses in warfare.
[Cultural Posturing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturalPosturing): She doesn't have a high opinion of Wutaians, and refers to Yuffie and Sonon as "savages" several times.

[Dark Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkActionGirl): She might not be much of a physical or magical fighter, but as long as you [give her a robot to pilot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AcePilot), she isn't afraid to get down and dirty, as Yuffie and Sonon can attest to.

[Dominance Through Furniture](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DominanceThroughFurniture): Introduced using one of her Mooks to rest her feet on. When she gets up, said Mook follows after her, ready to take up the role again wherever she goes.

[Dominatrix](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Dominatrix): Strongly implied, and *not* of the [Safe, Sane, and Consensual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SafeSaneAndConsensual) variety. There is a very sexual air about her, she uses a soldier as a footstool, and when they leave the room he crawls behind her like a dog.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): In addition to her sharing in her colleagues' revulsion towards Hojo's plans for Aerith, she tells Yuffie that mocking someone's physical appearance is beneath her. While one might dismiss her claim as a quip, it's worth noting that she has indeed never done so.

[Faux Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FauxAffablyEvil): Scarlet feigns politeness to Yuffie and Sonon throughout the former's DLC. At first she makes a legitimate effort while talking with them in the elevator, but after that she becomes more openly condescending. Additionally, while very much a [Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss) Scarlet tends to speak to her subordinates politely, even though their lives mean nothing to her.
[Femme Fatale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemmeFatale): She's a dangerous woman with a seductive demeanour who uses her sex appeal to keep her subordinates wrapped around her fingers.

[Fetishized Abuser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FetishizedAbuser): She's often abusing people in fetishizing manners (such as [using one of her subordinates as a foot stool](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DominanceThroughFurniture)) but it's played as [fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Fanservice), and at least one of her subordinates actually seems to *like* the treatment.

[Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius): Scarlet is the Head of Weapons Development at Shinra and in charge of designing Shinra's various mechs and robots, and also performs experiments on materia. And it's clear she's no mere figurehead and designed quite a lot of them herself.

[General Ripper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralRipper): Doubling as a *horrific* [Front Line General](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FrontLineGeneral), but when the infantry is burning Barrett's village, she's *'personally* leading the attack from the front, and she even grabs a rifle from a Shinra grunt and begins participating herself, all [with a sadistic smile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy).
[High-Heel Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighHeelPower): She wears high heels and is a dominating woman who enjoys putting her subordinates in submissive positions.

[I'm Standing Right Here](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImStandingRightHere): When she first meets Yuffie in the elevator, she immediately starts insulting Wutai and even asks her for a comment. It's pretty clear she figured out who she was at first glance and was having fun before getting out of harm's way.

[Just Between You and Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustBetweenYouAndMe):  (SPOILER) Scarlet gleefully tells Yuffie about Shinra's plan to drop the Sector 7 plate on the slums and blame it on Avalanche and Wutai. Justified since Yuffie wouldn't have been able to do anything about it by that point, and given the anti-Wutai sentiment in Midgar nobody would believe her. Moreover, Yuffie doesn't seem to fully understand what she's talking about.

tropeName: Kicking Ass in All Her Finery
tropeNotes: [Kicking Ass in All Her Finery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickingAssInAllHerFinery): In the  INTERmission  DLC, she pilots The Crimson Mare in her [Boss Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossBattle) while still wearing her fancy dress.

[Lack of Empathy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LackOfEmpathy): She's clearly unbothered by the casualties of the Sector 7 plate drop and acts dismissive about Reeve's plans to rebuild the destroyed sections of Midgard during the directors' meeting.
[Lady in Red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyInRed): Dresses in a red dress, which also shows off her cleavage.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): "Scarlet's Theme", which plays during her introductory scene in the Shinra Building. Unlike most Leitmotif in the game, hers actually have lyrics.

[Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist): Scarlet can't hold a candle to Hojo in this regard (and it's unlikely anyone on the Planet could), but Yuffie's DLC shows her to be obsessed with developing and improving weaponry. In fact, she views her weapons similarly to how Hojo views his specimens — though to a far saner degree.

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): She is a [Head-Turning Beauty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadTurningBeauty) with a [Buxom Beauty Standard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuxomBeautyStandard) figure who wears an [opulent red satin dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyInRed) that is [slit on the side](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SexySlitDress), [cut low on that back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SexyBacklessOutfit) and has a [plunging neckline](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NavelDeepNeckline) that prominently displays her cleavage and makes it obvious she's [not wearing a bra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VaporWear). She also tends to act like a [Dominatrix](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Dominatrix) and is portrayed as a [Fetishized Abuser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FetishizedAbuser) while mistreating her own men.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag):
    - In *Crisis Core*, an NPC in the Shinra Building will mention that he wouldn't mind being stepped on by Scarlet's high heels. In this game, she's seen using a man as a footstool. - During the INTERmission DLC she pilots a mech to battle Yuffie and Sonon that looks suspiciously like Magitek Armor from *Final Fantasy VI*. The fact that Scarlet wears a red dress and has blonde hair tied up in a ponytail, and rides the Crimson Mare in a [Slouch of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlouchOfVillainy), completes the image of a sinister mirror of Terra Branford.
[Navel-Deep Neckline](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NavelDeepNeckline): Her dress has a plunging neckline that prominently displays her cleavage.

[Nerves of Steel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NervesOfSteel): Even after  (SPOILER) she's taken hostage by Yuffie and Sonon, with the latter having every reason to want her dead, she doesn't bat an eyelash. Although she'd already called Deepground for backup, they still could've easily killed her .

[Noblewoman's Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoblewomansLaugh): Her [Evil Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilLaugh) is this, as per the original game. She gives an impressive one  (SPOILER) after the Crimson Mare is destroyed .
[Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyLook): She looks like she's in her early to mid-thirties, but she is actually forty years old.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): A very minor example, but she's sincere when she compliments Yuffie's looks. The one thing that she refuses to do is attack people on their appearance, after all.

[Politically Incorrect Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoliticallyIncorrectVillain): On top of her [other](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss) [wonderful](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LackOfEmpathy) [traits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FetishizedAbuser) Scarlet makes several degrading remarks about Wutians, including calling them monkeys, and insinuating that they are both foolish and weak.
[Proud Beauty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudBeauty): The lyrics of her [Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif) make it clear she greatly values her natural beauty.

[Sadist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Sadist): She's more than happy to suggest to Hojo that [torturing Aerith](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColdBloodedTorture) is not a problem, yet when he proposes letting members of SOLDIER turn her into a [Breeding Slave](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreedingSlave) in the name of "science", *that* [proves a bridge too far even for her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards).
[Red Is Violent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedIsViolent): Her red [Color Motif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorMotif) hints are her sadistic tendencies.
[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): She's fought multiple times while piloting versions of her Crimson Mare mecha.
[Rich Bitch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RichBitch): She's a smug, cruel, and condescending bitch who is incredibly rich and tends to look down on other people.

[Robot Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RobotMaster): Her department is in charge of creating most of the robot enemies that Shinra uses, and she has [designed quite a few of them herself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius).

[Rogues' Gallery Transplant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoguesGalleryTransplant): In the original game Scarlet is technically Barret's main nemesis (along with Heidegger, to an extent), but the remake pits her against Yuffie and gives the latter a personal reason to hate her too. However, Scarlet retains her role in Barret's backstory.
[Sexy Backless Outfit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SexyBacklessOutfit): Her red dress leaves most of her back exposed.

[Sexy Slit Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SexySlitDress): Her opulent dress has slits on the side of her legs. Although it *also* has a practical reason, as she hides a panic button on her leg, and the slits make it easy to reach.

[Skewed Priorities](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkewedPriorities):  (SPOILER) After being defeated by Yuffie and Sonon, Scarlet dismounts her mech and begins analyzing its weaknesses so she can improve it in the future, as if her foes weren't even there. Yuffie calls her out on this.
[Smug Smiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSmiler): She's often giving smug smiles and almost always has an expression of confidence or condescension.
[Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmurfettePrinciple): The only female member on the Shinra board of directors.
[Statuesque Stunner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatuesqueStunner): She's a [Head-Turning Beauty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadTurningBeauty) that when in heels, she stands even taller than *Heidegger*.
[Stocking Filler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StockingFiller): Under her dress, she wears black thigh-high stay-up stocking.

[Terms of Endangerment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TermsOfEndangerment): During the  INTERmission  DLC, she clearly enjoys talking down to Yuffie and Sonon while using fake politeness and insincere compliments.

[Woman Of Wealth And Taste](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WomanOfWealthAndTaste): Her clothes look extravagant and lavish, and she's seen working while reclining in an opulent chair while forcing one of her subordinates to [serve as a footstool](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DominanceThroughFurniture).

[Women Are Wiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WomenAreWiser): While she still has her eccentricities, she seems to keep them in check much better than her male colleagues and is portrayed as more sensible and capable. She's more competent than [Heidegger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralFailure) and [Palmer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatBastard), saner than [Hojo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist), and less hamstrung at Shinra than [Reeve](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate).
[Would Hurt a Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldHurtAChild): Acknowledges that Yuffie — and Sonon, presumably — are teenagers and attempts to murder them personally.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): One of the Urban Planning division's primary missions is supplying the residents of Midgar with mako energy, which makes him complicit in a greater evil. However, it is clear that he is ultimately a good man who has the people's best interests at heart and is opposed to the immorality going on around him. Given the option, he would likely not even be opposed to letting the mako stay in the ground and going green.

[Beauty Equals Goodness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeautyEqualsGoodness): In sharp contrast to [Scarlet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeautyIsBad), Reeve is a handsome man with a good heart who finds himself working working with a lot scummier people.

[Benevolent Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BenevolentBoss): Shown in a scene with his assistant whilst writing the report on Sector 7's collapse. He is nothing but polite and cordial towards her, making him stand out in further contrast to [Heidegger and Scarlet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss). The feeling seems to be mutual, with Reeve's assistant showing noteworthy concern over his well-being while also warning him of [Saying Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SayingTooMuch).

[The Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeart): Almost explicitly so among the Shinra heads, what with the Urban Planning division's symbol on the company logo being a heart-shape and all. However, since this is the Shinra Company we're talking about, he finds himself being a sadly inefficient and overlooked example: The other directors find far more unity in their shared heartlessness than in his attempts to appeal to their non-existent better natures.

[Heel–Face Revolving Door](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceRevolvingDoor): In *Rebirth*, Reeve—through Cait Sith—joins Avalanche's party and makes no secret of the fact that he's spying on them for Shinra, though he lies that he's just an unimportant middle-management grunt. Nevertheless, he goes out of his way to  (SPOILER) sabotage Avalanche's wanted posters—his secretary noting he's in a good mood for the first time in a long while .  (SPOILER) [He's forced to double-cross them by stealing the key to the Temple of the Ancients](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForcedIntoEvil), which leaves him devastated when even Aerith condemns him for his betrayal, but makes it up to them by using Cait Sith to buy them time to escape the collapsing Temple .

[Honest Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonestCorporateExecutive): He does his best to improve the living standards of the general populace in Midgar, even extending this to the people living in the slums, and even attempts to play the part of an [Internal Reformist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InternalReformist) by pleading with President Shinra not to go through with decisions that could or would harm the people. This, unfortunately, makes him the only corporate executive on Shinra's board of directors who plays into this trope rather than [the other one](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive).

[Only Sane Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneMan): Reeve's arguably the *only* Shinra executive who takes his job seriously, as his interests aren't seriously warped by a lust for power, greed, or far worse.  (SPOILER)  He is also the only executive who questions the plan to build Neo-Midgar in the Promised Land, pointing out the farfetched nature of building a new city in a place that might not even exist.
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): Unlike all of the Shinra higher ups, Reeve stands out for actually being a decent guy.

[Refuge in Audacity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RefugeInAudacity): Reeve hacks into the Shinra network  (SPOILER)  in order to help the main party by doctoring their wanted posters to resemble strangers in order to keep their identities secret.  He does all this *from his work computer in his office* while cheerily humming a tune, with his assistant noting that he's in a good mood; even Tseng who shows up later, doesn't clock his behavior as odd.

[Token Good Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate): He just wants what's best for Midgar, best seen when he desperately tries to convince the President not to go through with the plan to destroy Sector 7.  (SPOILER) This is best seen in contrasting his reaction to the fall of the Sector 7 Plate with President Shinra - while Shinra smiles from his office window, watching the plate and slums below burst into flames; Reeve (through the remote controlled [Cait Sith](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EarlyBirdCameo)) falls to his knees and pounds the ground, having rushed to the scene too late to stop it . This is ultimately deconstructed, as being the only good person on a board of the most morally bankrupt people in the world results in Reeve's department being perpetually neglected and ignored. As such, Midgar is falling apart in places and the slums are half-buried in literal mountains of junk and scrap. Since he doesn't agree with Shinra's decisions, Reeve himself has about as much power as Midgar's figurehead mayor despite being in an executive position, and he and his entire division are kept as a showpiece to convince the populace that Shinra cares about the city when they obviously don't.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): In the original, he was more of a [Zero-Effort Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZeroEffortBoss). In *Rebirth*, he pilots an Anuran Suppressor to get an edge, and despite making an ass of himself, he does puts up much more of a fight.

[Adaptational Intelligence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalIntelligence): A marginal example. He's still mostly presented as an inept buffoon, but compared to the outright [Manchild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManChild) who was prone to ridiculous childish antics from the 1997 game, this version of Palmer comes across as slightly less embarrassing. He at least tries to act the part of a man hailing from upper-class society (key word being "try").

[Adaptational Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalJerkass): In the original game he was a bit of a [Manchild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Manchild), and despite his callous indifference to his company's atrocities, he personally wasn't much worse than [Reeve](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate). This time around, however, he's more of an [Upper-Class Twit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpperClassTwit), giving him a higher degree of competence that makes it clear he has no problem living a comfortable life on Shinra's dime. Most notably, he [giggles childishly](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldMan) when Hojo suggests using psychological torture on Aerith, though [looks vaguely disgusted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards) when Hojo clarifies he plans to have  SOLDIERs  [forcibly impregnate her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RapeIsASpecialKindOfEvil).

[Animal Motif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotif): Palmer is frequently associated with frogs and amphibians, his facial features are reminiscent of a frog and he pilots an amphibious mech in *Rebirth*. As frogs are well known for moving from environment to environment, fitting for the head of Space and Aeronautics Division. They are also not known for thriving in toxic environments, as Shinra is no longer looking into space flight his division has languished for years and he is the company [Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey).

[Beware the Silly Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheSillyOnes): He is a bumbling, childish, twit whose antics border on comic relief, to the point he is essentially a [Harmless Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HarmlessVillain). In *Rebirth*, a string of humiliation he experienced - ranging from being in charge of handing [Wanted Posters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WantedPoster) (a menial work), his booking at the Gold Saucer hotel cancelled  (SPOILER) courtesy of Cait Sith , his security forces being slaughtered  (SPOILER) at Dyne's hands ,  (SPOILER) AND losing the Chocobo race track by having his betted racer be put on last place  - caused him to finally snap at the lack of respect he receives as one of the Heads of Department, and vows to make Cloud and co pay by attempting to crush them with his Anuran Suppressor.

[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): If something can happen to humiliate Palmer, it *will* happen. During his boss fight in *Rebirth*, even the Anuran Suppressor takes time to bully him by bashing its hatch shut while he's leaning out of it to taunt Avalanche.
[Cassandra Truth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CassandraTruth): He tries to warn the other executives that  (SPOILER) Sephiroth is back , but no-one except Hojo believes him.
[Dirty Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldMan): He's a disgustingly fat senior citizen, and is first seen chasing a Honeygirl around a private room in the Honeybee Inn.

[Fat Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatBastard): He's a rotund executive of an evil [MegaCorp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MegaCorp) who is formally introduced complaining to himself about a lack of butter and that without it his tea is nothing more than "boiled pond water".
[Gonk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Gonk): His facial features bring more to mind a clown mask than an average human face. He looks like an evil [Mayor Meanswell.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Series/LazyTown)

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): He almost has a heart attack when  (SPOILER) Sephiroth nonchalantly walks past him , but he's *almost* [more upset about spilling his tea](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkewedPriorities).

tropeName: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything
tropeNotes: [The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePiratesWhoDontDoAnything): As Palmer's museum hologram admits, the Space and Aeronautics Division of Shinra isn't really doing anything, since they have plenty of mako on Earth and don't see any need for space exploration. What he does for Shinra in the meantime is unclear.

[Upper-Class Twit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpperClassTwit): This version of Palmer has shades of this, dressing in a neat suit and speaking in a cultured voice, while at the same time being obsessed with food and lacking in intelligence.

[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown): He goes through being humiliated multiple times all throughout *Remake* and in the early chapters of *Rebirth*, but after he goes through the [Humiliation Conga](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumiliationConga) that is his *entire* time at the Gold Saucer from the moment he was ordered to go there, he *finally* snaps and tries to handle things himself. Personally confronting the party in a *war machine*, and starting his boss fight by going off on a *massive* screeching rant about everything he's been through up to that point.
QUOTE **Palmer:** Hand these posters out, Palmer. Booking's *cancelled*, Palmer.  (SPOILER)  Security's been *slaughtered, Palmer!* *[Your chocobo came](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArsonMurderAndJaywalking)* ***[LAST,](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArsonMurderAndJaywalking)*** ***PALMER!!***  *I've HAD IT!* And *YOU'RE* going to *PAY!* *[I'm a DIRECTOR! And you will show me some](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeWheresMyRespect)* ***[RESPECT!!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeWheresMyRespect)***
[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): He's very friendly and polite, but  (SPOILER) he's working with Hollander and Genesis.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): He's  (SPOILER) aiding Hollander and Genesis , but his motivations are much more sympathetic, and he  (SPOILER) eventually realizes the error of his ways and aids Zack.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): Post-time skip.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): Inasmuch as he can be considering the [Grey-and-Gray Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreyAndGrayMorality) of Shinra, but he is the director of SOLDIER and is known and respected among the company's military branch for being a good leader.

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): Realizing that he's  (SPOILER) the bastard son of President Shinra, effectively [abandoned](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalAbandonment) by his father he never knew, and that said father was an absolute *monster* in charge of the company  cements Lazard's actions for the rest of the story  (SPOILER) in supporting Genesis and Hollander to rebel against Shinra, albeit for his own agenda.
[First-Name Basis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FirstNameBasis): His subordinates refer to him as *Director Lazard* and his last name is largely ignored.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil):
    - To Hollander. (SPOILER) They both have been snubbed by Shinra and are using Genesis for revenge, but Lazard undergoes a [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) to help Zack while Hollander continues to aid Genesis. And while Hollander becomes a Genesis Copy, Lazard becomes an Angeal Copy. - Also one to (SPOILER) Rufus Shinra once you find out his full backstory. (SPOILER) While Rufus was born into his power and position, Lazard had to work his way up from the slums, and is a much better person than Rufus.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): He is mortally wounded protecting  (SPOILER) Cloud from Shinra forces while Zack is fighting Genesis beneath Banora.

[Humanoid Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination): He eventually becomes  (SPOILER) an Angeal Copy. By the time he finds Zack at the end of the game, he's fully taken on Angeal's face and hairstyle, save for his hair going white due to his degradation.
[Informed Attribute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAttribute): He's said to have not forgotten his roots and has sympathy for others living in the slums, but it doesn't come into play much.

[Luke, I Am Your Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LukeIAmYourFather): He is  (SPOILER) President Shinra's  illegitimate son with a slum woman. This also makes him  (SPOILER) Rufus's older brother and thus rightful heir to the company if his lineage were to be revealed. His discovery of this is why he helps Hollander and Genesis wage war on the company.
[The Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan): He's the one  (SPOILER) funding Hollander and Genesis.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): "Deusericus" is Latin for "silken god", a potential alternate reading of the kanji for "Shinra".

tropeName: The Mind Is a Plaything of the Body
tropeNotes: [The Mind Is a Plaything of the Body](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMindIsAPlaythingOfTheBody):  (SPOILER) As an Angeal Copy , he wishes to help Zack stop Genesis and save the world. Zack speculates that it's  (SPOILER) Angeal's cells  influencing his mind.
