[Moral Myopia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralMyopia): Nero holds Weiss dearly and names Deepground as their playground, but he has no qualms about slaughtering people, whether they are enemies or allies.  (SPOILER) Nevertheless, his treatment of Sonon after having killed him and watched his memories involving Melphie might imply a twisted level of respect and understanding, probably due to the sibling angle.

[Pay Evil unto Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PayEvilUntoEvil): He kills the scientists that monitored him during his battle. However, since these scientists were completely willing to let him slaughter Yuffie and Sonon, no one will feel sorry for them.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog):
    - In a twisted way. (SPOILER) When he kills Sonon, seeing his memories involving Melphie, which probably reminds him of his own love for his brother, rather than instantly killing or making him suffer as much as the other DG soldiers and scientists he killed, Nero instead lets him experience his memories with his sister first to make peace with his fate and at least find solace that he'll see her soon before finally killing him. Notably, he stops his sadistic laughing and remains silent through the entire ordeal, as if to show his respect and not distract Sonon from his memories. Furthermore, he treats Sonon's body with utmost care as he leaves, taking the corpse rather than absorbing it outright. Compared to what he usually does to others with his powers, this act is quite merciful . - Furthermore, (SPOILER) after fatally injuring Sonon, he does not go after Yuffie while he definitely could have teleported and kill her too. While it could be pragmatic, it is also possible that he did this because he respected Sonon's willingness to sacrifice himself for someone who wasn't exactly his sister and just reminded him of her and decided to spare Yuffie's life at that moment. - Just like in *Dirge of Cerberus*, he is loving toward Weiss. That's probably his most humanizing trait.
[Power Limiter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerLimiter): His straitjacket limits his power to manipulate darkness and once they are removed his power will increase.

[Psychopathic Man Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychopathicManChild): Far more than in "Dirge of Cerberus". Even his older brother, who is referred as depraved and sadistic, looks even more reasonable near him.  (SPOILER) Even if it is just an embodiement of her trauma in her trial, Yuffie has a vision of him in *Rebirth*, playing with Sonon like a puppet in the same way a child would play with a newfound toy.

[Razor Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RazorWings): Nero's weapons are a set of wing-like blades that collapse on his back. The wings are equipped with hands to grab objects while his real hands are bound. In the third phase of the fight, he'll empower his wings with dark energy and turn them into Abyssal Wings, increasing the strength and range of his attacks, as well as gaining two new attacks. Crippling these wings will instantly stagger Nero.

[Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): The Red to Weiss' Blue. Nero is more emotional and more prone to kill scientists while Weiss is way calmer and more cool-headed and simply indulged in whatever experiment they have in store. It contrasts with *Dirge of Cerberus* where Nero was the Blue to Weiss' Red as he was way quieter and unemotional than Weiss was, even if he was still sadistic.
[Soft-Spoken Sadist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoftSpokenSadist): He rarely raises his voice above a cold, sinister whisper even as he's threatening his opponents.
[Teleport Spam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeleportSpam): In the third phase of the fight, he'll begin using Spatial Shift, teleporting around the room in an portal of darkness.
[Villain Respect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainRespect): Hinted at during his battle against Yuffie and Sonon.

[Yandere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Yandere): His [Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy) behavior, his addiction to pain and his comments about Weiss in the battle imply that Nero may be one toward his brother. Neverthless, this trait was much more obvious and pronounced in "Dirge of Cerberus''.

[Beyond the Impossible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeyondTheImpossible): He creates Summon Materia — something he notes that was thought to be impossible, enabling Cloud and co. to [summon legendary deities](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlympusMons) like Shiva, Fat Chocobo, Leviathan, and even BAHAMUT!
[Character Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterCatchphrase): "That's it! I've come up with a new materia!"
[Commonality Connection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CommonalityConnection): Finishing his quests reveals his lack of control over his life, which mirrors Cloud's own frustrations.

[Cyborg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cyborg): Beating the Hard Mode-exclusive [Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss) in the VR simulator reveals that  (SPOILER) Chadley is actually a cyborg made to assist Hojo with his research. Unlike most examples, he yearns for his independence and collects battle data from Cloud in hopes of undoing the [Restraining Bolt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RestrainingBolt) imposed on him. If Cloud completes all his assignments, Chadley is able to do so and leaves Shinra .

[Didn't Think This Through](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntThinkThisThrough): Chadley opens *Rebirth* with having created MAI, an [Exposition Fairy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExpositionFairy) that's essentially the Shinra Building's propaganda tour guide expanded into a full character, and then spends much of the game coming to realize he's created someone he finds extremely annoying.
[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): Talk to him while Cloud is wearing a dress and he's surprised at  (SPOILER) having an emotional response, hinting at his artificial nature.

[Hard Light](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HardLight): A protorelic sidequest in *Rebirth*  (SPOILER) implies the body that Cloud and company meet is really a hologram capable of physically interacting with the world. His physical body is still in Hojo's lab. It's also implied by how Chadley always contacts Cloud with a vr background, instead of an outdoor environment.
[High-Class Glass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighClassGlass): He has a high tech monocle on his left eye.

[King of Games](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KingOfGames):  (SPOILER) In the *Intergrade* DLC episode, he turns out to be the Grandmaster of the Fort Condor game. This extends to *Rebirth* where he is the Rank 3 challenger in the Queen's Blood Tournament

[Mission Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissionControl): In *Rebirth* he graduates to Cloud's mission control ally, guiding him in discovering "World Intel" as Cloud explores each region. He is a frequent source of dialogue when traversing the world and making note of its many discoveries, giving lore to the player about various places and monsters.
[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): He works for Shinra's R&D department, but supplies Cloud and Avalanche with materia he develops.

[Offscreen Teleportation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffscreenTeleportation): Chadley always manages to get from Sector to Sector ahead of Cloud and Avalanche.  (SPOILER) Justified in that he has a neural connection to Shinra's surveillance network and a cybernetic body that he's using to chase Cloud, which is why he knows way more about Cloud than he should when they first meet. As a side note, this is used as a bit of [Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing); Aerith's data is all encrypted to the point where he can't track her or even know she exists, which initially makes him surprised to see her. Anyone familiar with her true nature will immediately know why.
[Science Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScienceHero): *Rebirth* sees him using his newfound freedom to travel the globe reactivating old communications towers to further understand the Planet.

[Sibling Rivalry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SiblingRivalry): He tends to bicker with his "sister" and creation, MAI, over their shared role as Cloud's [Mission Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissionControl) in *Rebirth*.

tropeName: So What Do We Do Now?
tropeNotes: [So What Do We Do Now?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoWhatDoWeDoNow): In the conclusion to his arc after  (SPOILER) revealing he's a cyborg and that Cloud helped him be free after using him for combat data, Cloud asks what he's going to do with his new freedom. Chadley's not sure, but he's glad not knowing something for a change.

[Teen Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeenGenius): He is just a teenager, but he is able to develop new forms of materia — including Summon materia, something thought to be impossible — using combat data obtained by Cloud's team.

[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): The sidequest in *Rebirth* reveals that Chadley is not as free as he thinks -  (SPOILER) Hojo is able to access what Chadley sees and is in control of Chadley's real body, meaning Chadley is unwittingly allowing Hojo to keep track of Cloud's party through their interactions.

tropeName: What Is This Thing You Call "Love"?
tropeNotes: [What Is This Thing You Call "Love"?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatIsThisThingYouCallLove): For Cloud hilariously enough, as he can't tell that Cloud crossdressing isn't a beautiful woman  (SPOILER) and he's just learning what emotions even are.
[A.I.-cronym](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AICronym): She's an artificial intelligence who goes by MAI, which is an acronym for her function as a **M**onster **A**ssesment **I**nstrument.
[Distaff Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistaffCounterpart): Appearance-wise she's a female version of Chadley.

[Exposition Fairy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExpositionFairy): MAI is an AI that was created by Chadley to help guide the party in their travels by giving hints and exposition about the ecological features of the places they travel.
[Genki Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenkiGirl): She is overly peppy and eccentric to the point where even Chadley is annoyed with her.
[Mission Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissionControl): Shares this role Chadley by acting as an [Exposition Fairy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExpositionFairy) to Cloud in *Rebirth*.

[Sibling Rivalry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SiblingRivalry): Tends to sometimes bicker with her creator and "brother" over whose better at acting as Cloud's [Mission Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissionControl). A lot of their humor comes from MAI and Chadley trying one up each other over providing useful information to Cloud.
[Always Someone Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSomeoneBetter): Hojo is this to him.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): Despite being the man that had ultimately created Genesis and Angeal, no one is really sad to see him go once Zack finally puts him down, as he was too petty and twisted for either of his creations to actually *care* in any real way. Considering Hollander instigated Genesis' [Start of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StartOfDarkness) solely for the sake of his revenge rather than for healing Genesis out of altruism, it's not that surprising.
[Beard of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeardOfEvil): Has a full bushy beard with matching mustache and sideburns.

[Best Served Cold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BestServedCold): The official series timeline places the Jenova Project as occurring 20 years before *Crisis Core*. Hollander's been waiting a long time to get back at Hojo for outdoing him

[Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe): While *much* of the tragedy in *Crisis Core Reunion* is directly a result of his petty vendetta against Hojo, his schemes quickly get sidelined when Genesis begins acting outside of his scope and does his own thing. By the time of his last appearance, he is little more than a freak of nature barely held together from duct-taped self-experiments using G cells.
[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): Deadly Breath.

[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): He always flees from danger and is visibly intimidated by Shinra's forces. He only fights Zack near the end of the game because he's cornered, and  (SPOILER) is so degraded that he has no choice but to fight for the one hope he has of saving his own life.

[Evil Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGenius): Though outdone by Hojo in both regards, he's still a brilliant scientist and is absolutely devoid of morals. His one advantage is that he's relatively sane [compared to Hojo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist).

[Evil Is Not a Toy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsNotAToy): His attempts to make Genesis his [Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn) backfire when Genesis gets tired of his failure to produce a cure and attempts to kill him.  (SPOILER) He later does so again off-screen, forcing Hollander to inject himself with Genesis's cells to save his own life, and he experiences the same debilitating health as Genesis does for it.

[Evil Is Petty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsPetty): He convinces Genesis to rebel against Shinra and take a large part of SOLDIER with them, and has Genesis wage war on Shinra by promising him a cure for his genetic degradation. Why? To show up Hojo and SOLDIER and prove his specimens are superior.
[Evil Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep): Compared to Hojo's high-pitched voice, Hollander is deep and gravelly.

[Evil Versus Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilVersusEvil): His rivalry with Hojo can be considered this, as both mad scientists are ultimately unrepentant monsters whose plans cause mass death and destruction. Ultimately, his entire beef with [Shinra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilInc) can be considered this as well, with the caveat that innocent people get caught in the crossfire of his revenge scheme.
[For Science!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience): See [Evil Is Petty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsPetty). He particularly wants to prove *his* science is better than Hojo's.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): It's genuinely impressive that in a world where someone like Professor Hojo exists, someone else can still qualify for this, and yet *here we are*. Not only is he an absolutely grotesque human being who conducted just as many horrific human experiments as Hojo, *he performed them on his own family no less.* Both Gillian and Angeal suffered - and ultimately died - because he implanted Jenova's cells into them, and that's nothing to say of how he manipulated Genesis just to settle a petty grudge with Hojo. His one - and *only* one - redeeming trait is that he was the one who commissioned a blacksmith to forge the Buster Sword for Angeal when he became a SOLDIER, laying down the foundation for what will inevitably become a [Legendary Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegendaryWeapon).
[Humanoid Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination): He transforms into a more monstrous humanoid form thanks to  (SPOILER) the Genesis cells he's injected himself with.
[Hyperspace Arsenal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HyperspaceArsenal): His "Dimension Missile" cinematic attack has him pull a missile larger than he is out of his satchel and hurl it at Zack.

[I Am Your Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IAmYourFather): Attempted, but defied. Hollander tries to claim himself as Angeal's father in the cutscene shortly before Zack faces Angeal, but Angeal just spits in his face about it. Hollander *is* Angeal's biological parent, but Angeal considered his stepfather to be his real father.
[The Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan): He's the real force behind Genesis's army, and the one who convinced Genesis to go against Shinra.
[The Man Behind the Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMonsters): The Genesis Copies are his work, as are Genesis and Angeal.
[Mook Maker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MookMaker): Can spawn monsters to aid him in battle.
[Only One Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyOneName): As with Hojo, it's hard to even say if it's his first or last name.
[Poisonous Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoisonousPerson): Infects Zack with poison and other status ailments.
[Power Gives You Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerGivesYouWings): He sprouts a small black wing over his shoulder  (SPOILER) when he becomes a Genesis Copy.
[Trademark Favorite Food](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrademarkFavoriteFood): He's a fan of Banora White juice, even wearing a shirt depicting the logo under his lab coat.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Genesis's rebellion against Shinra starts the chain of events that, aside many other things, cause Sephiroth to reconsider his allegiance, and then Genesis appears in Nibelheim to give a Sephiroth a breaking speech that finally pushes him into [Start of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StartOfDarkness). Hollander is the one who pushed Genesis's own [Start of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StartOfDarkness) just to upstage Hojo, resulting in countless tragedies in *[Final Fantasy VII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII)* up to the world being in danger.

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): If you talk to him after the final Angel of the Slums related sidequest, he decides to quit his job and go independent. He also seems to have developed a much higher opinion of the Angel and wants to write a more flattering article on her as his first assignment.

[Intrepid Reporter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntrepidReporter): Damon is tasked with writing an exposé on the Angel of the Slums, and sets out to the Sector 5 slums in order to do so. The Angel rigs a trap thinking he'll be more interested in [Going for the Big Scoop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoingForTheBigScoop) than in his personal safety, but he instead hires Cloud to check out the Angel's lair for him.
[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): He gets excited quite easily and gets rather loud when doing so.

[Loving a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovingAShadow): In his final scene, he declares he has fallen in love with the Angel of the Slums and wants to help her, despite not even knowing what she looks like.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): He seems to be heavily based on the detective character that appeared in an older concept for the original *Final Fantasy VII*.

[Paparazzi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Paparazzi): Damon writes pro-Shinra drivel for a tabloid that everybody — even Aerith — hates, and is a recurring thorn in Mireille's side due to his current job being to frame the Angel of the Slums as a dangerous criminal mastermind.
[Propaganda Machine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PropagandaMachine): He works for a pro-Shinra tabloid.
[Putting on the Reich](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuttingOnTheReich): He wears a Shinra armband that looks eerily similar to the swastika armbands worn by Nazis.
[The Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRival): He can usually be found bickering with Mireille Dudley, a supporter of the Angel of the Slums  (SPOILER) who actually is said Angel .

[Ungrateful Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBastard): After Cloud and Aerith destroy a trap the Angel of the Slums set to have Damon put out of commission, he ends up getting distracted by another lead and stiffs Cloud on his payment. Mireille picks his pocket and gives Cloud what he's owed.

[Allegorical Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllegoricalCharacter): He represents the normal civilians who just happen to work for Shinra to make ends meet, and serves to challenge [Barret's view](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackAndWhiteInsanity) that everyone associated with the company is fundamentally evil.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): He was a minor  NPC  in *Remake* that had a couple of brief scenes, then in *Rebirth* is met several times in the first half of the party's journey, and he's the focus of a sidequest at the Gold Saucer.

[Badass Pacifist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassPacifist): When Barret tries to intimidate him, he responds by quoting the Shinra creed: "We will not submit to intimidation or violence! But work together for peace and prosperity! That is how civilized people change the world!" Sure, he is scared off almost immediately after doing it, but that's about as badass as you can expect a regular joe to be.

[Benevolent Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BenevolentBoss): He's shown to care for the employees working under him, who all seem to respect and appreciate him.  (SPOILER) At the end of *Rebirth*'s final sidequest, he returns to Shinra despite realizing he's unhappy working for them so he can protect his subordinates from Shinra politics and bureaucracy.
[Everyone Calls Him "Barkeep"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneCallsHimBarkeep): He's never given a name and is only know by the description of his job: Shinra Middle Manager.

[Good Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodParents): Learns to play Fort Condor against Yuffie, not to become good enough at the game to win, but to become good enough to lose on purpose convincingly so that he'll be able to play and lose against his daughter without upsetting her.
[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): He may not look it, but he is an expert Chocobo jockey and gamer.
[King of Games](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KingOfGames): In *Rebirth*, he manages to put up high scores on every game available to the player, and is one of the most challenging opponents in 3D Brawler.

tropeName: Look Ma, I Am on TV!
tropeNotes: [Look Ma, I Am on TV!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LookMaIAmOnTV): In *Rebirth*, when he is interviewed by a reporter, he excitedly uses the camera to greet his wife and daughter, and keeps trying to talk to them even when the reporter tries to leave.
[Middle-Management Mook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MiddleManagementMook): It's literally in his name.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): Relatively speaking. While in *Remake*, he is a willing and knowing bureaucrat in a fascist and oppressive corporation, he is regardless protective of his employees and stands up to Barret to denounce violence of any kind. Later in *Rebirth*, he finally becomes fed up with Shinra's atrocities and quits, though he eventually returns just to look out for his people and families. He's living proof that not everyone in Shinra is bad, and there *are* people inside worth saving.

[Punch-Clock Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunchClockVillain): He's just your average middle manager who believes that Shinra does what's best for the world. Though he instigates the second quarrel with Barret in Chapter 5 of *Remake*, he's not so much a jerk as he is an ordinary civilian brainwashed by Shinra's corporate propaganda and implicated into a big mess without knowing the full scope of it. When Tifa pushes him into the next car during the battle on the train he appears surprised that someone from Avalanche would try to save him, even though he's with Shinra, the supposed enemy. When Tifa tells him that she doesn't care about any of that, she just doesn't want him or anyone else to get killed, he hesitatingly accepts this and promises that he'll look after the other passengers.
[Sharp-Dressed Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SharpDressedMan): A nice suit and a red necktie for a man worthy of his Middle Manager name.

[Throw the Dog a Bone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowTheDogABone): In *Rebirth* he is given a rather well-deserved vacation after the insane events of *Remake* and while he's still a bit high-strung, he seems to be sincerely enjoying himself.  (SPOILER) He eventually masters all the attractions at the Gold Saucer to the point where he is proclaimed the Ultimate Party Animal.
[Mascot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mascot): He was designed to be a cartoon mascot for Shinra, as a loyal dog soldier whose antics and adventures serve as pro-Shinra propaganda.

[Ripple Effect Indicator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RippleEffectIndicator):  (SPOILER) Stamp appears as different breeds of dogs depending of the timeline, such as showing up as a terrier in the timeline where Zack lived at the end of *Remake*. Near the end of *Rebirth*, Zack's choices create even more branching timelines with Stamp as different dogs. The timeline that Cloud wakes up in with an Aerith that gives him her White Materia also has its own Stamp.

[Show Within a Show](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShowWithinAShow): Is considered a popular cartoon character [In-Universe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InUniverse), with several children knowing about him. Even Barret and Yuffie, despite their hatred of all things Shinra, adore Stamp, with Barret more upset that Shinra would turn an innocent character into a [Propaganda Piece](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PropagandaPiece).

[Abled in the Adaptation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbledInTheAdaptation): In the original, for the entirety of the game except its very end, Sephiroth was [Dead All Along](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadAllAlong), his lifeless body stuck in the Northern Crater, using Jenova fragments to act in his stead. Here, while he's seemingly still in that condition, his ability to manifest through the Sephiroth Clones has improved to the point where he can make them take on his appearance and at least a semblance of his abilities. In the climaxes of both *Remake* and *Rebirth*, he arranges conditions where he's fully able to fight on his own with seemingly no host at all.

[Absurdly Sharp Blade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbsurdlySharpBlade): He cuts an entire bridge with one swipe of his sword,  (SPOILER) and can casually one-shot the Whispers — which are noted to be resilient to physical attacks .

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass):
    - Even with his original incarnation being the [World's Strongest Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsStrongestMan), in this game Sephiroth steps it up a notch. He demonstrates powers on-par with his *Advent Children* appearance, able to fly, telekinetically move buildings, and manifest his single black wing. (SPOILER) Possibly subverted, as it is implied the Sephiroth fought at the end of the game may actually be the *Advent Children*-era Sephiroth who has travelled back in time. - In the original game when he was a [Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember) during Cloud's flashback of Nibelheim, Sephiroth's primary power came from his high level, mastered Materia, and top-tier equipment. In the same sequence as *Rebirth*, the different style of gameplay makes the power disparity between him and Cloud much more apparent even without taking those factors into account; Sephiroth moves and attacks very quickly, deals heavy damage, fires blast of dark energy to attack from range, his unique mechanic lets him use different finishers depending on his combo, and his ATB abilities are also very strong. He easily outclasses Cloud and everyone else the player has taken control of before.

[Adaptational Early Appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalEarlyAppearance): *Remake* takes place entirely in Midgar, and Sephiroth was only mentioned during that portion of the original game. Here he appears as early as Chapter 2 (even if he's just a hallucination that Cloud suffers from), but makes a full, proper appearance in the final two chapters  (SPOILER) and is even the [final obstacle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) keeping the party from escaping Midgar, where in the original story he wasn't fought until the very end . *Rebirth* has him turn into his  (SPOILER) Sephiroth Reborn form for the final boss fight in that game, even through Bizarro Sephiroth (it's name in the original game) is not fought until the very end of the original game as the penultimate final boss .

[Adaptational Intelligence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalIntelligence): While Sephiroth in the original game was established to be [The Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAce) once upon a time, this was before his [Sanity Slippage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SanitySlippage) turned into something just one step above a [Generic Doomsday Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenericDoomsdayVillain). *Remake* makes him a far more active threat, and he is markedly better at playing mind games with Cloud and knows exactly which buttons to push — he sows paranoia about Jenova's shapeshifting mimicry, the inconsistencies in his memories, his lack of visible response to emotional events, and more, in the name of worsening Cloud's crisis of identity and drive a wedge between him and his allies.  (SPOILER) He also has a plan in place more complex and far-reaching than in the original game, intending to become a [Multiversal Conqueror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiversalConqueror), and as part of this tricks Cloud and his allies into killing the Arbiters of Fate to damage the timeline and potentially avert his future defeat.

[Adaptational Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalJerkass): Despite his more pronounced affability to Cloud in this version, Sephiroth does something in the remake that he didn't originally: he personally murdered Cloud's mother and uses it to torment him, telling him about how she begged him to spare her son and how he killed her with his own blade. He even takes it a step further and *recites her dying [Last Words](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastWords)* just to twist the knife more. In the original, she was another casualty of his burning of Nibelheim, and her death wasn't brought up again. He also mocks Cloud every time he fails to reinforce Cloud's frustration at the world over having no control over the direction of his own life to motivate Cloud into accomplishing his goals.

[Adaptation Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationNameChange):  (SPOILER)  The form he takes in the final boss fight of *Rebirth* is known as Sephiroth Reborn, it was known as Bizarro Sephiroth in the original game .

[Adaptational Personality Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalPersonalityChange): Played with. When he appears he tends to be focused on mocking and tormenting Cloud, which is accurate to his characterization in *Advent Children* (as well as spin-offs like *Kingdom Hearts* and *Dissidia*), but isn't much like his original *Final Fantasy VII* incarnation, where he was focused on other goals and didn't pay Cloud any notice unless he was in a position to be a complication in Sephiroth's plans. He still has shades of his original *VII* personality, but they're downplayed in favor of his rivalry with Cloud. Somewhat justified by the game being ambiguous on when Sephiroth is actually appearing to Cloud, and when Cloud's psychological problems are causing him to hallucinate Sephiroth; it could be that the times Sephiroth is more openly contemptuous of Cloud are when it's just in his head.  (SPOILER) Even more justified by the ending, where it is revealed that Sephiroth seems to have a very different plan from the original game, and Cloud is a part of them.

[Adaptational Wimp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalWimp): Make no mistake, Sephiroth is still incredibly dangerous and powerful in this continuity, but he's not the borderline [Physical God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhysicalGod) he was portrayed as in the original game, and he can find himself overwhelmed in a fight if taken by surprise or fighting multiple skilled opponents.

[All Your Powers Combined](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllYourPowersCombined):  (SPOILER) Does this with himself in his final boss fight, which combines aspects of his abilities from throughout his history. His moveset includes tier 3 magic, inspired by when he was a temporary party member in *VII*; he has Shadowflare and Heartless Angel from his Safer Sephiroth transformation; he has Octaslash from *Crisis Core*; he can manifest his single black wing first seen in *Advent Children*; he has attacks from the *Dissidia* games, with Scintilla and Hell's Gate coming from the original PSP games while Telluric Fury, Aeolian Onslaught, and Zanshin come from *Dissidia NT*; and he has several new attacks associated with darkness and can summon a dark aura around himself similar to his *Kingdom Hearts* appearances. It really emphasizes how dangerous Sephiroth is in *Remake* that he can do pretty much everything players have ever seen from him before and more, and even that still isn't the full extent of his power.

[Ambiguously Bi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBi): His interactions with Cloud are filled with homoerotic subtext, often creepy and played for horror. Some of his quotes include "I am your everything", "Don't deny me, embrace me", and "I will not end, nor will I have you end". He tends to get very close to Cloud and touch him a lot while delivering cryptic messages.

[Ambiguous Situation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousSituation):
    - Cloud is tormented by flashbacks and visions of him throughout the game, but it's sometimes ambiguous when Sephiroth is actually appearing to him and when Cloud is just hallucinating. The game's *Ultimania* guide specifies that there are four forms of Sephiroth in the game; the one that appears to Cloud in visions, the one in Cloud's flashbacks, the one manifested through the black-cloaked men, and the one that (SPOILER) is fought at the end of the game . The guide doesn't specify exactly what the nature of the fourth Sephiroth is and leaves his existence as a question mark. - In an instance only in the Japanese voice-over, when Sephiroth appears (SPOILER) at the End of the World , he uses the personal pronoun of *ore* 俺 as heard in *[Crisis Core](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/CrisisCore)*, instead of the more formal *watashi* 私 he uses in all his other appearances after his turn to villainy. Given the past consistency in his pronouns this is certainly a deliberate creative choice and not just a writer's oversight, but it's unclear what it could mean. (SPOILER) Cloud could possibly be talking to an entirely different Sephiroth, one from the *Crisis Core* era, or it could mean that Sephiroth in the present (or the future) has had a shift in his personality and motivations. - During a protorelic sidequest, Sephiroth (SPOILER) briefly meets Gilgamesh and is taken aback by seeing him and senses that he is a lost soul. It is unsaid if he actually recognizes him and if he does what that means for what Sephiroth actually is at the moment.

[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy):
    - The man who murdered Cloud and Tifa's parents and razed their home to the ground is naturally their most hated enemy just like in the original continuity. Sephiroth, however, does not display his trademark disdain for Cloud like in previous appearances. If anything, he's almost *warm* toward Cloud compared to how he's usually depicted complete with a decent amount of [Homoerotic Subtext](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HomoeroticSubtext). However, said subtext is play for horror, and he still makes derisive and cruel comments toward Cloud tormenting him for his failure to stop the Sector 7 plate from falling. He also vaguely alludes to his future goals in a sinister undertone, strongly hinting he is [hiding the true depth of his sadism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoftSpokenSadist) until it's time to reveal it. (SPOILER) Spoiler alert: He does. - As of the climax of *Rebirth,* (SPOILER) this trope extends as well to Aerith, who he seemingly killed, only for some form of her to live on to directly oppose his plans as a [Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood) representative of the Planet and Cetran legacy against his plan with Meteor and Jenova.

[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): Do not let his stoic, calm demeanor fool you. Sephiroth is a murderously unhinged [Omnicidal Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnicidalManiac) who plans to destroy all of life and recreate it in his own image. This part of him is especially pronounced during the Nibelheim incident where he set fire to the entire town and murdered many townsfolk in his path.

[Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): In a manner of speaking, the Sephiroth Clones are his followers who act on his will. However, Sephiroth only views them as disposable pawns. He allows many of them die while carrying out his orders in situations where he could have easily saved them  (SPOILER)  via [Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession) , but chooses not to.

[The Bad Guy Wins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBadGuyWins):  (SPOILER) In *Remake*, Sephiroth convinces the party that the Arbiters of Fate must be stopped via context-less visions of the future that will happen if they "fail to stop them", thus freeing destiny up to be changed - [just as Sephiroth intended](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero). Also, the fight against Cloud during the game's finale ends with Sephiroth easily defeating Cloud. This means Sephiroth walked away at the end of *Remake* with the win, having gotten everything he wanted and defeating the heroes. The only reason that *Remake* has a [Bittersweet Ending](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BittersweetEnding) instead of a [Downer Ending](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownerEnding) is because the good guys still have a chance to stop Sephiroth from enacting the rest of his plan.

tropeName: Bad Guys Do the Dirty Work
tropeNotes: [Bad Guys Do the Dirty Work](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadGuysDoTheDirtyWork): His murder of President Shinra, one of the major antagonists of *Remake.* Though everyone wanted Shinra to face justice for his crimes rather than outright be killed, Sephiroth does remove a major enemy of the party.

[Battle Aura](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleAura):  (SPOILER) Has an intimidating aura of purple energy when he powers up by absorbing Meteor. If anything it is more intimidating that he dismisses it casually, showing that all that power means little to him.

[Beneath the Mask](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeneathTheMask): Sephiroth manages to go all of *Remake* appearing [Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil), keeping his new motives ambiguous and treating Cloud in a manner that sends mixed messages about whether he wants revenge or wants Cloud to rule at his side. In *Rebirth*, this affable mask starts to slip, as he dials up his gaslighting in ways that are increasingly cruel and sometimes even petty, while Cloud under his control becomes an unabashed sadist. At the end of the game,  (SPOILER) when Cloud correctly points out that the Planet isn't rejoicing at having all of the timelines crammed together into one, it's *screaming in agony*, the mask fully comes off and Sephiroth spends the rest of the game engaging in cold-blooded torture out of anger at being told he's wrong, to such a degree that it alters his fighting style to be about inflicting as much pain as possible rather than actually winning the fight.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): Like the original game, he is the main antagonist of the remake though he doesn’t fully become this until the end of part 1.
[Big Bad Ensemble](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadEnsemble): He, alongside the Shinra Electric Power Company, both share the main villain position at the end of part 1.

[Blade Spam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BladeSpam):  (SPOILER) His Octaslash skill has him unleash a flurry of eight slashes from his sword. Some of his regular sword strikes also show multiple slash lines, similar to his moveset in *Dissidia*.

[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): Sephiroth's weapon-of-choice is the Masamune, a *nodachi* as long as he is tall. It's capable of effortlessly slicing through almost any material, and he can swing it with one hand fast enough to parry a slash from Cloud's Buster Sword.

[Canon Character All Along](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonCharacterAllAlong): Bizarrely enough,  (SPOILER) it's implied this is the exact same Sephiroth from the original game who not only knows what's going to happen, but seems to have devised a new means of attaining his goal and preventing Avalanche from defeating him. His reaction to Gilgamesh also insinuates he's the same version from all of the other spinoffs.

[Card-Carrying Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CardCarryingVillain): Compared to his [Godhood Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodhoodSeeker) mindset in the original game where he couldn't give less of a damn for anything but Jenova, Sephiroth *knows* how much Cloud hates him and willingly plays the role of an antagonist to the ex-SOLDIER while openly demonstrating just how immoral he could be if he feels like it. The prime example: the first thing Sephiroth does on screen is go into detail to Cloud on how good it felt to slice up Cloud's mother while Cloud watched.
[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow):  (SPOILER) His Shadow Flare attack has him conjure explosive orbs of darkness.

[Casting Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingGag): His previous long-term voice actor ([George Newbern](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/GeorgeNewbern)) was best known for voicing [Superman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/WesternAnimation/JusticeLeague). Sephiroth's new actor? [Tyler Hoechlin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/TylerHoechlin) is also known for his recent work in live-action...as [Superman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Series/Arrowverse). Tyler also played Martin Brewer in the early 2000s show *[7th Heaven](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Series/SeventhHeaven)*.

[Child Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildSoldier): In *[Final Fantasy VII: Ever Crisis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVIIEverCrisis)* a 15-year-old Sephiroth was deployed for the first time and saved Glenn Lodbrok, Lucia Lin, and Matt Winsord from being overwhelmed by Rhadorian soldiers, delivering an effortless [Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle) to the enemy troops. Following this, he took part in the broader Wutai War, becoming renowned as a legendary war-hero.

[Colony Drop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonyDrop): While inside the Shinra virtual reality presentation, Avalanche is shown a vision of Meteor destroying Midgar,  (SPOILER) and at the start of the final boss fight Sephiroth *absorbs* Meteor to power himself up. Also during the final battle's last phase, he'll use his Divine Proclamation skill, summoning a meteor and beginning a nine second countdown. If the party doesn't defeat him before the countdown ends, the meteor will drop on the party for a [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) .

[The Comically Serious](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComicallySerious): When paired up with the [endlessly energetic Zack Fair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Keet), though he takes his chipperness all in stride.

[Counter-Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CounterAttack):  (SPOILER) His Scintilla skill has him drop into a defensive stance and retaliate with a flurry of slashes if struck, similar to Cloud's Counterstance.

[Cryptic Conversation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrypticConversation): At the end of the first game, he leaves Cloud with confusing words which never go explained in-game  (SPOILER) after their final duel at the End of the World .
QUOTE **Sephiroth:** Seven seconds till the end. Time enough for you. Perhaps. [But what will you do with it? Let's see](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsUpToYou).

[Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle): His scuffles with Cloud at the end of *Remake* has him deliver this: Their first one-on-one duel has Sephiroth casually mocking Cloud the entire time and soon knocking him down. Even after having been seemingly beaten by him and the entire party, when they get to duel one last time, Sephiroth easily toys with him, countering all of his blows with Cloud hardly even making him move at all from his spot; and when he has enough, he instantly pushes Cloud back and disarms him. Notably, this is the only time that any work has Sephiroth ending the fight unquestionably victorious.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): While usually serious, he has his moments. Even after he goes insane, he retains a rather twisted sense of dull humor.
QUOTE **Tifa**: Man, I wish I could go on trips all over the world like you guys...

QUOTE **Sephiroth:** *([Beat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Beat))* "Trips?" I think you mean "*business* trips" - which are no fun at all!

QUOTE *[...]*

QUOTE **Cloud**: You're not real...you're...dead.<br data-format="\\"/>**Sephiroth**: *[in the smuggest, faux-surprised voice]* I am?

[Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): His Hell's Gate attack has him leaping into the air and stabbing the ground with his sword, creating large shockwaves in six directions.  (SPOILER) In the final boss fight of *Rebirth*, he replaces the shockwaves with an explosion of Whispers.

[Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession): It's revealed that  (SPOILER) he can control the robed and tattooed figures at-will, with Cloud suffering hallucinations of Sephiroth in their place .

[Didn't See That Coming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntSeeThatComing): He has this happen to him three times in *Rebirth,* which each eliciting a different response:
    - The first time is when he (SPOILER) attacks the WEAPON that's sheltering Tifa and, for once, he actually has trouble in dislodging the sword from the beast's body. [He actually visibly panics a bit at this.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoStoic) - The second time is when he (SPOILER) possesses a robed man and impales Tseng. As he gloats to the party that they will soon join him in death, Tseng shows he is [Not Quite Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotQuiteDead) and shoots him in the back. Sephiroth's face shows shock and disbelief right before his body dies. - The third time occurs during (SPOILER) the final battle, when Aerith, who Sephiroth had seemingly just killed, appears to fight alongside Cloud against him. Sephiroth actually admits that her appearance has thrown him for a loop and that he underestimated her.
[Dimensional Cutter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DimensionalCutter): He can make portals by slicing the air.

[Dissonant Serenity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DissonantSerenity):
    - When Cloud first "encounters" him, Sephiroth is casual and calm while standing in an alleyway that's gone up in flames. note  This is all revealed to be a hallucination. - He's comically nonchalant about (SPOILER) strolling into the Shinra building while ignoring most of the security, to the point where he's not shown to have even killed anyone until the President's office.
[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): The mere sight of Sephiroth walking through the hallways of Shinra's headquarters causes Palmer to drop his tea in shock.

[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss):  (SPOILER) Subverted during the final fight with him in *Remake*. Cloud initially faces him one-on-one, but then two of his teammates (depending on how much you used them during the preceding fight against Whisper Harbinger) intervene on his side.

[Elemental Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalPowers):  (SPOILER) In the third phase of the battle with him, he can change up his elemental affinity between Fire, Ice, Lightning, and Wind, giving himself attacks in that elemental but a weakness to the opposing element. After cycling through all four, he infuses himself with all four elements and gains resistance to all of them.

[Entitled Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EntitledBastard): Despite all his declarations of godhood this is what he is at the center of his motivations. After learning his true origins, he considers the Planet and everyone on it his property by right.

[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment): In this version, he makes his first appearance shortly after the mission to blow up the Sector 1 Reactor, and immediately proceeds to guide Cloud through an illusion he creates of a burning alleyway leading up to Nibelheim, and taunts him with his murder of his mother. Afterwards, he tells Cloud to run and live with his hatred. <sup>note </sup>  To rub further salt in the wound, the Ultimania makes clear that him telling Cloud to run and that he has to live is him repeating Claudia's final words to Cloud before she was killed  It shows his crueler demeanor as well as reintroduces the player to his obsession with Cloud.

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): When he discovers the testing pods for the Makonoids in the Nibelheim Reactor, he's absolutely livid with [Tranquil Fury](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TranquilFury), expressing sheer disgust and hatred for what Hojo had done since it's absolutely horrific to put *live humans* inside pods filled with mako [just to see how they mutate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience). Unfortunately for the world at large, this and seeing Jenova's name inside the reactor also causes him to have a ["Eureka!" Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EurekaMoment) at realizing he's similarly born to be a superhuman weapon through experiments too.

[Evil Cannot Comprehend Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCannotComprehendGood): In the climax of *Rebirth*,  (SPOILER) he believes his efforts of corrupting the Planet through merging worlds of [The Multiverse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMultiverse) together is something the Planet *wants*, and that its [utter cacophony of sound it creates](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HellIsThatNoise) is some sort of "ecstasy" at giving it that. When Cloud points out that it's the voice of a Planet in pain and agony, Sephiroth sighs, calling out Cloud for still "not understanding him" before attacking Cloud [mentally](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape) again as if out of spite for being called wrong since he *still* can't understand the Planet even after everything he's seen and done against it.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): Like in the original, he shows himself as one to Cloud and Aerith.
    - Like Cloud, he was once a SOLDIER, being stronger, more durable and faster than any normal human- as well as being proficient with a giant blade. In gameplay, this even is translated as both sharing similar moves. Furthermore, both want to defy fate, but Sephiroth does so for his own sake, while Cloud (SPOILER) does it for the sake of his friend Zack . - Like Aerith, he has special magic powers that stand out from regular Materia- his dark magic when compared to Aerith's holy powers. Also, they both (SPOILER) have the knowledge of the fate of their original counterparts, specially their deaths. However, he seeks to undo his fate while she seemingly resigns herself to it and accepts what is to come.

[Evil Is Bigger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsBigger): Downplayed compared to most examples. Sephiroth isn't a giant, but he is still noticeably taller and bulkier than the heroes, sans Barret.  (SPOILER) Sephiroth Reborn, meanwhile, *is* a giant, one big enough that an early part of the fight involves doing a [Colossus Climb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColossusClimb).

[Evil Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilLaugh): In *Rebirth*, he gives a haunting laugh after  (SPOILER) Cloud deflects his attempt to murder Aerith, only for a timeline distortion to seemingly reverse this and allow him to kill her anyway.  He gives another one as he escapes after the final battle.

[Fallen Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenHero): As shown in *Rebirth*, Sephiroth was a veteran of the Wutai War and an all-around stand-up guy until he discovered Jenova at the Nibelheim Mako Reactor—which doubled as one of Professor Hojo's research facilities for creating monsters—and read Professor Gast's research notes on her discovery and the inception of the Jenova Project. After this, Sephiroth snapped and razed Nibelheim to the ground, killing anyone who stood in his way or even just happened to cross his path.

[Faux Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FauxAffablyEvil): Bizarrely, his treatment of Cloud in *Remake* is akin to that of greeting an old friend/rival more than the hated [Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy) he is determined to destroy from before. He even expresses his wish for Cloud to run away and survive; however, given this is [still Sephiroth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard) and Aerith's own affirmations that he is just as evil as ever, it's quite easy to see his plans for Cloud and Avalanche are *not at all* benign in nature.  (SPOILER) His taunting of Cloud in the final stretch of *Rebirth* reconfirms that he is quite as nasty and narcissistic as ever, whatever affection he holds for him being entirely self-serving, treating him like a toy.

[Feather Flechettes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeatherFlechettes):  (SPOILER) During the final battle's last phase, he can fire the feathers from his wing as projectiles which will stun the character you're currently controlling.
[Fighting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingAShadow): He is killed at several points in *Rebirth*, only for it to be a Sephiroth Clone he possessed.
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss):  (SPOILER) He's the last enemy the player faces as the party makes their escape from Midgar.
[Flash Step](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlashStep): Could easily be mistaken for teleporting in battle, were it not for the motion blur.

[For the Evulz](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForTheEvulz):
    - Considering his control over the clones, its heavily implied many of their actions and what is done to them in *Rebirth* are caused by his wishes. Notably (SPOILER) the clones stop moving in Costa del Sol so he was likely letting Hojo experiment on them just so he could. - Throughout *Rebirth*, Rufus (SPOILER) speaks to Glenn and is belittled, goaded and insulted every time. At the end it is revealed that he is a robed man glamoured like Glenn. Meaning Sephiroth spent days, or even weeks depending on how long the game is supposed to be following Rufus just to screw with him . - At the end of *Rebirth* (SPOILER) Cloud finds the Black Materia in his possession, with the implication Sephiroth gave it to him solely to show that Cloud will give it back whenever he asks .

[Gaslighting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Gaslighting): In *Rebirth,* Sephiroth makes use of this to weaken Cloud's grip on his identity and his trust in his allies.  (SPOILER) He insinuates that Tifa is a Jenova copy until Cloud attempts to kill her in a paranoid fit, and then begins to cast doubt on Cloud's own emotional state, either calling him a hollow puppet or a deluded lunatic .

[Glass Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlassCannon):  (SPOILER) Fitting Sephiroth's nature as a villain whose threat is mostly in how much power other people give him over them, he has easily the weakest defenses of any boss in the game: he's a simple [Barrier Change Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarrierChangeBoss) who's vulnerable to a wide variety of counters, goes into Pressured status whenever he takes damage, and his stagger gauge is extremely small. Much of the danger in fighting him is the scope, speed, and ferocity of his attacks causing the player to lose track of how to respond, with the final phase adding a countdown to add even more pressure. [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope) during his time as a [Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember), when he is a [Nigh-Invulnerable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NighInvulnerable) [Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser).

[Go Mad from the Revelation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoMadFromTheRevelation): *Rebirth* shows that Sephiroth was originally [a pretty nice guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure) as far as supersoldiers go, but discovering his "mother" Jenova contained in a Mako Reactor that had been used as a bioweapons laboratory by Hojo led to him worrying that he was something other than human. Reading Professor Gast's notes on Jenova's discovery—which incorrectly deduced that she was a Cetra—and the inception of the Jenova Project caused him to snap and go on a rampage to "rescue" her.

[Gravity Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GravityMaster):  (SPOILER) At one point during his boss battle, he uses a powerful Gravity spell to pin Cloud and either Aerith or Tifa to the ground. He then attempts to kill Cloud, but Aerith, Tifa, or Barret knock him away, cancelling the spell.

[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): For Part 1, with Aerith even pointing out that Shinra is a minor issue compared to him. He isn't the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) of the Midgar section, but he has his hands still involved, even if he only appears a few times. Like with the original game, once the heroes leave Midgar, he becomes the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad).
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): In *Rebirth*, he's a playable party member during a flashback, and unlike the original game, he can be directly controlled.
[Hellish Pupils](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HellishPupils): Sephiroth's pupils are catlike slits, as shown off in closeups of his face, evidence that he's not entirely human.

[Hero Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroKiller):  (SPOILER) In the climax of *Rebirth,* he manages to seemingly kill Aerith yet again, as he's become infamous for doing in the original game's timeline. This is in spite of Cloud managing to block the killing blow, only for Sephiroth to distort time into forcing his blade into Aerith anyway. However, there's a lot of ambiguity on whether or not he truly finished the job, as some form of Aerith is still existing.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): While he mostly keeps to himself, he has a few notable traits and quirks he reveals once he lets someone get to know him better:
    - He takes absolutely *meticulous* care of his long hair. According to his fanclub (which may or may not have been started *by Hojo himself*), he uses up an entire bottle of shampoo and conditioner *per day* to keep it perfectly flowing. The shampoo is reportedly even scented with rose and vanilla! - Despite growing up in Midgar, he's appears to be a nature lover. He's awestruck by the beauty and serenity of Nibelheim's mountains. - He wasn't above playing incredibly, hilariously stupid games with Genesis and Angeal. One game involved placing a dumbapple on one of their heads, with the other two *throwing swords at it* to score points. [Naturally, Sephiroth always won](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAce)...which really makes you wonder how the other two *survived losing* with their heads still attached.

[Hijacked by Ganon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HijackedByGanon):  (SPOILER) While he was always the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) of *Final Fantasy VII*, the Midgar sequence focused on the battle with Shinra until the very end, when the party left town to pursue Sephiroth. In *Remake*, he instead appears in person to the party as they escape and serves as the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss).
[Hijacking Cthulhu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HijackingCthulhu): He possesses some form of control or influence over Jenova and those infused with her cells.

[HP to One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HPToOne):  (SPOILER) His [Signature Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignatureMove), Heartless Angel, has him throw his sword to the ground, creating an  AOE  that will sap the health of anyone caught in it.

[Humanoid Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination): Sephiroth's long silver hair and cat-like eyes are already major cues he isn't a normal human, but this game amplifies it. When Aerith first sees him, she sternly notes "everything about [him] is *wrong*," and tells the others that the Lifestream itself is furious at Sephiroth because of who and what he is.  (SPOILER) In battle, he's an "Unreadable" enemy — the same as the [Whispers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimePolice), [Summons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlympusMons), and [Jenova](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination).

[Immortality Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImmortalitySeeker):  (SPOILER)  The only part of his goals that are clear is that he outright tells Cloud that he wants to live forever. Interestingly, Sephiroth also tells Cloud that he desires to have **Cloud** live forever too.
[Kamehame Hadoken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KamehameHadoken): One of his new moves in *Rebirth* is the Whisper Cannon, a stream of Whispers thrown out of his cupped hands.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): For supposedly trying to have Cloud more on his side this go around,  (SPOILER) many things he does in *Rebirth* to further his agenda are so utterly cruel that he's gone beyond the original game's attempts to inflict a [Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon) and is seemingly doing everything he possibly can to psychologically break Cloud, knowing exactly how he ticks now. Cloud's [Sanity Slippage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SanitySlippage) kicks in earlier, is notably nastier, and works towards potentially worse consequences as a result.
[Laser Blade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserBlade):  (SPOILER) Sephiroth Reborn is given a new trick in the ability to conjure one of these from his upper body, which he uses to perform his Zanshin.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): In *Rebirth* his Limit Break is [Octaslash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BladeSpam). He also has a newly upgraded extension to it, Octaslash Prime, which can be used with a Triangle press immediately after Octaslash.

[Long-Haired Pretty Boy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LongHairedPrettyBoy): Sephiroth possesses an eerie, otherworldly beauty that is emphasized by his long silver hair. It makes him look more androgynous than Cloud (who is also very pretty, himself).

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): Sephiroth's magical prowess is just as much as a problem as his swordsmanship. He starts out using the highest level of elemental magic, always opening with Firaga, and will prioritize using magic over his sword to trick players that mindlessly use Cloud's counterattacks and are expecting him to fight like he's usually been portrayed by aggressively rushing with his sword at the start, leading to many unobservant players getting smacked with a fireball at the start of the fight. As the fight continues, he gets to show off spells unique to himself as well as an entirely different form of Elemental Infusion that no one else showed in the game with new elemental spells to pack it all up. He's actually way more vulnerable to being put into a punishable state when he's using Masamune than when he's casually under-handing high level spells at the player.

tropeName: Make Wrong What Once Went Right
tropeNotes: [Make Wrong What Once Went Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakeWrongWhatOnceWentRight):  (SPOILER) It's indicated that Sephiroth wants to defy destiny in order to avert his future defeat.

[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): Shows the heroes visions of Meteor destroying Midgar  (SPOILER) which convinces them that the Arbiters of Fate wanting to keep this future in motion means that they need to change the future. [This leaves it possible for him to change the future in his favor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBadGuyWins).

[Master of Illusion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfIllusion): He torments Cloud with hallucinations and visions throughout the game, such as reminding him of Nibelheim's destruction. He also somehow hijacks Shinra's VR suite to show Cloud, Barret, and Tifa a vision of him summoning Meteor to destroy Midgar.

[Master Swordsman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterSwordsman): Sephiroth's ability with the Masamune is legendary, just the fact he can use such a massive blade is proof of his skill.  (SPOILER) During the final battle, he deflects Cloud's attacks so effortlessly sometimes he literally has it resting on his shoulder.

[Mirror Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MirrorBoss): His movelist, particularly in the first phase, can make you feel like fighting an evil version of Cloud's.  (SPOILER) Appropriately because their strength comes from the same source.

[Momma's Boy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MommasBoy): While it's not as prevalent in the main game, flashbacks to the Nibelheim Incident show Sephiroth still sees Jenova as his mother  (SPOILER) and seeks to conquer the Planet in her honor .

[Multiversal Conqueror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiversalConqueror): In *Rebirth*, Sephiroth reveals that he's no longer interested in *just* conquering the Planet and turning it into his vessel...  (SPOILER) he wants to conquer the *Final Fantasy VII* branch of the multiverse by causing all the disparate timelines to merge together .

[Mystical White Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysticalWhiteHair): Sephiroth's knee-length silvery-white hair is a product of the process that created him, and is evidence of his [malevolent nature](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteHairBlackHeart).

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag):
    - Referencing *[Crisis Core](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/CrisisCore)*, (SPOILER) his Octaslash limit break makes a comeback as a skill during the final boss fight, and is his [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) during his playable segment in *Rebirth*. Also, one of his attacks has him fire off the feathers from his wing as projectiles, much like Genesis did during his first boss fight . - Referencing *[Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/FinalFantasyVIIAdventChildren)*, some of his lines — "On your knees." and "Shall I bring you despair?" — are quotes from the movie. He also manipulates corrupted Lifestream and sprouts his iconic black wing when unleashing his full power. - Referencing *[Dissidia Final Fantasy (2015)](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy2015)*, (SPOILER) a majority of Sephiroth’s attacks during the final boss fight and his playable guest party member segment in *Rebirth* take inspiration from his moveset in that game, with attacks such as “Telluric Fury”, “Aeolian Onslaught”, “[Scintilla](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CounterAttack)”, “[Shadow Flare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow)”, and his iconic “[Hell's Gate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove)” acting as they originally functioned with some minor alterations. Also one of his regular attacks has him fire three purple sword beams, a reference to his Zanshin Bravery Attack. - The opening cutscene of (SPOILER) his showdown with Cloud at the End of the World parallels the cutscene that plays during the final showdown between him and Cloud at the end of the original *Final Fantasy VII* . Moreover, (SPOILER) the final attack Cloud attempts on Sephiroth at the End of the World is clearly Omnislash, or at least some nascent version of it. Sephiroth effortlessly dodges every would-be hit, then scolds Cloud with a smug "[Not yet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallForward)."

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): Much like [his original iteration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Characters/FinalFantasyVIISephiroth), before he went completely mad Sephiroth was well known among SOLDIER and the citizens of Midgar for his bravery, empathy and kindness. And despite his at-times aloof nature, was a good friend to other SOLDIER mainstays like Genesis, Angeal and Zack. Even Barrett angrily admits that it sounds he was a stand-up guy before he descended into insanity as Cloud was recounting his "experiences" with him, making it *just* a touch harder to completely hate him.

[Not So Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoStoic): Whereas Sephiroth in the original game was practically unable to be budged from his position of self-importance after his [Sanity Slippage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SanitySlippage),  (SPOILER) multiple cases in *Rebirth* actually catch him off-guard. He has to put on a tough gambit against Rufus and pretend to be Glenn, who is anything *but* stoic in his attempts to ruthlessly guilt trip the new ruler for his manipulations, and he genuinely falters during cases like his accidental summoning of Gilgamesh, when Tseng kills a clone he was actively controlling after he expected the Turk to be down and out, or when Aerith manages to catch him off-guard in the final battle and support the party post-mortem.

[Not-So-Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoWellIntentionedExtremist): From his cryptic musings, he implies that there are greater cosmic forces in the *Final Fantasy VII* universe  <sup>note </sup>  forces that *may have sent Jenova and then the Meteor* or did something even worse , and his main goal is to kill them all.  (SPOILER) And unfortunately, that just leaves the possibility that he wants to usurp them and become a god. 
QUOTE **Sephiroth:** Our world will become a part of it one day. But I *will not end*.

[Not So Invincible After All](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoInvincibleAfterAll): Throughout *Remake* and *Rebirth*, Sephiroth appears to be an almost unmatchable force, easily besting Cloud every time they fight and manipulating him all the while. At the climax of *Rebirth*  (SPOILER) Aerith's control over the White Whispers allows her to aid Cloud and Zack in their battles with him, and shows up in person to aid Cloud when Sephiroth shows his true form. Sephiroth is so taken back by her actions that he admits to underestimating her and the following battle ends with his defeat, even forcing him down to one knee and retreating .

[Obviously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObviouslyEvil): To a bigger extent than in the original, who first appears in person during a flashback sequence where he was still a hero. Here, Cloud bumps into a hallucination of him in the middle of Midgar's streets, and he proceeds to guide him through burning alleys, all while his ominous theme "Those Chosen By the Planet" is playing. Coupled with his unnatural, cat-like eyes and black outfit, it becomes clear he is the villain even for those who have never played or heard of the original game.

[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel):
    - Averted in *Remake* proper. [Despite being the trope namer he DOESN'T do this.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TropeNamer) While he does gain his black wing, he never turns into a giant monster and keeps a human form for the entire fight. - Zig-zagged in his final boss fight in *Rebirth*, where he (SPOILER) transforms into Sephiroth Reborn (known as Bizarro Sephiroth in the original game) to fight the party after a round of battle in his normal form, but reverts back for the final phase.

[Perpetual Molt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerpetualMolt): Throughout *Remake*, a single black feather almost always heralds Sephiroth's presence. At the climax of the game, he also appears surrounded by dozens of feathers... Strangely, these feathers  (SPOILER) appear before Sephy has revealed his wing .

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog):
    - Surprisingly, rather than taunting Cloud overly about his failure to stop the collapse of the Seventh District's Plate and the death of his friends, Sephiroth actually displays him some sympathy in this case. He just calmly acknowledges his failure and while he does have a mocking tone, he tells Cloud in a surprisingly genuine way that through suffering, he'll get stronger, patting him and showing sincereness. Considering that he became like he was now because what he went through, you can see it as Sephiroth genuinely trying to motivate Cloud into accepting the pain and growing stronger. - In the finale, he reveals that while he still holds on to his dream of existing forever (SPOILER) he doesn't actually want to destroy Cloud anymore either. Seemingly to prove this, after defeating Cloud in a one-on-one duel, he spares Cloud rather than killing him. Of course, this could just mean [Sephiroth still wants to manipulate Cloud to do his bidding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantKillYouStillNeedYou), as in the previous version of events.

[Polite Villains, Rude Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoliteVillainsRudeHeroes): He's amazingly polite to Cloud in each of their meetings, treating him as though he's a friend. Cloud, on the other hand, is as hostile as ever thanks to Sephiroth's past villainy.

[Power of the Void](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerOfTheVoid):  (SPOILER) His Boundless Void attack has him create a small black hole that will restrain one of your party members if they're caught by it.

[Promoted to Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotedToPlayable): Sephiroth is a fully playable party member in Chapter 1 of *'Rebirth*, and later in an exceptionally tough gauntlet via Chadley's combat simulator.
[Psychotic Smirk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoticSmirk): He's *never* seen without a contemptuously smug smile on his face.

tropeName: Reports of My Death Were Greatly Exaggerated
tropeNotes: [Reports of My Death Were Greatly Exaggerated](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReportsOfMyDeathWereGreatlyExaggerated): Sephiroth's been presumed dead for years, hence Cloud's shock at seeing him apparently alive and well.

[Screw Destiny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewDestiny): Sephiroth maintains that he wants to save the Planet by defying destiny,  (SPOILER) and scolds Cloud for failing to stop the Sector 7 plate from being dropped .

[The Sociopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSociopath): As noted by Aerith, he isn't affected by the emotions of people around him at all. The fact he honestly asks Cloud to [join him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeCanRuleTogether)  (SPOILER) despite burning down Cloud's hometown and killing Cloud's mother *and gloating about it*  speaks volumes to how little he understands or cares about others emotions. However, it is shown in *Rebirth* that he wasn't always so detached; he detested Hojo for his experiments on people, and tried searching for the Infantryman swept away by the river on Mt. Nibel, and even expresses regret over his failure to find him.

[Soft-Spoken Sadist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoftSpokenSadist): Sephiroth never raises his voice beyond a calmly smug tone, even as he's telling Cloud to remember how his mother died or mocking him over his failures.

[Stance System](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StanceSystem): As a playable character in *Rebirth*, Sephiroth can alternate between his regular moveset and Retaliation Stance—which lets him parry oncoming attacks.

[Strong and Skilled](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrongAndSkilled): The main reason why this time the heroes can't defeat him even when he is still clearly not going all-out. In the original game, they defeated him in his Safer-Sephiroth form but that form was simply throwing his raw power at the party. Here, Sephiroth is not only heavily indicated to be more powerful than ever, but he is also fought at his human form, meaning that extraordinary power is backed up with an incredible amount of seasoned skill and veteran experience that one would expect from the greatest SOLDIER.

[Spanner in the Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks): His whole plan revolves around messing up events that were supposed to happen while motivating Cloud into stopping the planet from fixing history.

[Sugar-and-Ice Personality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SugarAndIcePersonality): Sephiroth in a nutshell pre-Nibelheim. He outwardly gave the impression of someone who was cold, aloof and perpetually stoic. But in fact, this was largely because [he wasn't exactly a people-person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSocialSkills), and was a good man with a whole heap of internal conflict who cared deeply for his friends.

[Super-Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperSoldier): Sephiroth was the premier member of SOLDIER's First Class prior to his disappearance, and his white hair and catlike eyes further distinguish him from lesser  SOLDIERs  like Roche and Cloud.

[Sword Beam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordBeam): One of his unnamed attacks involves sending shockwaves of purple energy out with his sword slashes. The fact that they go unnamed implies that it just happens without any real effort on his part. This doubles as another reference to *Dissidia*, where throwing out sword beams was a staple of his moveset. The move is given a name in *Rebirth* as Zanshin.

[A Taste of Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ATasteOfPower): At the start of *Rebirth* for the Nibelheim flashback, he's playable like in the original game. *Unlike* the original, he's able to take damage and isn't a [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) for threats in his path, instead becoming a [Difficult, but Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DifficultButAwesome) parry-centric fighter that can continuously chain his attacks together like an utter damage machine, tearing Stagger bars up and getting insane damage if you can properly keep him from being momentarily stunned by damage. It still readily showcases that he's simply [Always Someone Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSomeoneBetter) to the fresh-faced Cloud five years prior, as in *leagues* beyond him.

[They Killed Kenny Again](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheyKilledKennyAgain): In *Rebirth*, he gets killed several times by Cloud and the party, once by Tseng, and once by Rufus. Each time, it was just him possessing a Sephiroth Clone, so he treats it as a minor inconvenience before he gets another body.

[Time-Limit Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeLimitBoss): In *Remake*,  (SPOILER)  drop his health down to critical levels, he'll summon Meteor and start counting down. If his countdown reaches 0, Meteor *will* [Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill), incentivizing you to *quickly* defeat Sephiroth.  In *Rebirth*,  (SPOILER)  at critical health he begins firing dual Whisper Cannons and rotating in a circle while otherwise standing perfectly still, with his Stagger meter turning blue and beginning to drain on its own. If the Stagger meter fully drains, he instantly kills the party with a 9999 damage version of Octaslash Prime.

[Troll](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Troll): Most of the time he just shows up to mock and scare Cloud before leaving. Most of it is part of his plan, but sometimes he's clearly just being an asshole only because he thinks its hilarious. It's especially apparent when Cloud isn't the victim. The prime examples are him scaring the shit out of Palmer by just choosing to walk past him while ignoring him, scaring a bunch of kids with one of his creepy clones in Sector 5 before Cloud even showed up, or  (SPOILER)  playing a silent "made you look" before teleporting and casually floating off to get Cloud to climb a big ladder on the top of the Shinra building and halfassedly jumping off with a smile when Cloud almost gets to the top .

[Villain Forgot to Level Grind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainForgotToLevelGrind): Played with in *Rebirth*. While Sephiroth is presented as even stronger overall than he was in *Remake*, his swordsmanship skills have begun to atrophy as he leans into his new powers instead, to his detriment. The final phase of his  (SPOILER) fight in *Rebirth* has very simple patterns to block or dodge, with reliance on excessively flashy skewering techniques and shows of force using Whispers as projectiles that leave him vulnerable, in contrast to the overwhelmingly fast and brutal assault he preferred in *Remake*. There are even times that he will abandon the Masamune altogether, giving Cloud and Aerith an opportunity to destroy it to weaken him. His wing serves as a similar weak point, when he once had no such weaknesses .

[Villainous Rescue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousRescue):
