    - In *Remake*, he (SPOILER) stabs President Shinra from behind while he has a gun trained on the party . - In ''Rebirth, he defeats the Midgardsormr and rescues Cloud from drowning.
[Villain Override](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainOverride): He can assume control of Sephiroth Clones in order to perform tasks,  (SPOILER) such as assassinating President Shinra .

[Villain Respect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainRespect):
    - In the original game, Sephiroth was infamously *very* dismissive of Cloud as a [Spanner in the Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks) for his plans, only really manipulating him because he was an optimal pawn on the board at the time and then growing to hate him by *Advent Children*. Here, while he loves to [Troll](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Troll) Cloud and get a rise out of him, he very personally knows why Cloud hates him so much, (SPOILER) and seems inclined to bring Cloud up to his level in his [Immortality Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImmortalitySeeker) plan, sparing him after their final battle to keep him on the "right path" to their future and offering a [We Can Rule Together](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeCanRuleTogether). - He also grows to feel this way towards (SPOILER) Aerith in *Rebirth* after she continues to hinder him by helping the party and Zack with her magic during the fight against his "Sephiroth Reborn" form and later show up in person for his final duel with Cloud to back him up.

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): While Sephiroth's existence and evil nature has been a part of gaming's [Pop Culture Osmosis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PopCultureOsmosis) for ages, his role in the *Remake*  (SPOILER) and its [Cosmic Retcon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CosmicRetcon)  makes it hard to talk about him in length, other than that he's in the game.

[Weapon Specialization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaponSpecialization): Sephiroth has always had a thing for katanas. As a teenager he wielded a regular-sized one called Nameless, while as an adult he wields a massive nōdachi called the Masamune.

[We Can Rule Together](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeCanRuleTogether): In his own words, with how sincere they are being up to debate:
QUOTE  **Sephiroth:** Cloud, lend me your strength. [Let us defy destiny... together.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewDestiny)

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): While trying to persuade Cloud to join him, Sephiroth claims to be fighting against fate itself to preserve the Planet.  (SPOILER) However, Aerith disagrees with his way of doing so as it would involve sacrificing those living and believes the planet does not wish for that.

[White Hair, Black Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteHairBlackHeart): Already one of the most famous examples of the trope there is, Sephiroth still has his silvery-white hair and is still as cruel and self-serving as ever.

tropeName: Why Don't You Just Shoot Him?
tropeNotes: [Why Don't You Just Shoot Him?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhyDontYouJustShootHim): Ironic, given that he infamously does exactly this trope to Aerith at one point. A [Fatal Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatalFlaw) of his is that he can't help but gloat and taunt the opponents that catch his interest, preferring to play mind games with them rather than just end them once and for all. This often backfires on him, as him playing with his food often means that his enemy or one of their allies has a chance to strike back at the opening and turn the tables.
[Winged Humanoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WingedHumanoid): When using his full power, he manifests a single black wing from his right shoulder.

[Woobie, Destroyer of Worlds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WoobieDestroyerOfWorlds): While it may not excuse his actions, the *Remake* continuity makes it hard to not symphathise with Sephiroth's backstory. Despite being isolated by his enhanced abilities, pre-breakdown he shows himself to be a good and heroic man with many redeeming qualities. Having no knowledge of the actual truth of his origins and parents due to being lied to his entire life (namely: his real parents, that he *is* human, and his abilities are a result of human experimentation in the womb to inject him with Mako and Jenova cells), he then stumbles across Shinra's research on Jenova with its incorrect conclusions and gets driven insane by the implications, with no one around who can correct him and assuage his worst fears about being inhuman. In fact, it's implied that even Sephiroth himself is actually aware of how far he has fallen deep down, considering how he mentions to Cloud about "through suffering, you will grow strong", that being perhaps the only time where he shows any kind of genuine empathy towards Cloud.

[World's Best Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsBestWarrior): Just like in the original, Sephiroth is the greatest warrior in SOLDIER history, his accomplishments in Shinra's war with Wutai highly distinguishing himself as a hero, with it being said that he accomplished legendary feats that inspired countless people into joining the military. Being the most powerful man alive aside, he pretty much proves to also have the legendary combat skills to be the greatest warrior on the planet when he single-handedly fights in his human form against the entire party by himself and shows off incredible swordsmanship and magical abilities to hold them off while clearly not displaying all the abilities he had due to needing them in the future. Likewise, he proves himself to be truly the best warrior when he easily defeats Cloud, who has been able to defeat him numerous times before the remake, while still clearly toying with him.

[World's Strongest Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsStrongestMan): Sephiroth is easily considered the strongest being on the planet to the point where most tall tales actually *underestimate* how powerful he is (rather than the other way around).  (SPOILER) And he proves it at the end, where he fights a five-on-one battle with the party harder than ever and holds his ground throughout most of the battle, while proving himself to be easily capable of handling Cloud one-on-one, giving him a [Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle) even when he did seemingly lose the fight with the party, and putting him and another one of his friends on the ropes until the complete party arrives. It was also evident he still wasn't fighting at full strength, as he makes it clear he still needs the party and Cloud alive for his future plans.

[Adaptational Attractiveness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalAttractiveness): It was heavily implied the Sephiroth Clones were deformed and heavily burned beneath their robes in the original game. Here, they look like normal, if somewhat ragged, people.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): The Sephiroth Clones couldn't even move very fast in the original, or fight. Here, Sephiroth is able to turn them into powerful vessels of his will and power. Marco not only is the one to kill President Shinra and nearly Barret, but serves as a [Climax Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClimaxBoss).

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): In the original game, the Sephiroth Clones were largely background elements you had to go out of your way to find who were there to act as subtle foreshadowing to the true nature of Cloud and Sephiroth. In *Rebirth*, they are the central figures of the entire plot, as all the major figures at play surmise that they are drawn to Sephiroth and follow their lead in an endeavors to find the missing SOLDIER.
[Black Cloak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackCloak): They wear hooded black robes that obscure their faces.

[Death of Personality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathOfPersonality): Whatever personalities they had before are reduced to barely functioning instinctual puppets. The subtitles even get on it  (SPOILER) the robed ones that used to be Broden and Roche are referred to as Robed Man rather than their old names after they turn .

[Empty Shell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmptyShell): Although they are technically alive, whatever individual personality they use to have is long gone. All that is left is barely functioning humans who act more like zombies than people.
[Goroawase Number](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoroawaseNumber): Marco's number is 49, a wordplay on "shi ku": [Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourIsDeath) and Suffering.

[Implacable Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImplacableMan): Because they are compulsively and irresistibly drawn to Sephiroth and Jenova, they have no regard for their own well-being and continue shambling on no matter what's in their way. While some are killed by monsters, none of them seem to suffer from exhaustion, exposure to the elements, or hunger, and they're implicitly able to navigate the same treacherous terrain as Cloud and his allies without any trouble. Most if not all of them still have the physical abilities of a SOLDIER, simply without the mind to actually use it anymore.
[In the Hood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheHood): Their faces are shrouded in darkness underneath.
[Madness Mantra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadnessMantra): They mumble "Reunion..." under their breaths, signifying that they're not altogether there mentally.

[Meat Puppet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeatPuppet): Sephiroth can control them at will, causing them to take on his appearance — at least [to Cloud's eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThroughTheEyesOfMadness).

[Remote Body](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RemoteBody): Act as this to Sephiroth. When Sephiroth wants to interact with someone, he take control of one of his clones who will temporarily go through a [Transformation of the Possessed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TransformationOfThePossessed).
[Transformation of the Possessed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TransformationOfThePossessed): When Sephiroth is controlling them, they can assume his appearance.

[The Undead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUndead):  (SPOILER) As revealed in *Rebirth*, they are shown to be this - as seen where they still move and mumble despite the captain of Shinra-8 *scoring a headshot* on them, and Roche (after his Mako infusion) immediately gets raised as one of the robed one's after he succumbs to his wounds.
[We Have Reserves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHaveReserves): No matter how many of them die throughout the journey in *Rebirth*, there always seem to be more wherever the party goes next.

[What Measure Is a Non-Human?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatMeasureIsANonHuman): The party gradually begin finding it uncomfortable how others treat the Clones as an annoyance at best or a monster worthy of execution at worst, when by all accounts these were once ordinary people whose condition is no fault of their own. Barret in particular comes to see everyone's treatment of the Clones as abominable after witnessing the events on the cruise ship and in Costa Del Sol.

[You Are Number 6](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreNumberSix): They each have numbers tattooed on their shoulders, with only Tifa and Cloud's neighbor at Marle's apartment, Clone #49, having a name of his own — Marco. A few more are given names in *Rebirth*, as the party is given a chance to interact with some characters who are degrading but haven't yet succumbed to Jenova's control on their first meeting.

[Adaptational Ugliness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalUgliness): Very downplayed given she's always been a nightmarish alien parasite, but generally, Jenova's more monstrous transformations had up until this point been relegated to the original game, wherein they're simply in the form of lowpoly sprites like the rest of the enemies, with Compilation media placing far more focus on the recurring image of her humanoid feminine torso. Here though, these forms are given loving detail once more, and each and every one of them is a hideous [Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination) all patterned around the same recurring image of a scowling, sinister [skull](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkullForAHead).

[Alien Blood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlienBlood): Compared to the original where the trail of her blood that Sephiroth left behind was normal red blood, this time around its a dark, scintillating purple that moves around as though it's alive and emits wisps of dark energy.

[Ancient Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AncientEvil): Jenova is an [Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination) that arrived on the planet inside a meteor 2000 years before the present, devastated the Cetra's civilization, and was trapped in a glacier by the ice deity Shiva.

[Body Horror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyHorror): Jenova's humanoid form might be considered attractive... were it not for the protruding veins and grotesque organ-like extrusions. Her monstrous form is downright nightmarish.

[Captured Super-Entity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CapturedSuperEntity): Jenova is an ancient eldritch entity that is being kept and studied by Shinra under the misconception that she is one of the Cetra.  (SPOILER) Professor Hojo has dedicated half his life to studying her and the majority of his experiments involve infusing other life forms with her biomass to augment them.

[The Corruption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCorruption): Those infused with Jenova's cells become more powerful, typically at the cost of mutating into horrifying monsters. Hojo has dedicated most of his life towards weaponizing this to create nightmarish bioweapons.
[The Corruptor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCorruptor): The ghosts of the Cetra in the Temple of the Ancients suggest that she might have seeded the hatred that caused the humans to attack them.

[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): She becomes this to Sephiroth near the end of part 1 and like the original game Sephiroth uses Jenova like a puppet and to disguise as Sephiroth himself.

[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): Jenova is introduced as [a white-haired humanoid entity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination) floating in a stasis tank, but is capable of assuming horrifically monstrous forms.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Jenova is still pretty much a very expanded version of John Carpenter's *[The Thing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/TheThing1982)*. Now down to the little details such as blood that can move on its own.<!--* MeatPuppet: It's indicated that -- as in the original game -- Sephiroth assumes control of her body and transforms it into a replica of his own.-->
[Mystical White Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysticalWhiteHair): Jenova's humanoid form possesses long white hair, though her true nature is anything but human.

[People Jars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PeopleJars): She is contained in a large stasis tank in the center of the Drum, a classified laboratory resembling a larger version of her containment chamber in the Nibelheim mako reactor.  (SPOILER) She escapes at the end of the game with Sephiroth's help, to Professor Hojo's delight.
[Sealed Evil in a Can](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SealedEvilInACan): Shiva's dossier reveals that Jenova was frozen in a glacier by the ice deity 2,000 years in the past.

[Shapeshifter Guilt Trip](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShapeshifterGuiltTrip): How she originally infiltrated and destroyed the Cetra civilzation.
QUOTE **Sephiroth**: They say she's a monster. That she can peer inside you—into the very depths of your soul. That she can become those you hate. Those you fear. ...Those you *love*.

[Shapeshifter Swan Song](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShapeshifterSwanSong): Her "corpse" looks to be the result of some severe shapeshifter [Power Incontinence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerIncontinence) at the moment of or just before her supposed death given all the extra appendages, organs, eyeballs, protrusions and degradation and decomposition seen all over her body.

[Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming): In the Japanese version and some other translations, its boss forms retain the life-themed naming of the original game, with Jenova-BIRTH, Jenova-LIFE, and the newly added Jenova-BEAT (as in heart beat).

[The Virus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVirus): Jenova's biomass can infect other organisms, mutating them into horrific monsters. Hojo seeks to weaponize this property as a means of augmenting monsters and people alike.

[0% Approval Rating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZeroPercentApprovalRating): You'll be hard-pressed to find anyone in Wall Market who talks/thinks about Don Corneo favorably and even many of his closer associates like the Trio and Leslie are quick to turn on him to assist Cloud's party when given the opportunity.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): A very minor one.  (SPOILER) When Leslie holds him at gunpoint, he actually manages to pull off an impressive disarm and turn the tables on him. Of course, he still completely crumples when Cloud and company intervene in the nick of time. It's still more fighting prowess than he ever showed in the original.
[Adipose Rex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdiposeRex): He's the don of the Sector 6 slums and is a lecherous fat guy.

[Always a Bigger Fish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysABiggerFish): For all the fear and clout he carries in Wall Market, all the power he wields as the Don of all the Slums, even he is forced to turn tail and run out of Midgar out of fear of pissing off Shinra.

[Ambiguously Bi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBi): Maybe. Though he's clearly attracted to women he gravitates towards Cloud's masculine-sounding voice and identifies him appealingly as "big-boned", and he doesn't seem that put out when he discovers Cloud is male.

[Aroused by Their Voice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArousedByTheirVoice): Despite the fact that Cloud doesn’t even try to act like a woman (or maybe *because* [of that](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBi)), Corneo nonetheless acts turned on by his voice.

[Beware the Silly Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheSillyOnes): Corneo looks and acts goofy for a crime lord, but he is also a literal serial killer and rapist that numerous characters have serious vendettas against, and always manages to be slightly more in control of any given situation than he first appears to be. Leslie actually puts it best when Cloud implies that he may just storm Corneo's mansion through the front door:
QUOTE **Leslie:** Wouldn't try it if I were you. Trust me, you don't wanna screw with the don. If you even *think* about causing trouble, he'll make sure someone pays for it. And that "someone" might wind up being the girl you're trying so hard to break out. Or it could wind up being someone *you've never even met before.* Get it? You're in the don's world now.

[The Bluebeard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBluebeard): The women he chooses are refered to as his "today's bride" and he'll only keep them around if they satisfy him enough. Once he's done with them, he'll then feed them to his pet monster.

[Card-Carrying Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CardCarryingVillain): He hangs a lampshade on the [Evil Gloating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGloating) trope while trying to get Cloud, Aerith, and Tifa to stand on the trap door in the floor of his room, outright calling himself a villain.

[Dirty Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldMan): While his age is never stated, Corneo is certainly no spring chicken, yet he seems to favour younger women. He also doesn't like taking no for an answer, and seems unconcerned over whether or not his brides are willing participants.

[The Don](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDon): Don Corneo is a lecherous crime lord in Sector 6's slums, ostensibly rejecting even Shinra's authority according to the game's Twitter page, and is established in the Theme Song Trailer as taking a new woman as his "bride" each night before feeding them to his pet monster Abzu when he's done having his way with them.
[Fat Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatBastard): He's got a noticeable gut and is one mean bastard, being a lecherous, sadistic crime lord.

[Faux Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FauxAffablyEvil): Don't be fooled by that jolly, goofy persona of his. His silly, outlandish mannerisms and fun-loving disposition only serve to highlight how maniacally debauched he is. He enslaves women, then feeds them to his monstrous pet as soon as he's tired of their company. He is also perfectly fine with mass murder if it means securing more power for himself, hence his deal with Shinra to help in Sector 7's destruction.

[Gladiator Games](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GladiatorGames): He hosts no-holds-barred gladiator matches at the Corneo Colosseum, an arena located under Wall Market, which Cloud and Aerith have to compete in.
[Gonk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Gonk): He's rather hideous, with tacky clothes and a stupid hairstyle that do him no favors on top of his unfortunate looks.
[Good Hair, Evil Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodHairEvilHair): Sports a disconnected, side-swept undercut with a handlebar mustache and chinstrap beard.
[Groin Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GroinAttack): Just like in the original, Cloud, Aerith, and Tifa threaten the don with this if he doesn't give them the information that they want.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): Don Corneo is a licentious mobster who forces himself onto women, feeds them to his pet monster when he grows bored of them, and is otherwise responsible for having people’s lives be ruined or possibly worse. All these things make it clear that there is nothing redeeming about Don Corneo.
[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): He refers to Cloud as a "Big boned girl" but he's the fattest guy in the room.

[Insult Backfire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsultBackfire): The vulgar comments that Cloud makes at him only serve to get Corneo *even more* excited rather than being repulsed, with him only taking offense after Cloud kicks him away.
[Jiggle Physics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JigglePhysics): On his fat stomach, just to make him look even grosser.
[Just Between You and Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustBetweenYouAndMe): He *loves* this and especially wants his victims to know that the villain *only* does this when they're sure they've won.

[Kavorka Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KavorkaMan): Don Corneo is an unattractive man, but somehow manages to net himself a new "bride" almost every evening. Once he's bored of them, however, he feeds them to his pet monster. Leslie's backstory and NPC dialogue indicate that many women who find their way into his bedchambers may actually just be down on their luck and tragically resort to becoming his brides in the hopes that a night with the Don will net them enough money to get them back on their feet.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): His name literally means "Lord Horny". It also puns on [Don Corleone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/TheGodfather).

[Occidental Otaku](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OccidentalOtaku): He's indicated to have an appreciation for Wutai culture, with his mansion being themed after a Japanese castle and one of his high-ranking employees being an *oiran*.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): Aerith, Cloud, and Tifa threatening to castrate him unless he tells them why he was having his goons spy on Avalanche trumps his fear of retaliation from Heidegger.
[Perverted Sniffing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PervertedSniffing): He does this to Aerith while checking her out as his prospective "bride".

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): Subverted. He tells Leslie that he was planning to promote him and give him territory of his own if things went well. But now that he is on Shinra's bad side, he sees no reason to not try to blow Leslie's brains out on the spot.

[Psychopathic Man Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychopathicManChild): Cloud's vulgar comments towards him causes him to get rather giggly, such as how at one point, Corneo flails his arms and legs about on the bed before deciding that he's waited long enough, and wants some sugar.

tropeName: Rape Is a Special Kind of Evil
tropeNotes: [Rape Is a Special Kind of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RapeIsASpecialKindOfEvil): He blatantly forces himself on top of women. Corneo also dumps off girls that didn't quite catch his full attention to his horny goons. Said goons are ecstatic with what they claim to be Corneo rewarding them.

[Smarter Than You Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmarterThanYouLook): Even with his updated, more realistic character design, he's a ridiculous caricature of a man with a [Psychopathic Manchild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychopathicManchild) demeanour that makes it very hard to take him seriously. This is a mistake - he's a clever and ruthless opportunist who's always a little more in control of the situation than he seems to be, which is how he manages to repeatedly survive his run-ins with the heroes. Cloud even warns Yuffie not to underestimate him in *Rebirth*.

[Stout Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoutStrength): Proves himself to be surprisingly strong when he disarms the much younger and more obviously combat-capable  (SPOILER) Leslie , crushing his wrist with a one-handed twist before bringing him to his knees with a punch to the gut.
[Tattoo as Character Type](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TattooAsCharacterType): He has a tattoo of a heart on his head and infamous for being a lecherous womanizer.
[Too Kinky to Torture](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooKinkyToTorture): Cloud trash-talking and insulting him only serves as a turn-on, though he's livid when Cloud dares to physically strike him.
[Villain: Exit, Stage Left](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainExitStageLeft): His final appearance in Part 1 has the heroes corner him, only for him to successfully escape when Abzu attacks them.
[Co-Dragons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoDragons): The two serve as Don Corneo's lieutenants and seem to share equal authority.
[Combat Commentator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatCommentator): Mostly in the  (SPOILER) Hell House boss  battle and the fights at Gold Saucer's Musclehead Colosseum.
[Delinquent Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DelinquentHair): Playing up his urban delinquent look, Kotch sports a blond mohawk.

[The Host](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHost): They act as the Masters of Ceremony at Corneo Colosseum, announcing the combatants and hyping up the crowd. They hijack this role from Dio in *Rebirth* when they and Corneo attempt to seize the Musclehead Colosseum for themselves.

[Large-Ham Announcer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHamAnnouncer): As the  MC s of the Colosseum, they snark at participants, hype them up, and gleefully participate in [Lampshade Hanging](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging). The change of venue in *Rebirth* does not diminish this in the slightest.

[Locked Up and Left Behind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LockedUpAndLeftBehind): Following a raid on Corneo's mansion by Shinra's troops, Kotch ends up restrained on a table in Corneo's torture chamber. Cloud and company can free him if they so wish.
[Noble Male, Roguish Male](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleMaleRoguishMale): Scotch is the more stylish and suave of the two whereas Kotch is more straightforward and brash.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): Scotch recognizes Aerith as one of the Corneo Colosseum's new champions and has a brief moment of panic before she [kicks him in the crotch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GroinAttack) and Tifa boots him in the face.

[Shipper on Deck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipperOnDeck): When Cloud and Aerith sign up to the Corneo Colosseum, Scotch and Kotch assume they're romantically involved and play them up as a couple united by unquenchable bloodlust while  MCing .

[Slimeball](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Slimeball): Scotch has a more suave style than Kotch, but proves to be every bit as sleazy as his fellow MC and Don Corneo's other henchmen when given the opportunity to "entertain" Aerith and Tifa.

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): In *Rebirth* they're the antagonists of the Protorelic quest in the Grasslands, with the party having to fight and track them down several times all over the map.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): They appear to be based off the [Vice enemies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BanditMook) from the original game that were randomly encountered in the Sector 5 slums. Now they're minor antagonists encountered by the party numerous times.
[Batter Up!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BatterUp): Burke's weapon-of-choice is a nail-studded bat.

[Beware the Silly Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheSillyOnes): Despite Beck, Burke, and Butch mostly being comic relief, they're still a dangerous threat. Special mention goes to Butch who, though *definitely* the least intelligent of the three core members, is also the strongest, having a fair bit more HP than his partners in crime.

[Bringing in the Expert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BringingInTheExpert): Beck's Badasses does this quite a bit. In the Corneo Cup tournament, they reinforce themselves with 5 of Corneo's Lackeys — these guys provide [More Dakka](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreDakka) and grenades to the trio's melee. After that, they hire the Grungy Bandit — a fighter from the Colosseum, who becomes a permanent member of the group unlike those previous others. In *Rebirth* the last fight with them has them using a modded Sweeper to help fight off the party.

[Bullying a Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingADragon): Their profiles note that they are terrible at sizing up potential targets, and they pick fights with Cloud numerous times across the story — initially mistaking him and Aerith for an easy mark. The final time they do so, they are terrified when they recognize Cloud.

[Criminal Craves Legitimacy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CriminalCravesLegitimacy): In *Rebirth* they want to go "legit" and start a new "corporation" like Shinra. By the end of their questline, the party takes pity on them and agrees to just buy the Protorelic they found — but only after they promise that they'll abandon their criminal ways, which they all agree to, with Beck now calling himself their "president".
    - That said, by the end of the final sidequest in the Grasslands near the end of the game, they go right into being outlaw bikers.

[Delusions of Eloquence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DelusionsOfEloquence): The quite possibly only reason why Beck is still the leader of his own criminal gang is that he's dumb enough to believe that he's way smarter than he actually is, yet smart enough to not completely butcher his pronunciations (even though he's using expressions that he clearly has no idea what they really mean), combined with the fact that all the other bandits are so dumb that they actually fall for his ruse.

[Dumb Muscle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DumbMuscle): The Grungy Bandit / Burt that Beck's gang recruits later on in the game is dumb even by their idiotic standards. In fact, he isn't even intelligent enough to speak. That said, he is *by far* the strongest member of Beck's Badasses, being tankier than all three of them put together and having highly damaging attacks to boot.
[Egocentric Team Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EgocentricTeamNaming): Beck is a cocky guy who named the gang "Beck's Badasses" after himself.

[Feigning Intelligence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeigningIntelligence): Beck routinely uses big words in an attempt to sound smarter than he actually is, but falters whenever Butch asks him for clarification on what he means. Using the Assess Meteria on him reveals that "feigning knowledge of things" is Beck's "special ability."
[Gangbangers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Gangbangers): They're a small street gang that lurks in seedier parts of Midgar.

[Goldfish Poop Gang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldfishPoopGang): You know you're Goldfish Poop when the hero denies knowing who you are.
QUOTE **Beck:** Not so fast! You wanna come through here, you'll have to provide due compens- You again!?<br data-format="\\"/>**Burke:** [Oh shit!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap)<br data-format="\\"/>**Barret:** Friends of yours?<br data-format="\\"/>**Cloud:** Nope.<br data-format="\\"/>**Beck:** Stop lying! We go *way* back!
[The Highwayman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHighwayman): They mainly prowl the Collapsed Expressway of Sector 6, robbing people who try to pass through the area.

[Ineffectual Sympathetic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IneffectualSympatheticVillain): They are so stupid and ineffective that *Rebirth* starts playing them for sympathy, with the party pitying them so much they agree to pay them for the Protorelic, even though they could just kill them.

[The Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLeader): Beck is the leader of the gang, by virtue of being the least stupid member. His description even states that his ability to [feign intelligence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeigningIntelligence) is how he has been able to recruit the members of his gang.
[Malevolent Masked Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MalevolentMaskedMen): They all wear black masks with white sigils on the front.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): Their final appearance in *Remake* has them react in horror when they realize they've come across Cloud again. In *Rebirth* they similarly react with terror upon bumping into the party again.

[Named by the Adaptation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamedByTheAdaptation): In *Remake*, the muscular Colosseum fighter they hire is only known as "Grungy Bandit". In *Rebirth* he's revealed to be named Burt, which conveniently fits with the naming convention of the other three.
[Nothing but Skin and Bones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NothingButSkinAndBones): Burke has a lanky, malnourished build with visible ribs, as a sign of his poverty due to being a terrible bandit.

[Not Worth Killing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotWorthKilling): Really, the only explanation as to how they keep surviving encounters with Cloud. Even after their final story-mandated appearance in *Remake*, they can be fought at any time by returning to the spot in the ruined highway that serves as their new base of operations. In *Rebirth*, Aerith will straight up pity them and insist Cloud give them a chance by just paying for the Protorelic that they took.
[Only One Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyOneName): All members only get a single name.
[The Paralyzer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParalyzer): The only notable move Beck, Burke, and Butch can do is lay electric mines on the floor, which will paralyze anyone who steps on them.

[Playing Possum](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingPossum): They play dead upon being defeated, and can be heard whispering conspicuously to each other upon being first defeated. They also react in pain if stepped on. Using the Assess Meteria on them reveals that "playing dead" is Burke and Butch's "special ability."

[Quirky Miniboss Squad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuirkyMinibossSquad): They're a bunch of incompetent idiots who *really* shouldn't keep picking fights with the people who keep wiping the floor with them, but seeing as they've got nothing better to do...

[Revenge Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevengeBeforeReason): Beck, Burke, and Butch challenge Cloud and Aerith in the Corneo Colosseum in order to seek "due recompense" for their humiliating defeat, bringing in members of Corneo's gang as an assist. They later seek a rematch with hired muscle from the Colosseum.

[Rouge Angles of Satin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RougeAnglesOfSatin): In the "The Price of Thievery" sidequest, they try to impersonate the Guardian Angel of the Slums to steal donations for the Leaf House, but malaprop her name as "Garden Angle" — leading to their ruse being exposed when Cloud apprehends them.
[Rule of Three](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RuleOfThree): They have three story-mandated appearances, each one resulting in them being further humiliated.

[Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag): Beck is the smartest of them — which isn't saying much — and a running gag is malapropism-prone Butch having to ask him for clarification whenever he uses big words.

[Serial Escalation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SerialEscalation): Only the first fight is against Beck, Butch, and Burke. When they pop up in the Corneo Cup, they quickly bring in five of Corneo's Lackeys to back them up; and every appearance after that has them backed up by their newest member Grungy Bandit / Burt, who's much stronger. However, the trope is also inverted, as they go from being introduced in cutscenes to being treated as if they were any other enemy on the map in their final appearances.
[Sinister Scimitar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SinisterScimitar): Butch's weapon of choice is a black-bladed scimitar.

[Stout Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoutStrength): Grungy Bandit / Burt has a bulky, stout build and is a very strong fighter who uses [wrestling moves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrestlerInAllOfUs).

[Terrible Trio](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TerribleTrio): Though Beck's Badasses does contain more than three members, its leaders, Beck, Burke, and Butch, qualifies. As for the "terrible" part, well... they try. And, to be fair to them, they *are* a band of notorious criminals at least. It's just that they're going up against Cloud and company.
[Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming): All their names start with *B*.
[The Unintelligible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnintelligible): Grungy Bandit / Burt is so stupid he doesn't know how to speak properly, with his few lines being completely unintelligible.

[Unique Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UniqueEnemy): Beck, Burke, and Butch serve as unique variants to the common "Bandit" enemies. Ironically, they're not all that much stronger than the enemies they're supposed to be unique versions of, and they're outright *weaker* than the blue-vested Bandits.

[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene): Burke and Butch both never wear a shirt, which is played for [Fan Disservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FanDisservice) since Butch is an obese [Gonk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Gonk) while Burke is [Nothing but Skin and Bones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NothingButSkinAndBones).

[Wrestler in All of Us](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrestlerInAllOfUs): New hire Grungy Bandit / Burt is a fighter from the Colosseum whose weapon of choice is wrestling moves like Press Slam and Choke Slam. Unlike Rude, [he's definitely willing to use them on Tifa](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldHitAGirl).

[Ambiguously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyEvil): The heroes can't really make heads or tails of them, but know they're certainly antagonistic at times.  (SPOILER) There's also the fact that Sephiroth can seemingly control them in the final battles, though it's hard to tell if that's actually what's going on.  Initially,  (SPOILER) they're on no one's side, just literally upholding fate. *Rebirth* switches things up by having the black-colored Whispers help Sephiroth subvert destiny while the white-colored ones continue to ensure that things remains on track for the Planet's survival.
[Black Cloak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackCloak): They're noted to resemble cloaked and hooded wraiths, accenting their sinister appearance.

[Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality): They're ready to save those that aren't supposed to die according to fate, and antagonize those that *are*.  (SPOILER) The Arbiters cause Jessie's grenade to blow up in her face and then block Cloud and Tifa from reaching her until it's too late, and prevent Wedge from fleeing the collapsing Sector 7 plate when he tries to rescue his cat — though he is revealed to have survived. Conversely, when Barret is killed by Sephiroth one of the Arbiters resurrects him, and they aid Aerith and Cloud when they're escaping the Sector 5 Church, blocking the Shinra infantry from reaching Aerith when she falls in front of them.
[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): The Arbiters of Fate were completely absent from the original *Final Fantasy VII*.
[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): In *Rebirth*, the Black Whispers are considered this to the original Arbiters as they're under Sephiroth's direct control.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): Despite the cast believing they're enemies, their first combat encounter has these things mostly being non-aggressive and doing pitiful damage until a more powerful spectre emerges, and their binding grab attacks are literally just encircling a character and doing surprisingly minuscule damage.  (SPOILER) That's because they aren't trying to kill your party members, but "detain them" so they follow destiny's line more; it's why they leave immediately after injuring Jessie, as they ensured at that point that Barret will now hire Cloud for the Sector 5 bombing mission compared to the cast holding off previously.

[Godzilla Threshold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodzillaThreshold): The *Compilation* is rife with various [Weapons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Kaiju) for world-class threats, but  (SPOILER) these beings literally exist by the Planet's will because Sephiroth is outright trying to [change history itself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewDestiny). And considering some of the chaos they cause just by running amok in certain scenes, even if only malevolent to those defying fate, they're distinctly more dangerous than the average measure thanks to being able to manipulate things on a human scale instead of just destroying everything.

[Good Colors, Evil Colors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodColorsEvilColors): *Rebirth* further differentiates the Whispers into two colored variants: black and white.  (SPOILER) The black Whispers happen to be under Sephiroth's control while the White Whispers are aligned with the Planet and later Aerith.

[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): Considering the ambiguity of their intentions and how they react to the various events and time divergences, the cast assume they're a greater problem than whatever the heck Sephiroth is doing in the first part's story.  (SPOILER) Turns out that by the standards of [Sephiroth's plans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewDestiny), one could make a case for them constituting a [Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood) of sorts, albeit one that's very antagonistic towards the Avalanche members that were fated to die, forcing Cloud and friends into a direct confrontation with them. Their defeat at the end of part one means that Cloud may have a chance to make things much less bleak in this timeline, but also that Sephiroth could make things much *more* bleak.

[Invisible to Normals](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvisibleToNormals): Aerith is initially the only person who can see them, by virtue of being a Cetra. Cloud next becomes able to see them as well when they touch him, and eventually *everyone* with an important role to play in the world (Barret, Tifa, Red XIII, Rufus, and Sephiroth, specifically) becomes able to see them.

[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony):  (SPOILER) Their purposes is to make sure the plot of the original game happens, but they're essentially [Canon Foreigners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner) who don't exist in the original game.

[Leaning on the Fourth Wall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeaningOnTheFourthWall):  (SPOILER)  They're essentially an embodiment of forces attempting to preserve a purist idea of what a *Final Fantasy VII* remake should be, opposing any changes to the events of the original timeline.

[Life Drain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LifeDrain): Aerith remarks that every time they touch her she feels she's losing "a part of herself." *Rebirth* reveals that they took most of her memories of the future as well as those from her white materia, leaving it blank for much of the story.
[Living Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingShadow): The Arbiters of Fate are spectral entities seemingly made of smoke and shadows, and are invisible to most people.

tropeName: Make Wrong What Once Went Right
tropeNotes: [Make Wrong What Once Went Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakeWrongWhatOnceWentRight): While they ultimately want to  (SPOILER) uphold the plot fated to happen by denying deviations from the story , it means denying *any* possible changes; whatever happens to be more in favor of the heroes' side [is just as subject to their interference](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality) as any advantages the villains might get,  (SPOILER) just because it didn't happen in the original story . That's why they're willing to  (SPOILER) harm and even *kill* characters [destined to die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomedByCanon) .

[Meanwhile, in the Future…](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeanwhileInTheFuture): The destruction of  (SPOILER) the Whisper Harbinger in the present appears to destroy the Arbiters of Fate at every point in time they interfered in . Most significantly,  (SPOILER) this causes Zack to survive his final battle, but it also seems to mean Biggs and Jessie never died either, and likely Wedge as well, [if he died at all](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UncertainDoom).

[Necromancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Necromancer): They can bring people back from the dead.  (SPOILER) In the climax of the storming of the Shinra HQ, Barret is explicitly killed by Sephiroth, but because this would cause things to diverge majorly from the original game's plot, one of the Arbiters immediately begins to resurrect him .

[Oxymoronic Being](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OxymoronicBeing): Their reason for their existence and actions essentially boils down to  (SPOILER) making sure the events of * FF7 * happened as they did . At the same time, they were [never originally part of said plot themselves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony), yet continue to exist and act on anyway.

tropeName: Set Right What Once Went Wrong
tropeNotes: [Set Right What Once Went Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SetRightWhatOnceWentWrong): Their goal is to ensure  (SPOILER) the plot of the original *Final Fantasy VII* goes off without any changes to its eventual conclusion of saving the planet . That means they'll  (SPOILER) interfere with any points that risk deviating from "destiny", such as making sure Cloud and Aerith escape Reno's forces in the church  or  (SPOILER) reviving Barrett after Sephiroth kills him at Shinra Tower.

[Spanner in the Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks): They try to deal with these as they crop up, and frequently act as this themselves. For example,  (SPOILER) Cloud not immediately accepting the next reactor gig causes them to create a stir in the Sector 7 slums just so that Jessie gets hurt in the collateral, forcing him get involved anyway. They also step in to prevent Cloud from killing Reno in a battle that didn't happen originally, repeatedly try to kill Wedge when he survives the Sector Seven plate collapse, make damn sure to whisk Hojo away before he reveals the full truth of Cloud never having been in SOLDIER to begin with, and resurrect Barret when he is killed by Sephiroth, because this could have a major butterfly effect on the rest of the game's plot.

[Take That, Audience!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeThatAudience): The Arbiters basically personify  (SPOILER) *Final Fantasy VII* purists who wanted a remake that has the exact same plot as the original and engineer events throughout the game so it can be achieved. Yet because of this, they are seen mostly as *villains* by the heroes, who don't exactly like being made to do what they don't know. Aerith, in particular, who is implied to have full knowledge of the original game's story, is horrified to learn that she's basically [Doomed by Canon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomedByCanon) to advance the story and convinces the others to defy them, even though it means that Sephiroth's defeat is not inevitable.

[Time Police](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimePolice):  (SPOILER) The Arbiters of Fate seek to enforce that [You Can't Fight Fate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCantFightFate) and intervene to both help and hinder the heroes in order to make sure that the events of *Final Fantasy VII Remake* occur more-or-less as they did in the original *Final Fantasy VII*.

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): While showcased in the trailers and advertising openly, what the Arbiters of Fate are as well as their goals are a major underlying mystery to part one of the story, as they revolve around a major crux of the changes from the original game. Their influence and each major appearance they have is consequently meant to be a big surprise.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist):
    - (SPOILER) While the original events of *Final Fantasy VII* had a good number of tragic deaths and sacrifices, those events are at least guaranteed to save the Planet, although certain sacrifices that provided that guarantee disappear whenever the story goes slightly [Off the Rails](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffTheRails). Fortunately, Sephiroth's [Adaptational Early Appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalEarlyAppearance) counts as derailing, so the Arbiters render him less dangerous than he should be. Less fortunately, people who get [Spared by the Adaptation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SparedByTheAdaptation) *also* count as derailing, which means the Arbiters are constantly trying to kill those survivors off as well as protect the villains who're supposed to be doing the killing. - (SPOILER) The final chapter of *Rebirth* has the White Whispers stall the party from making their way inside the Forgotten Capital to keep Aerith focused on her attempts to pray for Holy.

[World-Healing Wave](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldHealingWave):  (SPOILER) While not an "evil" force damaging the world out of malice, the Arbiters take pains to ensure that people who died in the original story will die *again* in the remake — but when the Arbiters are destroyed, all the people killed by their meddling are retroactively revived. In *Rebirth*, the White Whispers literally invoke this trope during the final battle to help keep the heroes alive.

[You Can't Fight Fate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCantFightFate): They're the ones that actively enforce this, making characters stick to how things went in the original game and acting to keep them in line if they deviate.  (SPOILER) However, it turns out you literally *can* fight fate, and doing so can change history.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): It's not explained how he does it, but he now has the ability to magnetize various scrap to his gun arm, allowing him to swing it like a giant club or else make metal "snakes" that either shoot lasers or try to stab Barret from below the earth.

[Adaptational Heroism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalHeroism): In the original game, Dyne was a nihilist who regularly went on random murderous rampages since he wanted to kill everyone and everything. In this continuity, Dyne at least has enough sanity to direct his [Roaring Rampage of Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge) at Shinra, the true guilty party of his misfortunes. Dyne's shooting spree at the Gold Saucer is changed to a failed assassination attempt on Director Palmer's life. When Barret reunites with him, Dyne is genuinely happy to see his old friend again, and he acts pretty cordial to Barret, albeit while showing clear signs of insanity. Things only get violent when Dyne sees Barret with Cloud, an ex-SOLDIER, and comes to the conclusion that Barret is on Shinra's payroll. During his [Last Stand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastStand), despite his *burning* resentment, he still tackles Barret away from enemy fire and uses his own body to shield him from the bullets; a [Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog) moment completely absent from the original.

[Adaptational Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalNiceGuy): In the original game, when Barret reveals that Marlene actually survived and that he's been taking care of her, Dyne decides to kill her to reunite her with her mother. Here, he just gets even more pissed off at Barret under the delusion that he's kidnapped her. Also, this version of Dyne was initially happy to see Barret again, whereas the original version has nothing but resentment for his old friend.

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): Of "Chapter 8: All That Glitters" in *Rebirth* as Dyne goes on a shooting spree at the Gold Saucer in an attempt to kill Palmer and Barret is blamed for Dyne's crimes. The party's search for the real culprit to clear Barret's name serves as the main focus of the chapter.

[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): All the trauma he's suffered has done a number on his mental state, leaving him a broken shell of the man he once was, prone to outbursts of murderously violent rage.

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): Due to being an [Adaptational Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalNiceGuy), Dyne can be surprisingly friendly despite, or maybe because of his insane state. However, the moment he sees someone who is affiliated with Shinra, or at the very least someone whom Dyne thinks is with Shinra, then all bets are off. Dyne will stop at nothing to kill that person, and he doesn't care how many innocent people he has to go through to get to them.

[Dies Differently in Adaptation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiesDifferentlyInAdaptation): Rather than jump off a cliff to his death after getting his senses knocked back into him for a moment, he instead pulls a [Suicide by Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideByCop) and allows himself to get gunned down by a group of Shinra troops that had tracked him.

[The Dissenter Is Always Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDissenterIsAlwaysRight): He was the only one in Corel who was against letting Shinra build a Mako reactor in their town while the others were blinded by the prospect of more money and energy. He is tragically proven right when the faulty reactor explodes and Shinra slaughters the town to cover it up.
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): Like in the original game Barret decides to fight Dyne in an one-on-one battle without any help from the rest of the party.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Due to his hatred for Shinra, this extends to the SOLDIER group. Upon seeing Cloud, he immediately assumes Barret sold himself to Shinra, not knowing that Cloud is no longer a part of it. He then immediately opens fire to the group, ignoring Barret's pleas.

[Good Scars, Evil Scars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodScarsEvilScars): In another mirror of Barret's injuries Dyne has two scars on the left half of his face. Unlike Barret's much smaller scars Dyne's stretch over the top of his head to his cheek representing his more twisted and broken personality.

[Go Out with a Smile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoOutWithASmile): After succumbing to his wounds and cursing Barret, Dyne then envisions himself returning home to his wife, happily embracing Eleanor while saying he missed her with his final breath.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): Although it was driven by [Suicide by Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideByCop), Dyne uses the last of his strength to protect an unarmed Barret from a squadron of Shinra troopers. Although, with his dying breath he tell Barret to keep living with the guilt of what he has done.

[Shadow Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShadowArchetype): Dyne represents what Barret could have become if he didn't have Marlene to keep him grounded, a man with nothing to live for except for vengeance against Shinra.

[Symbolic Mutilation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SymbolicMutilation): Scarlet shot off his and Barret's hands while the latter was trying to pull up the former, representing Shinra destroying their friendship. The mutilation is symbolically undone in his final moments, where Dyne's gun-arm drops off and he turns so that all remaining shots of him focus instead on his organic arm, representing his recovery of some semblance of his humanity.

[These Hands Have Killed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheseHandsHaveKilled): When Barret tells him Marlene is still alive, Dyne laments that his hands are saturated in blood and that he doesn't want his daughter to see the killer her father's become.

[Tragic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicVillain): Dyne is a mentally unstable and murderously violent man, but if not for Shinra's despicable actions against his village that led to him losing everything and everyone he cared for, he would've been content to simply live out the rest of his days as a humble coal miner and family man.

[We Used to Be Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeUsedToBeFriends): Dyne has nothing but scorn and resentment for Barret now, blaming him for letting Shinra install a Mako reactor in their town and the tragedy that followed it. So much resentment, that when Barret tells him that he saved Marlene and has been taking care of her for years, Dyne just becomes *even more* pissed off, [accusing Barret of stealing Marlene and with her the last reason he had to live, instead of thanking him for saving her.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBastard)

[Weapon Tombstone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaponTombstone): Returning to the battlefield  (SPOILER) shows that Dio did have his body buried, with his gun-arm serving as his tombstone. Symbolically, the gun-arm is pointed down, to show getting it only led to his death .

[Ambiguous Situation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousSituation): It's unclear whether any living members of the Gi Tribe remained when they attacked Cosmo Canyon,  (SPOILER) as Gi Nattak's comments imply they all died a *very* long time ago .

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): Gi Nattak and Bugenhagen frame the Gi Tribe as such,  (SPOILER) having settled in the region of Cosmo Canyon after arriving on the Planet following the destruction of their homeworld, only to find they were [Barred from the Afterlife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarredFromTheAfterlife) after death. Consumed by bitter rage and spite, they stole a sacred materia from the Cetra and corrupted it into the Black Materia to destroy the Planet itself, but were driven deep underground by a war with the Cetra and encroachment into their lands by the ancestors of those who presently live in Cosmo Canyon. Now, only their vengeful spirits remain, lashing out at the descendants of their oppressors and praying that the Black Materia will be returned to them so that they can have peace through oblivion .

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): In the original game, the tribe was merely background lore regarding Red XIII's father Seto, In *Rebirth* they are revealed to also clashed with the Cetra,  (SPOILER)  and created the Black Materia, whose origins were unstated in the original game.

[Barred from the Afterlife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarredFromTheAfterlife): It's revealed that the Gi Tribe were unable to enter the Lifestream after death  (SPOILER) due to being extraterrestrials. When the Cetra refused to intercede with the Planet on their behalf, the Gi Tribe declared war and stole a sacred materia, corrupting it with their nihilistic despair and hatred into the Black Materia .

[Non-Human Undead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonHumanUndead): They are revealed to be  (SPOILER) an ancient race of aliens who came to the Planet during the time of the Cetra, but were barred from entering the Lifestream after death due to not originating from the Planet . By the time the game's story takes place, only their vengeful spirits remain.

tropeName: Put Them All Out of My Misery
tropeNotes: [Put Them All Out of My Misery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PutThemAllOutOfMyMisery):  (SPOILER) As the Gi are trapped on the Planet but didn't originate from it, they're unable to enter the Lifestream and doomed to spend eternity as disembodied spirits. They created the Black Materia to call down Meteor and destroy the Planet entirely, allowing them to fully die even if it takes all other life with them .

[Suicidal Cosmic Temper Tantrum](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicidalCosmicTemperTantrum): With the Gi Tribe being barred from the Lifestream  (SPOILER) due to being extraterrestrials, they created the Black Materia to destroy the planet out of nihilistic spite and hatred towards the Cetra .

[Vengeful Ghost](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VengefulGhost): Being denied access to the Lifestream after death left them bitter and spiteful towards the other species of the Planet,  (SPOILER) such as the Cetra and Red XIII's species .
[Villainous Legacy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousLegacy):  (SPOILER) It is because they created the Black Materia that Sephiroth is able to become a threat to the Planet.

[Artifact Domination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtifactDomination): Her spirit [is bound to the Queen's Blood card patterned after her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SealedEvilInACan), and eventually possesses Regina's body.

[Corrupted Character Copy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptedCharacterCopy): As the spirit of an ancient monarch possessing the body of an ace player of a monster [Card Battle Game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CardBattleGame), and proving shockingly adept at said game for having been dead for centuries, the Shadowblood Queen is one to the Pharaoh from *[Yu-Gi-Oh!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/YuGiOh)*—though unlike him, she is an evil tyrant.

tropeName: The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard
tropeNotes: [The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComputerIsACheatingBastard): Unlike every other Queen's Blood player, the Queen's deck is full of unobtainable cards designed specifically to improve the performance of her own card, which she also always gets to put on the field before the player's first turn.

[The Corruption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCorruption): She uses unique cards that are based on the Summon cards, but all have the effect of de-powering cards in their zones of effect instead of their normal effects.

[Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession): She seeks to corrupt Regina over the course of the Queen's Blood tournament subplot, serving as the final boss after hijacking her body to face off against Cloud.  (SPOILER) After Cloud beats her, the spirit of the Emerald Witch who led the rebellion against her in-life—[also bound to a Queen's Blood card](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SealedGoodInACan)—tries to exorcize her, but fails until Vincent intervenes .

[Fallen Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenHero): According to Lidrehl Balmon's ghost, the Queen was once a kind and benevolent ruler who loved her subjects and was in turn adored by them... until one day she abruptly changed—becoming a ruthless tyrant who saw her subjects as nothing more than fodder for her conquests.

tropeName: God Save Us from the Queen!
tropeNotes: [God Save Us from the Queen!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodSaveUsFromTheQueen): In life, she was a tyrant who ruled over what's now the Gongaga region, until her subjects—led by the Emerald Witch—overthrew and executed her.

[Life Drinker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LifeDrinker): In order to resurrect herself, she's been draining the life force of those who come into possession of her card, mentally dominating them and either driving them insane or outright taking over their bodies before killing them.

[Maker of Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakerOfMonsters): According to legend, the myriad fiends that terrorize the world were [born from her spilled blood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodMagic) when she was executed.

[Outside-Context Problem](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutsideContextProblem): While ghosts are nothing new to the world of  FF7 , the Shadowblood Queen merits special mention for being the only antagonist to try to [Take Over the World](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeOverTheWorld) through a [Card Battle Game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CardBattleGame). She also can't be defeated in a fight, but instead through said card game.

[Sealed Evil in a Can](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SealedEvilInACan): Her disembodied spirit is bound to the one-of-a-kind Queen's Blood card made in her likeness, though she seeks to resurrect herself by possessing the bodies of those who obtain her card and consuming their life-force.  (SPOILER) After being defeated, the Emerald Witch's spirit renders the Shadowblood Queen's inert—signified by green-white chains appearing on the latter's card.
[Terms of Endangerment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TermsOfEndangerment): She snidely refers to Cloud as "little puppet"—demonstrating awareness of Sephiroth's hold over him.

[Vengeful Ghost](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VengefulGhost): Like the spirits of the Gi Tribe, she was [Barred from the Afterlife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarredFromTheAfterlife) and persists as a vengeful spirit seeking to resurrect herself and reclaim her throne.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): The only reason it's remembered in the original is because of its laser tail that would attack the characters if the player struck it in its counter position, as a tutorial on teaching the player about the classic Active Time Battle mechanics. Here? The damn thing goes absolutely *ballistic*, tears up the entire reactor room while bombarding Cloud and Barret with bullets and missiles, has a barrier system, can discharge an  EMP  field, and just when you think it's finally about to kick the bucket, *it has an auto-regenerative emergency mode* that forces players to chop it down to size fast.

[Beware My Stinger Tail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareMyStingerTail): It can fire powerful [energy beams](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyWeapon) from the tip of its tail, forcing the player to hide behind debris. In Hard Mode it will fire it's tail laser attack a second time soon after the first, forcing the player to quickly run into *another* debris for cover.
[Cognizant Limbs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CognizantLimbs): The Scorpion Sentinel's legs can be targeted separately from its main body.

[Deflector Shields](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeflectorShields): In the second phase of the fight, it will activate a barrier system, making it resistant to magic and physical attacks. Attacking it's exposed generator will turn it off.

[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): In the original game, this boss was known as the "Guard Scorpion." In the Japanese version of the remake, its name stays "Guard Scorpion," but in the English version its name is changed.
[EMP](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EMP): The "EM-Field" attack has it releases an electric wave into the floor as an [Area of Effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AreaOfEffect) attack.

[Grapple Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrappleMove): The "Death Grip" attack has it swiping its claw to grab a character, holding them in the air while charging it's "[Stinger Salvo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyWeapon)" attack at point-blank range. It will lose his grip on the character if dealt enough damage.
[In a Single Bound](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InASingleBound): It will jump high into the air when maneuvering around the arena.
[Macross Missile Massacre](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MacrossMissileMassacre): The "Mark 99 Launchers" attack has it firing out a salvo of small missiles.
[Regenerating Health](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RegeneratingHealth): It activates an auto-repair unit that regenerates it's health in the final phase, turning the fight into a DPS race.
[Spider Tank](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiderTank): The Scorpion Sentinel, as its name suggests, is a scorpion-shaped mech armed with a variety of powerful weapons.

[Wake-Up Call Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WakeUpCallBoss): In the playable demo, this boss is rather challenging. Players are encouraged to swap party members at certain times and memorize the Scorpion's attack patterns in order to avoid them. In the full game, this boss is still challenging but a little bit less punishing compared to the demo  (SPOILER) unless you are playing on [Hard Mode](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NewGamePlus) .
[Degraded Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DegradedBoss): Can later be fought in Chapter 9 & 14 in the Corneo Colosseum as an optional battle.
[Elites Are More Glamorous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElitesAreMoreGlamorous): His armor and shield are considerably more glamorous than the average Shinra Trooper.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): He's accompanied by several Shinra soldiers during his boss fight.
[King Mook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KingMook): He's a boss version of the [Shinra Riot Trooper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShieldBearingMook) with more powerful attacks, higher defense, and grenades.

[Lawman Baton](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LawmanBaton): An elite member of Shinra's Public Security force that wields a stun baton as a weapon, which is capable of [stunning his target](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParalyzer).

tropeName: Luckily, My Shield Will Protect Me
tropeNotes: [Luckily, My Shield Will Protect Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LuckilyMyShieldWillProtectMe): His tower shield protects him against frontal attacks. Cloud has to resort to magic, [Counter-Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CounterAttack) or attacking him from the rear to damage him.
[Mook Lieutenant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MookLieutenant): He serves as a unit commander for the Shinra troops in the Sector 8 town area.
[Shield Bash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShieldBash): His most common attack is a shield bash.
[Stern Chase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SternChase): He leads Shinra's Public Security efforts in capturing Cloud in Sector 8.
[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): The first Shinra mech boss that was absent from the original.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): It has an attack that electrifies the train tracks to deal heavy lightning elemental damage.
[Spider Tank](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiderTank): It's a crab-like tank mecha with four legs and a pair of arm-mounted machine gun turrets.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): In the original game, the Airbuster was something of a pushover once you managed to lock its movement, and wasn't much of a challenge. Here, if the player doesn't go out of their way to sabotage its development, it lives up to its designation and is sickeningly powerful. Even diminishing its capabilities still results in a hell of a fight, as well.

[Battleship Raid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleshipRaid): Played with, as the Airbuster is under-construction as Cloud, Barrett, and Tifa attack the Sector 5 Mako Reactor, and they can sabotage its construction in order to weaken it.

[Boring, but Practical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoringButPractical): Towards the end of the fight, the Airbuster gets the idea to simply fly away from the fight and take to long-range battle. Your only hope of even hitting him at that point is Barret and any lightning materia you thought to equip beforehand while it still retains its powerful payload.

[Boss-Altering Consequence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossAlteringConsequence): By gathering key cards scattered throughout the control rooms, you can alter how often the Airbuster uses certain attacks depending on which terminal you use.
[Chest Blaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChestBlaster): It can fire powerful energy beams from its chest-mounted power core.
[Detachment Combat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DetachmentCombat): One of the Airbuster's many new tricks is the ability to detach its arms from its body and use them as independent attack drones.
[Finger Firearms](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FingerFirearms): It can fire lasers from its fingertips, and which inflict the stun status effect.
[Homing Lasers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HomingLasers): Airbuster's shoulders house laser cannons that fire a scattershot upward before raining down on the battlefield.
[Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mecha): Airbuster is a prototype flight-capable combat mech with a wide array of powerful weapons.
[Ridiculously Potent Explosive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RidiculouslyPotentExplosive): Its Big Bomber units are described as being capable of wiping out entire armies.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): The original incarnation of the Airbuster was already visually similar to the Zeong from *[Mobile Suit Gundam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/MobileSuitGundam)*. The new version leans into the comparison much harder, giving the Airbuster the Zeong's signature detachable arms and [Finger Firearms](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FingerFirearms).
[Super Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperPrototype): It is a prototype mech constructed with the intent of slaying giant monsters.
[Time-Limit Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeLimitBoss): Although the timer is very generous, there *is* a limit to how long the boss fight can run before Mako Reactor 5 explodes.

[Walking Armory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingArmory): Electrical fields around its waist, two cannons on its back, [Finger Firearms](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FingerFirearms), a [Chest Blaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChestBlaster), waist-launched bombs, flamethrowers in its palms, [Homing Lasers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HomingLasers) in its shoulders, and electrical punches.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): In the original *Final Fantasy VII* it was a regular but powerful [Giant Mook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantMook) that could be fought in the slums, but in the *Remake* it's a boss fought in the Corneo Colosseum.

[Adaptational Late Appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalLateAppearance): In the original game, it appeared in the Sector 6 Slums. Here, it appears in the Corneo Colosseum, after the slums have been passed through.

[Artistic License – Engineering](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtisticLicenseEngineering): [Played for Laughs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayedForLaughs) by the announcers, whose many lines include wondering if the Hell House's architect had "one too many" when designing it.
[Barrier Change Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarrierChangeBoss): It periodically changes its elemental weakness and absorption along with its elemental attacks.
[Beehive Barrier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeehiveBarrier): It's capable of generating a tessellated force field to protect itself from damage.

[Giant Space Flea from Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantSpaceFleaFromNowhere): There's absolutely no foreshadowing its appearance, with the only thing preceding it being Corneo suddenly demanding an extra battle in the Colosseum. When assessed, it's noted that nobody knows how it was built.
[Haunted House](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HauntedHouse): It's a creepy mech with the motif of a haunted house.

[Have a Nice Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HaveANiceDeath): Unlike every other boss in the game, losing to the Hell House causes Scotch and Kotch to *keep commenting* on the Game Over screen, bemoaning Cloud and Aerith's demise.

[Inexplicably Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InexplicablyAwesome): A huge robotic monster in the shape of a house with house-themed abilities, missiles in the shape of chairs, its [Beehive Barrier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeehiveBarrier) that's able to change weaknesses and its amazingly-titled *God House Mode* [all come with little to no explanation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItRunsOnNonsensoleum). Besides bringing a ridiculous and flashy end to Cloud and Aerith's time at the Colosseum, of course.
[Macross Missile Massacre](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MacrossMissileMassacre): One of its main attacks is firing volleys of chair-shaped missiles.
[Mechanical Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechanicalAbomination): It's played up as such, with even its dossier noting that its inner workings are a complete mystery.

[Mysterious Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousPast): How, where, when and why it was built, and how Corneo got his hands on it, are never elaborated upon. Same goes for its inner workings and technology. All it's known for is being the Don's secret weapon.
[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): In the second stage of its battle a face pops out the front, arms from its roof, and rocket boosters from its back end.

[Refuge in Audacity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RefugeInAudacity): The original game's Hell House was a unique and bizarre enemy, a sentient house who could attack you. The remake embraces the absurdity and ramps it up, making Hell House a robot built into the shape of a small house, which can launch chairs as missiles as an attack, project a barrier to defend itself, suck a character into itself to pummel them inside and has other abilities like House Call and Housing Rush, all while Corneo's henchman commentators continuously make awful house-related puns. The game is fully aware of how insane the enemy is and lampshades it endlessly.
[Those Magnificent Flying Machines](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThoseMagnificentFlyingMachines): It's able to fly around the arena using rocket propulsion and eventually sprouts thrusters on its back.
[Turns Red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnsRed): After taking enough damage, the Hell House shifts from its standard "concealed" form into its true Hell House form.

[Wake-Up Call Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WakeUpCallBoss): It's plausible on Normal difficulty to make your way up to this fight by just mostly dealing physical damage, raising Stagger meters and hitting with weaknesses where applicable. The Hell House then demands that the player watches the fight and *strategizes very carefully* to be able to stand a snowball's chance in hell of winning without bumping down the difficulty. Similarly, on Hard mode you may have gotten by without changing their character build or worrying about using too much MP in the chapter before reaching the boss - Hell House marks the point where the player needs to plan what materia they’ll need to use in advance, and needs to ration their MP use throughout the chapter to avoid going into the boss battle with a drastically diminished ability to cast spells.
[Walking Tank](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingTank): How it's designed and acts, being a quadrepedal *house* with heavy weaponry and thrusters.
[Adaptation Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationNameChange): His name was [transliterated](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlternateCharacterReading) as "Aps" in the original game.

[Dies Differently in Adaptation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiesDifferentlyInAdaptation): In the original game, Cloud, Aerith, and Tifa kill him. In *Remake*, it flees after they defeat it, crashing through a wall and providing the trio with an escape route. It returns alongside its offspring in Chapter 14 to save Don Corneo from Leslie and Avalanche, and is defeated again by the party.  (SPOILER) In *Rebirth* Abzu shows up again alongside Don Corneo and despite getting another beating, has enough strength to make an exit afterwards .

[Fed to the Beast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FedToTheBeast): Don Corneo keeps it as a pet, and feeds it the women he takes as his "brides" once he's done having his way with them. Cloud, Aerith, and Tifa end up being dropped into its sewer-based lair, forcing them to fight it.
[Heroic Build](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBuild): Despite its otherwise monstrous features, its actually possesses one of these, and will even strike a pose or two during battle to show it off.
