[It Can Think](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItCanThink): Its Assess materia dossier notes that while it may look like a grotesquely ugly beast, it's deceptively intelligent.  (SPOILER) It's smart enough to play dead when defeated, even using the defeat in the Colosseum as a pretense to save his master .

[Monster Is a Mommy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MonsterIsAMommy): Despite being referred to with male pronouns, it has a plethora of progeny prowling the sewers. One shoat happens to be smarter than the rest, and has a nasty sense of humor.

[Not Quite Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotQuiteDead):  (SPOILER) Is seemingly killed by the party during the second fight in *Remake* - *Rebirth* reveals that he is alive and well (he sports the same broken horns like before), and fights the party inside the Musclehead Colosseum with Don Corneo as his rider.
[Religious and Mythological Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReligiousAndMythologicalThemeNaming): Abzu is named after the primordial sea that exists below the Underworld in Sumerian mythology.

[Scars are Forever](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScarsAreForever): Any crippling damage you've done on Abzu (either one of its horns) stays that way after it flees  (SPOILER) and then fight again for a rematch later. In *Rebirth* both horns are broken and the tail gone .
[Fusion Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FusionDance): It is an amalgam of numerous ghosts, which fuse together to have some "fun" with Cloud, Tifa, and Aerith.

[Mana Drain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManaDrain): Its Etheric Drain skill has it grab Aerith and drain her MP to power up its next skill, Etheric Burst, where it releases the MP in a short-ranged explosion.

[Mind over Matter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindOverMatter): It can telekinetically lift objects and throw them around. It will periodically use its telekinesis to rearrange the objects in the room to make navigating it harder.

[Not Evil, Just Misunderstood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotEvilJustMisunderstood): While it and its constituent ghosts frequently harass and attack Cloud, Tifa, and Aerith, they're more lonely and bored than anything and just want to play.

[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): It can conjure spectral flames to attack its opponents. One of its normal attacks is to swipe the ground and send out a wave of blue flame, and its Balefire skill has it summon spectral flames to act as mines.
[Stance System](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StanceSystem): It can shift between corporeal and incorporeal states, respectively rendering magic and physical attacks useless against it.

[Super-Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperScream): Its Piercing Scream skill, which is [Exactly What It Says on the Tin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactlyWhatItSaysOnTheTin). It will stun any character that's too close to it.
[Undead Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndeadChild): The ghosts it is comprised of are all the spirits of children who were abducted and killed by Eligor.
[Weaksauce Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaksauceWeakness): [Healing magic and items cause it damage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReviveKillsZombie), as befitting an undead enemy.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): Single-handedly responsible for the Train Graveyard's dangerous reputation, Eligor condemns lost children into becoming malevolent spirits. It's implied to have a high body count. [An interview](https://na.finalfantasy.com/topics/205) even confirmed that Eligor battles the party because (SPOILER) it foresaw the disturbance in the Lifestream which would result from the Sector 7 Plate collapse and tried to prevent them from saving it, meaning it possessed a level of precognition otherwise only seen in the Arbiters, Aerith, and Sephiroth. Not bad for what used to be a common enemy.
[Anti-Regeneration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiRegeneration): In Hard mode, Eligor will also cast Reflect on the party as well which will redirect any beneficial spells to himself including Cure.

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): Of "Chapter 11: Haunted" in *Remake.* This being serve as the main obstacle to the heroes as they to navigate out of the haunted train graveyard and back to the Sector 7 slums.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): It was a normal enemy in the original game, fought as a [Giant Mook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantMook) in random encounters in the Train Graveyard. Now it's a boss.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): Its Winds of Gehenna skill has it fire a black wind from its halberd.

[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): It manipulates a dark spectral energy, conjuring tornadoes of black wind and shrouding its would-be victims in darkness to heighten their fear.
[Cyborg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cyborg): It is a cyborg-like ghost resembling a rider and horse with gears and wheels for hind legs, and the rider portion having a glowing red robotic eye.
[Devil's Pitchfork](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DevilsPitchfork): Wields a sinister halberd as its primary weapon.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): This creature has reached urban legend proportion. Marlene tells Tifa of the tale of the Black Wind that takes people away, to be trapped in the Train Graveyard forever.
[Emotion Eater](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmotionEater): It is sustained by the fear of its victims.

[Evil Can Not Comprehend Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCanNotComprehendGood): It shows Tifa a vision of Marlene, unaware that it would just make her go [Mama Bear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MamaBear) instead of despairing.
[Eye Beams](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyeBeams): Its Piercing Gaze and Sweeping Gaze skills have it fire red lasers from its eye.
[Javelin Thrower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JavelinThrower): Its Javelin Bolts skill has it rain down electrified copies of its halberd.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Eligor in the original game was notable for having the Striking Staff for Aerith as a stealable weapon, as the Striking Staff is a much more powerful weapon for her normally not available until Junon. Here, the Eligor has the Bladed Staff (which is based in appearance on the Striking Staff) as a stealable item, but this time it's the only way to acquire it at all.

[Nigh-Invulnerable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NighInvulnerable): Like the ghost enemies in the area, Eligor can make himself immune to physical attacks and alternately he can also reflect spells used against him.
[Ninja Pirate Robot Zombie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NinjaPirateRobotZombie): It's an undead cyborg charioteer.

[Punched Across the Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunchedAcrossTheRoom):  (SPOILER)  A dying Eligor is the victim of the kick equivalent. Tifa jumps up to him and does her Sommersault directly at his head. This smashes him through piles of shipping crates and through the wall surrounding the compound.

[Religious and Mythological Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReligiousAndMythologicalThemeNaming): Named after a demon from the [Ars Goetia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/ArsGoetia) described as a ghostly knight riding on a decaying horse.
[Tulpa](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Tulpa): In its description, it was formed from the memories of all the suffering that happened in the Train Graveyard.

[Unique Items](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UniqueItems): Eligor is the only enemy in the game with a truly unique stealable item, the Bladed Staff. Every other enemy has items that can be found or even bought elsewhere (some of these items are almost unique though, such as the Iron Maiden which can only be found once and a 2nd copy stolen from the M.O.T.H Unit.)

[Villain of Another Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainOfAnotherStory): This thing has captured and killed many children over the years and is the reason the Train Graveyard is the haunted hellhole it is. Cloud, Tifa, and Aerith only go through its territory to get back to the Sector 7 slums and kill it because it gets in their way.
[Would Hurt a Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldHurtAChild): It abducts children to prey off their fear until they die and become the ghosts haunting the Train Graveyard.
[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): The Failed Experiment and Unknown entities were completely absent from prior installments in the *Compilation of Final Fantasy VII*.
[Combat Tentacles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatTentacles): Unlike its lesser brethren, which only have one tentacle, it has four tentacles protruding from its back.
[Escaped from the Lab](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EscapedFromTheLab): The collapse of the Sector 7 plate enabled it and its kindred to escape from the stasis tanks they were being held in.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): It has an attack called Livewire, in which it discharges electrical blasts after pounding its chest.  (SPOILER) This invokes another unfortunate victim of Hojo's experiments: Vincent Valentine. Vincent's Death Gigas transformation has the same attack.

[Gone Horribly Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoneHorriblyRight): It was once a test-subject in Shinra's Deepground experiments, which turned it and the Unknown Entities that accompany it into monsters. Despite having been deemed failures, it and its lesser brethren are still highly effective and dangerous combatants.
[Grievous Harm with a Body](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrievousHarmWithABody): It can grab, electrify, and throw its lesser brethren at its opponents.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): It primarily uses electrical attacks to stun its prey.

[Was Once a Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WasOnceAMan): Following its defeat, it's revealed that the Failed Experiment and its lesser kindred are cognates of the makonoids from the original game, being the result of  (SPOILER) Professor Hojo abducting civilians and infusing them with mako and Jenova cells until they mutate into monsters .
[Wolfpack Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WolfpackBoss): It's fought alongside a swarm of similar smaller creatures, which it can throw at Barret and Tifa or absorb to heal itself.

[Adaptational Early Appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalEarlyAppearance): Behemoths were encountered far later in the original game, during the raid on the Midgar Cannon. This one is found during the first run through Midgar.
[Counter-Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CounterAttack): If hit with magic while the horns are intact, it will retaliate with its Counter Flare skill, conjuring an explosion.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): It is a legendary monster, and even other monsters are terrified of it. Even Shinra’s science division are afraid of it, as it’s sealed in a separate room with the door covered in security tape warning any unsuspecting soul not to open the door.
[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): It can be heard shortly after Barret, Cloud & Tifa are separated in Chapter 13.
[Horn Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HornAttack): One of its main means of offense is using its massive horns to ram and toss opponents.
[Mighty Roar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyRoar): It can be heard yowling throughout in Chapter 13, and its Enemy Intel dossier notes other monsters are terrified of its roar.
[Panthera Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PantheraAwesome): It's a massive beast resembling a panther with a fin on its back and bull-like horns.
[Volcanic Veins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VolcanicVeins): Its body is covered in glowing red markings which [intensify as it powers up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnsRed).

[Degraded Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DegradedBoss): Hell House on Hard mode can periodically summon a group of three Tonberries. Whilst they’re as lethal as ever, they have significantly less health than the one fought in Sector 5.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): Despite its adorable appearance, it is a powerful and extremely dangerous monster. Corneo's thugs wisely choose to stay out of its way when it fights Cloud's party, and immediately surrender upon its defeat.

[Implacable Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImplacableMan): It has a load of health and is extremely difficult to Stagger. Unless it is Staggered or defeated, it does not flinch or get knocked down from any of the party's attacks.
[One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill): Its knife attacks one-shot anyone they hit. It can also use two spells called "Tantrum" and "Doom and Gloom" that do the same thing.
[Pintsized Powerhouse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PintsizedPowerhouse): Small as a moogle, but can one-hit ko anyone.
[The Slow Walk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSlowWalk): As true to form and [ominous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ominouswalk) as ever.
[Teleportation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Teleportation): To make up for its slow walking speed, it sometimes teleports around the battlefield.
[Time Stands Still](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeStandsStill): It likes to cast Stop on the party, leaving them helpless as it slowly walks up to them to stab them.

[Adaptational Early Appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalEarlyAppearance): In the original game, it appeared as Barret, Aerith and Red XIII took the elevator to the ground floor in Shinra Tower, attacking immediately after the Hundred Gunner fell. Here, it instead attacks Cloud, Tifa and Barret as they make their way across the ruins of the Sector 7 plate to the Shinra Tower.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): In Japanese, it retains the name Heli Gunner from the original *Final Fantasy VII*.
[More Dakka](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreDakka): It's armed with a pair of massive rotary cannons, and can also fire grenades.

[Taking You with Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingYouWithMe): Self-destructs in defeat. Being that the boss battle takes place amidst  (SPOILER) the ruins of Sector 7 , this is more effective (if equally as unsuccessful) than the Airbuster’s attempt.
[Arm Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmCannon): Its left arm is a radial mouth that acts as a projectile weapon.
[Cthulhumanoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cthulhumanoid): It is a towering humanoid abomination with a tentacled head.
[Enemy Summoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemySummoner): It spawns little spider-legged eyeball-monsters called  H0521-OPTs  to fight alongside it.
[Goal-Oriented Evolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoalOrientedEvolution): Its dossier states that it evolves through combat to become more efficient at killing enemies.
[Too Many Mouths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooManyMouths): It has grotesque [Lamprey Mouths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampreyMouth) on its left arm and right shoulder.
[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): In the original, it was an easily-dispatched regular enemy in a random encounter. Here, it's a boss battle.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): In the original *Final Fantasy VII*, it was a basic enemy found in the Shinra Headquarters after Jenova escapes. Now it's a full-fledged boss battle.
[Me's a Crowd](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MesACrowd): Spawns several clones of itself for the second half of the boss fight.

[Nightmare Face](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightmareFace): Unlike the Brain Pod from the original *Final Fantasy VII* which had a goofy-looking head within, this one's face is a nightmarish, techno-organic one.
[Poisonous Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoisonousPerson): Discharges toxic waste that deals damage over time to those standing in it.
[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): In the original, it was an easily-dispatched regular enemy in a random encounter. Here, it's a full-fledged boss battle.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): In the original *Final Fantasy VII* it was a basic enemy found in the Shinra Headquarters. Now it's a full-fledged boss battle, and much larger in size.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): Was called Sword Dance in the original *Final Fantasy VII*, and retains this name in the Japanese version.
[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss): The first half of the battle has Cloud and Barret combat it, after which it retreats to the area where Tifa, Aerith, and Red XIII are.
[Spin Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpinAttack): Several of its attacks involve spinning and using its bladed body like a buzzsaw.

[Adaptational Early Appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalEarlyAppearance): While itself a [Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner), it comes from a batch of several similar Jenova forms that were originally first encountered on the ship to Costa del Sol.

[Adaptational Superpower Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalSuperpowerChange): Its existence is one for Sephiroth and Jenova; whereas in the core game all the Sephiroth [Body Doubles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyDouble) were pieces of Jenova, here it's an illusion created by a Sephiroth Clone.

[Black Eyes of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackEyesOfEvil): Has a pair of jet-black eyes deep in its skull sockets. Also doubles as a subtle nod to *[The Thing (1982)](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/TheThing1982)*, where in the 1982 version of the film a frequent hint as to which human was infected by the Thing were pitch-black eyes.
[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): The only bosses who attacked you when fleeing Shinra headquarters were Shinra-aligned mechs, let alone a minion of Sephiroth's.

[Combat Tentacles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatTentacles): Jenova Dreamweaver has a pair of tentacles protruding from its lower body, and in the second stage of its boss fight can project tentacles through the portals that open in the floor to attack foes keeping their distance.

[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): Called "Jenova Beat" (as in heart beat) in Japan, tying into the [Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming) of Birth, Life and Death of the similarly-shaped Jenova-forms in the original game.

[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): It is a monstrous incarnation of Jenova, appearing as a grotesquely twisted pillar of flesh and tentacles that has corrupted the terrain around it.

[Master of Illusion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfIllusion): It is stated to have the ability to create potent hallucinations, causing the party to perceive a cavern with pillars of crystalized mako.

[Meat Moss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeatMoss): The arena in which it's fought is a Cetra cavern deep in the Planet, with pillars of crystalized mako covered by pulsating tendrils of Jenova's biomass. In the third stage of the fight, gobs of corrosive ooze drip off the ceiling.
[No Body Left Behind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoBodyLeftBehind): After it's defeated its body turns into that of a Sephiroth Clone and disappears into wisps of darkness.
[Shattering the Illusion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShatteringTheIllusion): Killing it shatters the illusory world it creates, and kills the Sephiroth Clone that conjured it.
[Skull for a Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkullForAHead): Jenova Dreamweaver has fanged skull for a face, with a pair of mandibles where its lower jaw should be.

[Your Mind Makes It Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YourMindMakesItReal): While Red XIII tells the team that Jenova Dreamweaver — or at least the arena it creates — is merely an illusion and to stay calm, it's still capable of injuring the team.
[Arm Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmCannon): Its left arm is a rotary cannon made of smaller rotary cannons, and its right arm is a powerful plasma cannon.
[Chest Blaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChestBlaster): Like the Airbuster, it can fire powerful energy beams from its torso-mounted core.
[Corridor Cubbyhole Run](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorridorCubbyholeRun): Several of its attacks are very powerful, but the player can use the pillars around the area to hide from said attacks.

[Desperation Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperationAttack): When it's on its last legs it will become immobile and only use the [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) Cry Havoc as an attack.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): Was called Hundred Gunner in the original *Final Fantasy VII*, which it retains in the Japanese original.
[Homing Lasers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HomingLasers): Its Obliterating laser attack fires a massive volley of energy beams that home in on their target.
[Humongous Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumongousMecha): It's a massive tank-like mech that chases Barret, Aerith, and Red XIII through the Shinra HQ.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag):
    - It first makes its appearance in the lift where Barret, Aerith and Red XIII are in, just like in the original game, although it is no longer fought on the elevator. - Cry Havoc's 9999 surefire damage attack is reminiscent of the Weapons' Light Pillar attack from *[Final Fantasy VIII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVIII)*.

[One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill): When it's on its last legs, it will charge up a massive [Beam Spam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeamSpam) attack called Cry Havoc. Anyone caught in the open will take [9999 damage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cap), and it will also destroy cover (but the character behind will be safe).

[Shoot the Medic First](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheMedicFirst): In the first phase of the fight, it's protected by three Barrier Drones that put up an invincible shield on it, and they need to be taken down in order to make the boss vulnerable.
[Tank Goodness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TankGoodness): It's a four-barreled tank-like mech with a rotary cannon and a plasma cannon for "arms".

[Time-Limit Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeLimitBoss): In its final phase, it will repeatedly charge up and unleash a [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) [Beam Spam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeamSpam) attack that instakills anyone not behind cover and destroys any cover it hits, meaning that you need to destroy it *quickly* before it causes a [Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill).
[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Its name is only included in supplemental material, such as the art book included with the deluxe edition.

[Fire-Breathing Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireBreathingWeapon): Armed with four torso-mounted flamethrowers, which it uses in conjunction with its [rotating torso](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbnormalLimbRotationRange).
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): Was called Motor Ball in the original *Final Fantasy VII*, which it retains in the Japanese version.
[Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mecha): One of the largest of Shinra's mechs, sporting a humanoid torso atop six massive spiked wheels.

[No Name Given](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNameGiven): No name appears above its health bar and it doesn’t appear in the Enemy Intel page on the menu screen, as Cloud can’t use materia whilst driving and thus cannot use Assess to view the enemy’s weakness.

[Shielded Core Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShieldedCoreBoss): To damage it, Cloud needs to deplete the health bars on all its wheels, causing it to become vulnerable to damage for a short while before it repairs its wheels again.

[Vehicular Combat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VehicularCombat): Chases the remnants of Avalanche as they flee Midgar, with Cloud fighting it from his motorcycle and Barret from the back of a stolen truck. This is in contrast to the original game, where it was fought as a standard-gameplay boss fight only after the motorcycle mini-game sequence was already completed.

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual):
    - The official Ultimania guide to *Remake* makes it explicit that Rubrum, Viridi, and Croceo use the same weapons and fighting styles as Kadaj, Loz, and Yazoo from *[Advent Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/FinalFantasyVIIAdventChildren)*. - The score for the remake also identifies the piece that plays when the Whisper Harbinger (and the three sub-bosses) reveal themselves as "Arbiter of Fate - *Advent*". This appears to be a further reference that the enemies are tied in some fashion to the preceding anime.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): The Whispers are not actually the real enemy whatsoever, but the heroes firmly believe otherwise and think each of the visions given to them are some sort of bad future.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): Its Correction skill has it conjure a massive wind to blow the party away.

[Call-Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallBack):
    - Rubrum, Viridi, and Croceo's weapons, fighting styles, move names and summoning of Bahamut all reference the three Remnants of Sephiroth — Kadaj, Loz, and Yazoo — from the *[Advent Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/FinalFantasyVIIAdventChildren)* sequel film. - In the Japanese version, one of Croceo's special moves is named "Velvet Nightmare" - a reference to the nickname of Yazoo's primary weapon from the same film.
[Climax Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClimaxBoss): The second-to-last boss faced in the main story, followed by  (SPOILER) the battle with Sephiroth .
[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): If it won, it would effectively have saved the world by ensuring the timeline where Sephiroth is defeated remains intact.

[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): It is an amalgam of countless Whispers, connected to all the threads of the space-time continuum. Barret even lampshades how it's more worthy of being called an arbiter of fate than the individual Whispers are.

[Enemy Summoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemySummoner): It summons a trio of lesser Whisper entities — [Rubrum](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BladeBelowTheShoulder), [Croceo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmCannon), and [Viridi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerFist) — to dispose of Avalanche.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): Subverted. Initially, its three apparitions appear to be this to our heroes (Rubrum is a counterpart to Cloud, having a massive [BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS); Croceo is a counterpart to Barret, having a pair of [Arm Cannons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmCannon); and Viridi is a counterpart to Tifa, having a massive mace-like fist). However Rubrum's sword is thin and wielded in his left arm, Croceo has two arm cannons rather than a single gun and Viridi rather than boxing has a single enlarged fist. As confirmed in the Ultimania, this is because they are in fact more closely tied to the three Remnants of Sephiroth. Kadaj was a left-handed katana wielder, Yazoo used two handguns, and Loz fought with a pile bunker. They are also all linked elementally: Kadaj used fire magic, Yazoo wind, and Loz lightning. In fusing into Bahamut, they also call back to the summoning of Bahamut  SIN .

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): The fact that the Harbinger's apparitions are based off of the Remnants of Sephiroth seems to be completely out of left field, as taking the form of an enemy to the Planet should be the *last thing* the Whispers would be doing. Come *Rebirth*,  (SPOILER) we find out the Black-robed Whispers of Fate are actually under Sephiroth's influence, versus the White-robed ones that appear in that game to oppose them. If this is retroactive for *Remake*, it means the Harbinger was potentially one elaborate [Batman Gambit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BatmanGambit) by Sephiroth to produce a false villain so the heroes would make changing the world easier for him.

[Fusion Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FusionDance):
    - The Whisper Harbinger is formed of countless Whispers merging together into a colossal entity. - At the third stage of the boss fight, Rubrum, Croceo, and Viridi amalgamate into [Whisper Bahamut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DraconicAbomination).
[Gem Tissue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GemTissue): Rubrum is partially comprised of red crystal, Croceo of yellow crystal, and Viridi of blue crystal.

[Godzilla Threshold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodzillaThreshold): The Whispers were already the Planet's response to Sephiroth attempting to [Screw Destiny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewDestiny), but the Harbinger is essentially a [Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Kaiju) in all but name in its last-ditch attempts to prevent history from being distorted.

[Non-Malicious Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonMaliciousMonster): It just wants to preserve the future where the Planet's survival is guaranteed, and repeatedly attempts to talk down the party by showing them visions of the original future.
[No-Sell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSell): It's completely immune to being directly attacked, and can only be damaged through attacking Rubrum, Croceo, and Viridi.

[Poor Communication Kills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoorCommunicationKills): What ends up causing its demise. If the cast could realize that what they saw in the [Psychic Dreams for Everyone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychicDreamsForEveryone) were not *inherently* a bad thing (though it would require  (SPOILER) Aerith's death  as per the original timeline), not to mention Sephiroth luring them into this distrust and situation to begin with, this entire battle wouldn't need to happen. And with its death comes a theoretical [new cavalcade of problems](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero).

[Psychic Dreams for Everyone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychicDreamsForEveryone): It inflicts visions of the future as it should be on the party, attempting to get them to give up on changing it. Unfortunately, the visions it shows are of things like [Meteor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ApocalypseHow), so they don't listen.
[Psycho Rangers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoRangers): Rubrum, Croceo, and Viridi have similar fighting styles to Kadaj, Yazoo, and Loz, respectively.
[Reality Warper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealityWarper): It creates a hurricane of darkness containing chunks of rubble copied from pieces of Midgar.

tropeName: Set Right What Once Went Wrong
tropeNotes: [Set Right What Once Went Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SetRightWhatOnceWentWrong): Rubrum, Croceo, and Viridi's Enemy Intel profiles state they're from a future timeline that they're fighting to preserve.

[Adaptational Early Appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalEarlyAppearance): In the original game, Malboros didn’t appear until the start of the second disc & on a completely different continent. Whilst it doesn’t appear outside of the Battle Simulator, it’s still far earlier than in the original game.
[Adaptational Wimp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalWimp): Despite being upgraded to an actual boss, it's actually easier to defeat than its original * FFVII * incarnation.
[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): It was a normal enemy in the original *Final Fantasy VII*, but in the *Remake* it's a boss.
[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): Its signature Bad Breath attack has it exhale a noxious spray of red acid from its maw, inflicting numerous status effects.
[Man-Eating Plant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManEatingPlant): It's a monstrous plant-like monster with thick vine-like tentacles and a gaping fang-lined maw.

tropeName: More Teeth than the Osmond Family
tropeNotes: [More Teeth than the Osmond Family](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreTeethThanTheOsmondFamily): It has a gaping maw lined with hundreds of fangs.

[Nerf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Nerf): Its Bad Breath attack is nowhere near as dangerous as it was in the original game; it's unlikely to hit more than one of your party members, the statuses it inflicts can now wear off with time, and it can be avoided by simply running behind the Malboro when it attempts to use it.

[Tentacled Terror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TentacledTerror): It's a nightmarish plant-like monster with a gaping fang-lined maw and body bristling in [Combat Tentacles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatTentacles).
[Waddling Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaddlingHead): It is a massive set of jaws with eyestalks on top and tentacles on the bottom.

[Adaptational Early Appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalEarlyAppearance): Technically just a prototype of the actual Proudclod, and as a virtual reality program it doesn't physically exist, but it appears well before the battle for the mako cannon the original one was used in.

[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): The Japanese version calls it "Proud Clad Unit Zero", Proud Clad being the correct version of the original *Final Fantasy VII* mistranslation.

[Early-Bird Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EarlyBirdCameo): A partially constructed version of the mech can be seen during the second chapter of “ INTERmission ” as Yuffie & Sonon make their way through Shinra’s Advanced Weapons lab. The size of it is quite a bit bigger then the Prototype and may be the in-development Proudclod itself.
[Energy Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyWeapon): It's most powerful attack are the two [Shoulder Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoulderCannon) lasers.
[Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mecha): It's a little smaller than the Arsenal but it's still the most powerful Shinra mech in-game.

[Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier): Not winning any marathons but hits like a runaway tank and harder to put down. It gets faster when it [Turns Red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnsRed).

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag):
    - The name of the boss is a reference to what Heidegger and Scarlet referred to the Proud Clod as: the Pride and Joy of Shinra. - The Proudclod dropped Cloud's second strongest sword, the Ragnarok. The reward it drops is named after the translation of Ragnarok into German.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): It is only available to fight on hard mode after facing all other VR challenges along with all the Corneo Colosseum challenges.
[Super Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperPrototype): A virtual reality recreation of a currently discontinued Shinra weapon.
[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): The Gigantipede mech was completely absent from prior installments in the *Compilation of Final Fantasy VII*.
[Arm Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmCannon): Its cannon configuration gives it two Makocannons on its arms.
[Attack Its Weak Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackItsWeakPoint): Attacking Scarlet will force the Crimson Mare into the Pressured state.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): The sword and shield configuration gives it a Claymore the length of the mech to fight with.
[Blade Spam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BladeSpam): Its Fulgent Blade attack has it energize its Claymore with Mako energy and perform six powerful slashes.

[Boss-Altering Consequence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossAlteringConsequence): In *Rebirth*, you can destroy the Mark II's arms, changing it's attach patterns accordingly. Starting out with twin swords and relentless slashing attacks, destroying those has it equip canon arms, allowing it to bombard you at mid-range. Destroying *those* causes it to equip close-range boring instruments that, while surprisingly easier to dodge than the last two, hit like a freight train and usually result in the Scarlet Mare getting far too close for comfort. If you manage to destroy those too, the boss fight ends instantly regardless of how much health the main mech has left.
    - That said, there's nothing stopping you from destroying one arm of the pair you're having the least difficulty dealing with, and wailing on the main body with impunity since you've essentially created a very large blindspot the machine can no longer adequately cover (It should be noted that Scarlet will always change out the arms her machine is using based on health thresholds, so if you're adopting this strategy, do note that you'd essentially be doing it 3 times at most and destroying the arms is arguably faster overall unless you're taking advantage of the extra range to constantly stagger the boss).

[Dash Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DashAttack): When wielding its twin blades, one of its attacks has it charge at you with its blades ignited. The move returns in *Rebirth*, now [with spinning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpinAttack).
[Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): When wielding its Makocannons, it will rain down energy blasts from above.

[Detachment Combat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DetachmentCombat): One of Scarlet's new tricks in *Rebirth* is to detach her arm parts and have them fight as independent drones, not unlike the Airbuster. Since this trick also means that spare arm parts can fly to her from her nearby airship, this also lets the Crimson Mare maintain its arm-swapping gimmick anywhere instead of only inside Scarlet's own test chamber.
[Didn't Need Those Anyway!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntNeedThoseAnyway): Its weapons can be destroyed to temporarily halt its attacks, but Scarlet will simply replace them with other weapons.
[Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding): The Crimson Mare can swap between twin swords, twin Makocannons, and twin drill gauntlets.
[Elemental Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalWeapon): It starts the fight armed with twin swords that it can ignite with flames for a [Dash Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DashAttack).

[Energy Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyWeapon): It can fire lasers from the Makocannons on its arms. Its Fullsade skill has it fire a [Wave-Motion Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaveMotionGun) from both cannons.

[Flawed Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlawedPrototype): Its analysis description points out that Scarlet designed it with form over function, and that its extravagancies — like the large open cockpit — provide exploitable weak spots.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): Two of its skills has it summon sentry drones and missile launchers to aid it in battle.
[Gatling Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GatlingGood): It's Bullet Barrage skill has it fire guns from its twin blades.
[King Mook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KingMook): It's basically a boss form of the common Sweeper and Cutter mecha mooks.
[Mecha Expansion Pack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechaExpansionPack): The Crimson Mare returns in *Rebirth* as Mark II, sporting a new jetpack and with its arms upgraded to be able to fly on their own.
[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): Despite its size, it is deceptively fast and has a plethora of damaging weapons and attacks.

[Logical Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LogicalWeakness): In *Rebirth*, destroying all three sets of the Mark II's arms will instantly end the boss battle, since doing so means the machine no longer has any means with which to attack you.

tropeName: Luckily, My Shield Will Protect Me
tropeNotes: [Luckily, My Shield Will Protect Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LuckilyMyShieldWillProtectMe): One of its weapon configurations has it armed with a large Claymore and a shield, which it can use to stab forward in a dash attack.
[Macross Missile Massacre](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MacrossMissileMassacre): Its Rocket Launcher skill, which is [Exactly What It Says on the Tin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactlyWhatItSaysOnTheTin).
[Mini-Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MiniMecha): Scarlet pilots it and it's only about 3 meters tall.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): A red dressed blonde rider piloting a bipedal [Mini-Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MiniMecha) with an open air cockpit? Looks like Scarlet's been taking cues from *[Final Fantasy VI](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI)*.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Its Flame Pillar skill has it conjure fire underneath Yuffie or Sonon.
[Spin Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpinAttack): It can peform on with its twin blades or its Claymore.
[Super Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperPrototype): Scarlet hasn't fully completed the design and considers the battle with Yuffie and Sonon a worthy test drive.

[Dual Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss): Of a kind; the Projector completely lacks any at all ability to defend itself, but it's also completely invulnerable until you've defeated the Diabolic Creation. The Diabolic Creation, in the meantime, is the primary threat in the fight, but is also, in actuality, a mere holographic projection that can be recreated by the Projector every time you take it down unless you destroy the Projector itself.
[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): The Diabolic Creation is no less monstrous than Specimen  H0512 .
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): The Projector brings forth enemies that you have to defeat before it's rendered vulnerable.

[Lost in Translation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LostInTranslation): The Diabolic Creation's Japanese name is "Heretic Rayleigh", alluding both to the Jenova-infused Heretic Hojo boss from the original game as well as Professor Rayleigh, a Shinra researcher from *Before Crisis*. The obvious implications being that the Diabolic Creation is a digitally preserved version of Professor Reyleigh post-exposure to Jenova cells.
[Master of Illusion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfIllusion): Of a more technological kind; the Projector can create replicas of enemies just from data.
[To Serve Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToServeMan): The Diabolic Creation is explicitly stated in its Assessment data to have been disposed of in-part due to its cannibalistic nature.

[Was Once a Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WasOnceAMan): Given the available evidence, the Diabolic Creation was likely a human infused with Jenova cells, with its Japanese name indicating it was [Professor Rayleigh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/BeforeCrisis).

[Adaptational Early Appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalEarlyAppearance): In *Rebirth* it's fought during the Nibelheim flashback, while in the original game it was encountered well after that point when the main party travels between Nibelheim and Rocket Town.
[Horn Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HornAttack): It has a Rhinoceros beetle-like horn jutting from its head, which it can use both to ram opponents and fire energy beams from its tip.

[It Can Think](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItCanThink): Sephiroth notes that the creature believes that the Nibel Reactor survey team is after the Materia in the region. Cloud suggesting trying to communicate with it, although it's clearly not interested.
[Power Pincers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerPincers): One of its sets of legs has powerful pincers it can use to grab opponents, incapacitating them.

[Adaptation Deviation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationDeviation): The role it plays in *Rebirth* differs from the one it did in the original *Final Fantasy VII* in a couple of ways:
    - In the original it played the role of overleveled [Beef Gate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeefGate) to force the player to learn how to capture Chocobos so they could evade it in the overworld. In *Rebirth* it's now the mandatory boss encounter for the end of Chapter 2. - After crossing the swamp in the original, the party would discover one of them dead and impaled on a tree, with the party presuming it was [Killed Offscreen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffscreen) by Sephiroth, [estabilishing just how strong he is if he can beat an enemy that the party had to avoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWorfEffect). In *Rebirth*, after defeating it, the snake will [pull Cloud underwater in a cutscene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadsIWinTailsYouLose) and Sephitroth will show to rescue Cloud, easily dispatching the snake with a spell that throws it out of the water and impales it on a tree.

[Adaptation Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationNameChange): Due to a mistranslation it was named "Midgar Zolom" in the original *Final Fantasy VII*. Now it's called Midgardsormr, which was the original intention.

[Adaptational Wimp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalWimp): In the original game, the Midgardsormr (or "Midgar Zolom" as it was mistranslated back then) was an overleveled [Beef Gate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeefGate) that you were expected to [run from](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunOrDie) instead of fight until much later into the game. Here, while it's still a dangerous enemy, becoming a mandatory boss fight means it can be defeated as normal,  (SPOILER)  though not killed, at least until [Sephiroth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousRescue) shows up.

[Bootstrapped Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BootstrappedLeitmotif): Its boss themes are all remixes of "Let the Battles Begin," the regular battle theme from the original game, which also played when fighting the Midgardsormr back then.

[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): It can shoot streams of flame that it can focus into a devastating energy beam.
    - In its second phase, it will start using its "Scorching Breath" attack, where it will breathe fire while doing a 360-degree spin. But it has a large windup and an obvious tell, giving the party a change to back away from it. - In its final phase, it will start using the "Beta'' attack, where it will fire a concentrated heat beam into the ground, creating a huge [Area of Effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AreaOfEffect) attack.
[Boss Arena Urgency](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossArenaUrgency): Its "Toxic Waters" attack will have it use its venomous fangs to spread poison into the marsh.

[Composite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompositeCharacter): Of a sort.  (SPOILER)  In the original game, the Midgardsormr who would attack the party in the overworld was a different individual from the one the party later finds impaled by Sephiroth on a tree (to justify why it can still attack you after witnessing that scene). Here, it's the same one.

[Getting Eaten Is Harmless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GettingEatenIsHarmless): In gameplay footage, the Midgardsormr's bestiary entry notes it likes to swallow its prey whole, and can do so to party members—incapacitating them until it's forced to vomit them back out.

[The Great Serpent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGreatSerpent): It's a colossal cobra-like snake with crocodilian scutes and horns on its head, large enough to easily swallow anything that trespasses in its territory.

tropeName: Heads I Win, Tails You Lose
tropeNotes: [Heads I Win, Tails You Lose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadsIWinTailsYouLose): After being defeated, it's no worse for wear and  (SPOILER) grabs Cloud in its coils before diving into the swamp to drown and devour him .

[Impaled with Extreme Prejudice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice): When it  (SPOILER) tries to eat Sephiroth, he conjures a whirlpool that launches it dozens of feet into the air and impales it through the head on a sharpened treetop .

[Mole Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoleMonster): It can dive underground for a few moments, before erupting from beneath a party member to catch them in its mouth in a [Grapple Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrappleMove). The only way to avoid the attack is by dodging it when [the water begins to vibrate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadVibrations).

[Mugging the Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MuggingTheMonster):  (SPOILER) When Sephiroth shows up to bail Cloud out of becoming the Midgardsormr's snack, it promptly tries to eat him and is effortlessly defeated in a [Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle).
[Tail Slap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TailSlap): Its "Sweep" attack will have it whip its giant tail in a 360-degree spin.
[That's No Moon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatsNoMoon): While coiled up and sleeping in the swamp, it's mistaken for an island by Cloud's team—who wake it up by clambering onto its back.

[To Serve Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToServeMan): It's a colossal monstrous serpent with a preference for eating humans, with signs outside the swamp warning travellers to ride a Chocobo if they're not especially fast.

[Swallowed Whole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwallowedWhole): It's [Grapple Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrappleMove) will have them grab a party member and swallow them whole, removing them from the battle for a time, before they're spit out.
[Use Your Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UseYourHead): In addition to the spiralled horns on the side of its head, it has a *Pachycephalosaurus*-like head-dome it can use to bash into opponents.

[The Worf Effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWorfEffect): After being defeated, a cutscene will trigger where the Midgardsormr will still manage to grab Cloud and drag him deep beneath the water, rendering Cloud helpless. But then Sephiroth shows up for a [Villainous Rescue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousRescue), and finishing off the enemy that the party couldn't handle with a single slash and a spell.

[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): The Mythril Golem, while being a recurring enemy throughout the series as a whole, was completely absent from prior installments in the *Compilation of Final Fantasy VII*.
[Red Eyes, Take Warning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedEyesTakeWarning): The only way to tell it has a "head" is because of the glowing red eyes on it, showing it's a hostile creature.
[Rock Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RockMonster): He's a golem made out of animated pieces of Mythril, having gained sentience due to exposure to Mako.
[Adaptation Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationNameChange): It was called Bottomswell in the original *Final Fantasy VII*, but *Rebirth* renames it to Terror of the Deep.
[Adaptation Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationNameChange): Was called Jenova Birth back in the original "Final Fantasy VII".
[Combat Tentacles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatTentacles): She has several tentacles sprouting from her body, and summons more of them during the third phase of her boss fight.
[Eye Beams](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyeBeams): In her second phase she can fire beams of purple energy from her numerous eyes.
[Eyes Do Not Belong There](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyesDoNotBelongThere): Sprouts several glowing, purple eyes across her side and on her tongue when entering her second phase.
[Multi-Armed and Dangerous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiArmedAndDangerous): In her second phase she sprouts multiple arms from the right side of her body.

[Metamorphosis Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MetamorphosisMonster): In her first phase she starts out dangling from the ceiling, but in her second phase she sprouts numerous additional arms and eyes, and crawls around on multiple bloated legs.

[Stationary Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StationaryBoss): In the first phase of her boss fight she's rooted to the ceiling by a tumorous mass of flesh, though in the second stage she detaches and starts moving around on multiple legs.
[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): The Grasptropod was completely absent from prior installments in the *Compilation of Final Fantasy VII*.
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): At first Cloud has two party members for backup, but they are quickly captured by the mech, forcing him to fight it alone.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): A boss with long arms on sand, that takes away two party members to fight solo is the staple of the Ruby Weapon. Unfortunately, cheesing it with unconscious members is not possible.
[Moveset Clone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MovesetClone): As a modified version of the Valkyrie, it shares a lot of its moves and animations with its previous iteration.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): Can create wind-elemental cyclone by beating its wing.
[Feathered Fiend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeatheredFiend): It's a large, predatory avian monster with sharp claws and multiple wings.
[Animal Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMecha): It's a Shinra war machine built in the shape of a giant frog.
[Mini-Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MiniMecha): It's a bipedal frog-shaped war machine. The description says it's semi-automated, which is why even someone as incompetent as Palmer can pilot it.
[Wave-Motion Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaveMotionGun): It's strongest weapon is a massive laser cannon.
[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): Specimen  H1024  was completely absent from prior installments in the *Compilation of Final Fantasy VII*.
[Cthulhumanoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cthulhumanoid): It's just as grotesque and inhuman as Specimen  H0512  was, this time having multiple limbs.
[Punny Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunnyName): It's a variant of  H0512  and its name is the same number doubled.

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): Once his vengeful spirit is pacified enough to communicate, he invites the party  (SPOILER) into the hellish realm that the Gi Tribe carved out for themselves deep underground and asks that they retrieve the Black Materia so that he can use it to free his people from their suffering by granting them oblivion—glossing over that doing so would destroy the Planet and wipe out all other life in the process . Even when reminded that Aerith is a member of the hated Cetra, he simply remarks that [she is a Cetra in bloodline only](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreACreditToYourRace).

[Bishōnen Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BishonenLine): When fought as a boss he's a giant skeletal warrior missing the lower half of his body, but when he later appears before the party to accompany them to the Village of the Gi Tribe he appears as he presumably did in-life.

[Climax Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClimaxBoss): The second Climax boss of *Rebirth*, defeating him opens a great deal of lore behind the Cetra and the Gi, as well as expounding upon the origins of the Black Materia that becomes the focal point of the last third of the game.
[Dem Bones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemBones): When fought as a boss, he manifests as a hideously monstrous floating skeleton.
[Glowing Eyelights of Undeath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlowingEyelightsOfUndeath): When fought as a boss, he has glowing red lights for pupils in otherwise empty voids.
[Skeletons in the Coat Closet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkeletonsInTheCoatCloset): When fought as a boss, he's clad in armor made of monster bones—including a fanged skull for a helmet.

[Time-Limit Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeLimitBoss): When he enters the final phase of his fight, he casts Doom on Red and Barret. A timer appears above both their heads and they have until it reaches zero to finish Gi Nattak off.

[Vengeful Ghost](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VengefulGhost): Like the rest of the Gi Tribe, centuries of being denied acceptance into the afterlife has filled him with spite and rage, twisting him into a nihilist who only desires oblivion.

[Moveset Clone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MovesetClone): Shares a lot of attacks and animations with the Diabolic Creation, with the biggest difference being that the Variant does not have the Projector to assist it.

[Multiple Head Case](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultipleHeadCase): While not in personality, one head will sleep while the other head being awake affects its attack behavior, meaning that Cait Sith has to adjust tactics.
[Was Once a Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WasOnceAMan): One of the many results of Hojo's experiments.
[Adaptation Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationNameChange): It was called "Lost Number" in the original *Final Fantasy VII*, but *Rebirth* renames it to Forgotten Specimen.
[Barrier Change Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarrierChangeBoss): It will continuously swap its resistance from physical to magic throughout the boss fight.
[Adaptation Deviation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationDeviation): It was never fought in the original game, as Vincent never attacked the party originally.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): Vincent's other monster forms don't make an appearance, but a later phase of the boss fight has red tendrils spread across the arena and the Galian Beast uses several Chaos themed attacks, a reference to Vincent's other, more powerful alter ego.

[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): Despite its immense size and strength, the Galian Beast is also among the fastest bosses in the game, even outspeeding Roche. It's this to such a degree that the game goes out of its way to pause and warn the player that a vicious battle lies ahead.

[Morphic Resonance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MorphicResonance): Even moreso than in *Dirge of Cerberus*, the Galian Beast retains many traits of Vincent's human form, including its claws having gold armoring in place of his gold details, belts around its limbs, and its hair is the same as Vincent's but longer and more wild, and the ends gradient to red to give the imagery of his cape.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): It ends the fight with Chaos Flare, a dual reference to the Galian Beast's Beast Flare attack in the original *VII* and Vincent's Chaos transformation. Its Assess intel also describes as "a creature of Chaos".
[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): It serves as this for Vincent, who transforms when trying to kill Avalanche for snooping around Shinra Manor.
[Rapid-Fire Fisticuffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RapidFireFisticuffs): Most of the Galian Beast's moves consist of brutalizing the party with long combo strings of punches, claw swipes, and kicks.

[Schmuck Bait](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SchmuckBait): The Assess entry for the Galian Beast advises attacking it during certain moves where it stands still to Pressure it. What the entry fails to mention is that doing so will cause Vincent to deliver an extremely fast, powerful, and wide-reaching counterattack.
[Shadow Discretion Shot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShadowDiscretionShot): The cutscene preceding it only shows its silhouette on the wall as Vincent's body gruesomely transforms into the Galian Beast.

[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): It's a fire-breathing dragon. Its description says it has an organ on its chest that allows it to spew flames. Attacking it will cause its breath to lose some of its range.

[Our Dragons Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDragonsAreDifferent): It's a fairly classic take on a dragon, being a red, fire-spewing wyrm who's able to fly and is the guardian of an ancient temple filled with lost relics.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): It wields a gigantic sword that is almost as tall as it's whole body.

[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): Iron Giants have been in the world, but a specific variant called Ironclad was completely absent from prior installments in the *Compilation of Final Fantasy VII*.
[Top-Heavy Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TopHeavyGuy): Has a huge torso and disproportionally smaller legs.
[Dual Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss): The fight begins with only one Demon Gate, but once it's brought down to half its health, another Demon Gate will pop in from the opposite wall.
[Stationary Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StationaryEnemy): It's stuck to the walls of the temple for the entirety of the fight.

[The Walls Are Closing In](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWallsAreClosingIn): Its Encroach move cause both walls of the temple to close in, which shrinks the area the party has to maneuver to dodge the Demon Gate's attack.
[Adaptation Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationNameChange): Was simply Jenova Life in the original game, a name it retains in Japanese and other translations.
[Beam Spam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeamSpam): Starts firing more and more eye-lasers as the fight progresses.
[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): She can spit noxious bubbles from her mouth as one of her attacks.

[Death Glare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathGlare): Her skeletal face is locked in a perpetual one which is punctuated even further [when she gets right up in the camera's face](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFourthWallWillNotProtectYou) to give the player a "lovely" view of her human-like eyes during the transition to her second phase to show just how pissed she actually is.
[Combat Tentacles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatTentacles): She has several bladed tentacles, including a long segmented one extending from her upper body, that she uses in combat.

[Metamorphosis Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MetamorphosisMonster): In the first stage of her boss fight she has a Gigeresque caterpillar-like lower body formed from scraps of flesh stretched across a rib-cage and spinal column, a pair of vestigial malformed wings with several eyes, and several bladed tentacles. In her second stage, she transforms—sprouting a pair of large malformed butterfly-like wings.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag):
    - The penultimate phase of the fight with her serves as one to the Bizarro Sephiroth fight from the original game as it takes places on a series of platforms and has you alternate between party members as you slowly whittle the beast down by attacking its body parts. - In the final phase it becomes more red and uses fire based attacks, much like the later Jenova Death boss fought later in the original game.
[Pre-Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PreFinalBoss): The last foe faced in *Rebirth* before the final boss.

[Stealth Insult](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StealthInsult): Two of its attacks, [Mourning Wail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway) and [Lachrymal Exhale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BubbleGun), are named so to  (SPOILER) further mock the sudden loss of Aerith.
[Adaptational Early Appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalEarlyAppearance): In the original game, Summons weren’t made available until after leaving Midgar.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): In the original game, Summons were relegated to just sticking to their traditional *Final Fantasy* purpose (that is to be utilized in combat) with no proper lore nor background given to their existence within the  FF7 -verse, specifically. The remake not only gives most of them backstories of their own, some (like Shiva) are even portrayed as legendary figures who've played major roles in ages past.
[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Summons only offer their materia's bearer aid in particularly difficult fights, relishing the challenge of a worthy opponent.

[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): The three DLC Summons (Cactuar, Carbuncle, and Chocobo Chick) weren’t in the original game, although Cactuar and Carbuncle have both been summons in other entries in the franchise.

[Defeat Means Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefeatMeansFriendship): In the majority of cases, defeating a summon in combat is all you acquire their respective summon materia. This is even lampshaded in the achievement for defeating a summon in *'Rebirth*: "You Work For Me Now".
[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): When each Summon runs out of time, it unleashes a devastatingly powerful attack before disappearing.

[Olympus Mons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlympusMons): Most of the Summons are [deific entities](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhysicalGod) born from the Lifestream, and are thought to have once been worshiped by the Cetra. <sup>note </sup>  Bugenhagen reveals in *Rebirth* that the Cetra were actually [atheistic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatEarthAtheist), though many of the deiform entities called forth by the Summon materia *were* worshipped by ancient humans.  While most of the original Cetra-made materia used to summon them have been lost to the ages, Chadley is able to recreate them using battle data obtained from Cloud's team.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): Inverted. The Summons in the original game are more of an element of gameplay, since they are Summon Materia - obtainable magic items to be used in battle. Beginning with *Remake*, the Summons become more integrated into the background and lore of the game, like Shiva encasing Jenova in ice in the past, or other summons becoming local deities worshipped in different parts of the world.
[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): Each entity is tied to a red materia, which calls them forth when they sense its bearer is taking part in a difficult battle.
[Big Red Devil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigRedDevil): He has a very demonic appearance, possessing horns, fangs, claws, and black-and-orange skin that looks like cracked lava.
[Horned Humanoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HornedHumanoid): He is a bulky humanoid being that possesses a pair of long, backswept horns — accentuating his demonic appearance.
[Our Genies Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurGeniesAreDifferent): He's a demonic djinn that possesses control over fire.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): He's a demonic fire-djinn, and most of his attacks involve him hurling flames at his opponents.
[Tornado Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TornadoMove): His Ultimate Attack, Hellfire, causes him to fill the battlefield with a tempest of flames.

[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope). Unlike most of the main summons, Jessie gives Cloud Ifrit's Materia without needing to fight it, but Ifrit himself appears as a boss in the final VR Combat Simulation gauntlet alongside Bahamut when the latter's HP is about halfway gone.

[Adaptational Modesty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalModesty): Zigzagged. Shiva wears a few more pieces of clothing in the Remake than she did in the original game, but the new armor pieces have holes in them and the fabric is translucent, meaning she actually shows *more* skin than she did in the original.
[Amazing Technicolor Population](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmazingTechnicolorPopulation): She has light-blue skin, which is the only thing that makes her look inhuman.
[Attack Drone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackDrone): After being staggered once, she'll summon ice familiars that orbit around her and nullify her weakness to Fire.

[Deity of Human Origin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeityOfHumanOrigin): According to her dossier, she was once a queen who "healed the planet's wounds" with her powerful ice magic, implying she was a member of the Cetra in-life.

[Hero of Another Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroOfAnotherStory): Two thousand years ago she fought and defeated [Jenova](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination), sealing the planet-eating alien inside a glacier.
[An Ice Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson): Shiva wields ice-magic so powerful she created the glacier covering the northern continent.
[Magical Barefooter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicalBarefooter): She's a magical summon whose humanoid form has no footwear.
[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): She's a beautiful woman who's scantily clad.
[Mystical White Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysticalWhiteHair): Shiva has snow-white hair, befitting her powerful ice-magic.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): She's an optional boss available to fight in VR Combat Simulation and isn't part of the main story.
[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): She was once a queen who fought to save the planet when Jenova attacked.

[Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic): Contrasting her icy move set, Shiva is scantily clad — though [not quite as underdressed as she was in the original game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalModesty).

[Turns Red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnsRed): Shiva can enter a state where she Pressures herself, making her more vulnerable to being staggered, but attacks much more relentlessly with larger and more powerful versions of her previous moves.
[Acrofatic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Acrofatic): It's surprisingly speedy for being so heavyset, and is capable of jumping surprising distances.
[Battle Aura](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleAura): It emits downy wisps of golden energy in battle.

[Big Fun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigFun): Being a chonky chocobo with comical attacks and abilities that is regarded as a symbol of luck and fertility, it is basically *Final Fantasy*'s counterpart to Budai/Hotei of the Seven Lucky Gods.
[Decomposite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecompositeCharacter): It's based on the fat chocobo that would rarely appear when the Choco/Mog summon was used in the original *Final Fantasy VII*.

[Enemy Summoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemySummoner): It can summon plush versions of Bombs and Tonberries to fight alongside it, and very rarely a Cactuar, the last of which is a prime candidate for the Assess log's [Last Lousy Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastLousyPoint).
[Eyes Always Shut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyesAlwaysShut): Its eyes are always shut, accentuating its comical appearance.

[Ground Pound](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GroundPound): Its Ultimate Attack, Kerplunk, has its moogle companions (somehow) carry it up in the air and then drop it to make it smash down onto the battlefield butt-first.
[Mystical 108](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mystical108): In *Rebirth*, the Queen's Blood card "Fat Chocobo" is card number 108. Appropriate given the Buddhist undertones of this big bird.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): He's an optional boss available to fight in VR Combat Simulation and isn't part of the main story.
[Rolling Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RollingAttack): One of its moves have it rolling around the battlefield, flattening enemies in its path.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): The Chocobo deals wind-elemental damage.
[Energy Ball](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyBall): The Moogle attacks by firing blasts of magic at its enemies.
[Martial Arts Headband](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MartialArtsHeadband): The moogle riding the chocobo wears a white martial arts headband, possibly signifying its status as a warrior.
[Natural Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NaturalWeapon): The chocobo attacks with its beak, wings, and talons.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): The original summon was the first summon the player could acquire in the original game, and was subsequently outclassed by both other summons & higher-level magic.
[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): They are the only non-DLC summon that is never faced in battle.
[Zerg Rush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZergRush): Their Ultimate Attack, Stampede, summons a flock of chocobo to trample the opponent.
[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): It can spit [a torrent of water](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash) from its jaws.
[Dragons Are Divine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonsAreDivine): It's a sea-dragon so massive that its full body doesn't appear when it's summoned, and is worshipped as a god in Wutai.
[Giant Wall of Watery Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantWallOfWateryDoom): Its Ultimate Attack, Tidal Wave, summons a massive tsunami to flatten its enemies.
[Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash): Many of its attacks are water-based, fitting its nature as a divine sea-serpent.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): The developers initially intended to go with the typical [Fire, Ice, Lightning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIceLightning) trio of Ifrit, Shiva, and Ramuh, as summons, but decided to drop Ramuh for Leviathan to homage the original demos for *Final Fantasy VII*, where Leviathan was a summon materia equipped on Aerith during the opening raid on the Sector 8 reactor. With *Remake* and chapter select, players can now recreate that scene.
[Old Save Bonus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldSaveBonus): It can be obtained in *Rebirth* by having save data from *Remake*.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): Leviathan is an optional boss available to fight in VR Combat Simulation and isn't part of the main story.

[Plot Lock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotLock): Due to the combination of Leviathan flying around the battlefield and its size, it cannot be summoned in certain battles due to the battlefield otherwise limiting its movement.
[Sea Serpents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SeaSerpents): It's a serpentine sea-dragon with fins on its neck, though it flies using a pair of small wings.
[Shockwave Clap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockwaveClap): It can create a shockwave of water by flapping its wings.
[Tail Slap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TailSlap): One of its attacks involves it sweeping the battlefield with its massive tail.
[Teleportation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Teleportation): It can warp around the battlefield by diving into the ground.
[Tornado Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TornadoMove): Its Tidal Roar ability creates damaging water spouts that move around the battlefield.

[Battle Aura](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleAura): His Umbral Aura skill has him cloak itself in an aura that deals [Damage Over Time](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamageOverTime). As it gets closer to using Megaflare, the aura gets stronger.

[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): His classic Flare Breath skill has him breathe purple fire. Also, his Umbral Inferno skill has him fire several [Homing Projectiles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HomingProjectile) from its mouth. It also breathes purple flames onto enemies it manages to grab, and its Ultimate Attack — Megaflare — has it spit a ball of plasma that deals 9999 damage.
[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): Many of his attacks, such as his Umbral Strikes skill seem to be darkness-based.
[Dash Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DashAttack): One of his normal attacks has him perform a spinning dive at you.
[Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): His Divebomb skill has him dive at your party from above with a small explosion.
[Destroyer Deity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DestroyerDeity): In *Rebirth* Chadley calls it a god of destruction, noting that he's surprised it has even more powerful forms.
[Dragons Are Divine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonsAreDivine): It's a legendary dragon-god thought to have once been worshiped by the Cetra, though it's actually the least-powerful of the Bahamuts.
[Energy Ball](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyBall): His Umbral Strikes skill has it conjure orbs of darkness in his hands and toss them at you.
[Eye Beams](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyeBeams): His Umbral Gaze skill, a move he rarely uses, has him fire lasers from his eyes that will inflict Stop on anyone they hit.

[Fantastic Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticNuke): His [Signature Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignatureMove), Megaflare. Bahamut will periodically begin a five-second countdown and gather energy around himself. When the countdown ends, it will use Megaflare and deal massive damage to your party. Staggering him will reset the countdown and remove his aura.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): Halfway through the rematch in the final simulator gauntlet, Bahamut can summon Ifrit.
[Grapple Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrappleMove): Bahamut can snatch opponents up in his talons, and blasts them with a torrent of purple flames.
[Magic Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicNuke): His Megaflare attack has him spit a ball of plasma that creates a mushroom cloud explosion and deals 9999 damage.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): Bahamut is an optional boss available to fight in VR Combat Simulation and isn't part of the main story.

[Plot Lock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotLock): Due to the combination of Bahamut flying around the battlefield and his size, he cannot be summoned in certain battles due to the battlefield otherwise limiting his movement.
[Put on a Bus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PutOnABus): The major summon of *Remake* not brought over to *Rebirth*. Bahamut Arisen takes his spot in the summon lineup for all intents and purposes.
[Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming): All of his skills are prefixed with the word Umbral.

[Time-Limit Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeLimitBoss): Calling back to some prior incarnations of Bahamut and Tiamat, shortly into the fight Bahamut begins a five-count to casting Megaflare. While the attack isn't a guaranteed [Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill), it might as well be.

[Wolverine Claws](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WolverineClaws): His main form of offense comes in the form of swiping you with his scarily long, powerful claws. His Claw Swipe skill has him drag his claws along the ground and release four waves of energy while his Umbral Frenzy skil has him perform a deadly eight hit combo with his claws.

[Death of a Thousand Cuts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathOfAThousandCuts): It wouldn't be a Cactuar without its trademark 1,000 Needles and 10,000 Needles attacks, both of which fire countless thorns at its opponents.

[Downloadable Content](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownloadableContent): Cactuar is only available via either the Deluxe Edition or alongside Carbuncle in [the more expensive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrackIsCheaper) 1st Class Edition.

[Spike Shooter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpikeShooter): Its only Special Attack is 1,000 Needles, where it fires a rapid volley of thorns at a single opponent. Its Ultimate Attack — 10,000 Needles — has it fire an omnidirectional barrage of spikes.
[Barrier Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarrierWarrior): She casts Barrier and Manaward on your party to protect them from damage.
[Canon Foreigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonForeigner): Carbuncle did not appear in any form in the original game or any of its spin-offs.

[Downloadable Content](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownloadableContent): Carbuncle is only available via the 1st Class Edition, which includes a copy of the Deluxe Edition and Cactaur as part of the package.
[Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy): She is the only summon that doesn't actually attack enemies.
[Status Buff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusBuff): She casts Haste on your party to increase their speed.
[Support Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportPartyMember): All of her summon abilities are supportive in nature rather than offensive.
[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): It's a downy baby chocobo that wields powerful black magic.
[Downloadable Content](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownloadableContent): Chocobo Chick is only available as pre-order DLC.

[Elemental Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalPowers): Has attacks for all four in-game elements: [fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire), [ice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson), [lightning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe), and [wind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway).

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): While Ramuh is usually considered a powerful summon in *Final Fantasy*, he tends to not move around much in action-based games and his attacks are almost universally limited to lightning magic. When fought as a boss, Ramuh is able to teleport freely around the arena to keep up with Yuffie and has more physical prowess than usual, with several attack that have him use his staff to strike her, and he can also attack with a flail construct formed from electricity.
